review:
(THIS GAME IS INCREDIBLY GOOD FIRST OF ALL IT'S GREAT IT'S REALLY FUN AND HARD)
... However this PC version crashes all the damn time, making the DLC especially pretty much a huge pain to try to enjoy and complete. I wish I could go back to it, I had planned for a 100% playthrough going in, but it just sucks so much and it's so demoralizing to deal with the perpetual crashing constantly kicking you out of the groove of some amazing runs in this GREAT game that is FUN AS HELL when you can actually play it without interruption.

(I FULLY RECOMMEND THE ACTUAL CONTENT OF THE GAME IT'S REALLY PEAK STUFF)

Play this on PS5 if you have one. I don't so I'm stuck with this. Shoulda gave it to Nixxes.

I really liked this game, even though it STRUGGLED to run on my computer. I would probably like it more if I played it at 60fps. Anyways, story is abstract at times, I tried to pay attention but gave up after a while. The bosses are really fun, though some of them are shockingly easy at times. Example, the final boss gave me no issues what so ever compared to minibosses or certain enemies. I enjoyed it. Excited to see what Housemarque does next!

The gameplay is fun, The story is ass. It ends with more questions than answers and sort of sequel baits even though there's no way in hell this game is getting a sequel. Once the story is over there's no real reason to keep playing. Might be a fun weekend game if it's on sale. For full price? hell no.

This is probably the most underrated game ever how this did not win game of the year back in 2021 or receive any awards is hard to believe.... the gameplay and character movement is so smooth and the combat is so satisfying... Only other game that gave me this kind of experience is Doom 2016 and Doom Eternal... Graphics are good with a really great particle system. The narrative and story while seeming confused at first is actually executed brilliantly and makes a lot of sense once you get to the end of the game... This game gave me an experience that I will not forget for a very long time and nowadays there are very few games that do this for me. The PC port does have some small issues here and there like stuttering at times but there are mods to fix that and overall I had a good experience. Co-op feature is really good especially at the beginning when the game may feel very difficult but it can be hard to find people as many do not play on pc... Overall I would recommend this game if you like rougelite shooters and want a different and unique experience compared to most games out there.

Incredibly memorable and thought provoking, Returnal provides a unique and worthwhile experience. It is regrettably held back by its simplistic roguelike elements.

When the best character upgrades are simple stat increases it robs the game of its complexity. With few exceptions, increasing Vitality and Damage is absolutely the best choice for your resources. I would have liked it if the upgrades in this game granted combat power to the player through effects which then resulted in more effective vitality or damage rather than immediately giving a percentage stat increase.  To illustrate this point further, in Risk of Rain 2, Ukulele isn't a good item because it just increases your damage. It's a good item because it also has a chance to create arcing chain lightning which can reactivate your other on-hit items. The same principle applies in Noita with Chainsaws allowing for wand wrapping. In Returnal an artifact that executes this principle well is the Resinous Shield which grants you a shield against the next hit when you pick up Resin. This is much more interesting than a damage/integrity/protection augment and I would have liked to have seen more items like this.

I believe that the developers expected that having weapons with random traits would provide enough variety in conjunction with the malfunction and parasite systems but the latter are so often not worth engaging with due to their random negative effects. Debuffs such as "suffer damage when collecting items" or "suffer damage on Overload" are completely debilitating effects since they fight against muscle memory and in the case of the former, effectively halts item progression entirely until you can cleanse it.

I would like to see a version of this game where weapon traits are collectables that can mix and match with all the base weapons. I also disliked the proficiency system as it encourages repeated use of the same weapon. Encouraging the player to use different weapons with a reward system such as in Hades would have helped alleviate stagnation. Perhaps increased experience gains for a certain amount of kills. Furthermore, A simple 1-2-3 melee combo would have done wonders to the game's flow. Add a weapon which expands the melee skill set too while we're at it.

The elite monsters are absolutely the most dangerous encounters in the game and a fair criticism of the encounter design is that the power budget for elites is too high and a portion should have been allocated elsewhere. Returnal largely becomes a game of surviving these elite encounters and is less engaging once you master its fundamentals.

When all is said and done Returnal is still an amazing game and every video game enthusiast should try it. Something which can not be overstated is the incredible attention to detail. The lead up and conclusion to the fourth boss really was one of those once in a lifetime gaming experiences. It is burned into my soul.
Great quality if you have the specs for it

I strongly recommend this game (if you like a challenging game...)
Visually it's beautiful, great art design, great atmosphere and lots, lots of particle effects
From a technical point of view the PC version is a mixed bag: it's superior to the PS5 version (I have finished the game on PS5 first and on PC then) but has few technical issues. In particular is very stuttering even on a powerful PC (I have played the game on a 4090, a Ryzen 9 7900x, 32GB of DDR5 @6000MT and a 980 PRO NVMe SSD). I think the problem is the frame cap that doesn't work as it should. Turing off all the ray tracing effects and using the Vsync to avoid going over the 120Hz of my monitor solved the majority of the stutters, but some (traversal stutters) are still present. In 4k at 120fps this version was still a superior experience to the PS5's one and the stutters are not game breaking (at least at 120fps), but it's a shame that the game has this small "stain"

This game is a horrific manifestation of anxiety, an eldritch abomination which infiltrates your mind with the sole intention of causing distress.

Whilst playing this game I am utterly captivated by the atmospheric music and visuals. The sound of rain in the dense forest rolling down my suits display as I search through cryptic log files for clues. Slowly walking through the cyclopean architecture as I listen to the mad ramblings of a Selene who came before, I prepare for the confrontations that await. The horror and panic as, out of the corner of my eye, I spot an Apollo Astronaut who shouldn't exist, watching me.

On offer is one of the purest escapes from our reality that I've ever experienced, but it comes at a cost. This game has imparted upon me a perpetual sense inescapable dread. By the end, the flow of my mind mirrored the cycle: endings, beginnings, all mixed into one endless undecipherable loop circulating through my head. Whereas for Selene, the cycle will stretch on into the starlit void of eternity, I will be set free from this madness at the end of my inconsequential lifetime, but until then, I will savour every moment that I've spent on Atropos.
Addictive arcade game play, very progressive and stylish. rogue-like perfection. excellent game!

[h1]One of the Best Rouguelites with AAA Quality[/h1]

[h2]The Setup[/h2]
We play as Selene, an Astra Space Scout. Players instantly find themselves in a crash on to an unknown planet. Our job is to survive the fauna and dangers of the planet. It's not long before we realize that the planet holds more secrets about Selene than we imagined.

The game makes us go through multiple biomes with multiple arenas that holds multiple kinds of bosses and sub-bosses in store. If you die, you start from beginning but some items and upgrades remain across the runs. However, this changes once we reach halfway into the game.
All the arenas and level are procedurally generated and weapon and item drops are all random. Thgis may make getting all achievements a bit frustrating.

[h2]The Gameplay[/h2]
It's a third person shooter where weapons and melee feels satisfying but the accuracy and feedback takes a back seat. This isn't a bad thing as killing the enemies is just a way for progression to next level and gun upgrades. The dopamine rush comes from the Adrenaline mechanic that reward players with instant boosts if we manage to kill multiple enemies without taking a hit.
Not taking a hit rewards the players even more with the fact that with full health, all the health pickups (Silphiums) become Silphium Resins that contributes to increasing the health pool.
This is where my major gripe from the game comes from. Once you become accustomed with the gameplay mechanics and figure out how to become fat by optimizing health pickups, the game becomes a bit too easy. It feels like enemy levels don't react much to our health pools.
[b]There's a sure shot way to make this game easy: Grow health pool and just explore each an every corner of every room in each run![/b]
Having said that, I had a lot of fun playing the game and one of the bosses actually tested my skills where I defeated it with a sliver of health left.

There's a lot of platforming thrown in as well where every biome will have some items locked for traversal that can be unlocked by the items we receive by progressing into the game.
[b]If you can't reach any item in any arena, just remember that the game is designed to make you play again and you may reach that item in next run with permanent item unlocks earned via story progression[/b]

[h2]The Visuals[/h2]
The game looks and runs amazing on mid to high-end builds. It supports Ultrawide and DLSS as well as Frame Generation for RTX 40 Series and above cards. The art of this game is inspired by a lot of space and sci-fi media and they've done a good job of creating a game the looks and feels fabulous. There are a few stutters here and there but mostly it's a solid PC port of a visually stunning PS5 game.

[h2]The Story[/h2]
I particularly loved the story presented in a non-chronological and psychological horror style. The story would appear a pretty basic distress and escape run but the distress runs too deep once you progress further into the house cutscenes. These segments may appear all confusing at first but once you understand it by piecing together all the various logs and cryptic scriptures in the game, it becomes clear that it about deep traumatic experiences and guilt.
There are two endings of the game: one is a basic ending that brings more questions than it answers and then there's a true ending that can only be achieved my making minimum two full runs of the game by watching all house cutscenes, collecting a few separate items and killing the final boss again.
Even after achieving this true ending, if you have questions like I had, just open any story explainer on the internet and it will become crystal clear.

[h2]My Rating[/h2]
[b]9/10
This is truly an underrrated gem from Housemarque that got put away by a lot of people intimidated by its initial difficulty and confusing story presentation. But those who stick by and take effort to understand every aspect of the game and the story, are rewarded by an unforgettable experience. it's most definitely a MUST PLAY[/b]

Addictive

The PC version of this game has SEVERE TECHNICAL ISSUES!

My system is a Ryzen 9 5950X, RTX 2070 (8GB), 32 GB DDR4 RAM. Game is installed on a SSD (as recommended).

I have tried everything that people discuss about the crashes online:
- Disabling Steam Overlay
- Disabling Steam Controls
- Using DX11 Mode

I tried in 4K with DLSS, without DLSS, with Resolution scaled down with HDR on, with HDR off.
I tried 1440p with DLSS, without DLSS.
I even downgraded the graphics driver.
I also tried with a Radeon RX580 (8GB) in the same system.

THE GAME KEEPS CRASHING!
It crashes in irregular intervals. Sometimes it's fine for an extend time, than it crashes every 15 minutes.
Other bugs that keep appearing are:
- Audio bugs
- Texture loading bug
- Game briefly minimizing and reappearing paused (without crash)

The crashes happen during boss fights, involved story sequences and during mundane gameplay (no enemies in the room, just browsing for items).

It is really sad, because the game is really great. The rougelike gameplay is great. The Combat is awesome. The presentation is great, even on low/mid settings. But the crashes are so bad that it kills all fun and immersion. It's really that frustrating when the game crashes on an intense boss fight, that just had you on the edge of your seat.

The issues will probably not be addressed by the publisher. Since Sony Interactive Entertainment sees its PC releases as an advertisement for people buying PS5 Consoles, PS5 Controllers and signing up for their Playstation network.

Really really sad.
But I can not recommend playing this version unless the "fatl error" crashes are fixed. Which does not seem very likely.

Returnal is a must go if you like Rouge-lite games, it has a very good gameplay and it becomes more rewarding as you advance through each of the levels. The game highly rewards skills, so it encourages you to master-it. However there are something you must know before you enter this game, being a Playstation AAA comes with it's downfalls and Returnal does not escape this. 

The first and most important it's the length of each run, as I told before this is a rouge-lite game, however that doesn't mean (in this case) that is a short game. Each run is pretty long if you ask me taking about 1-2 hours (or more) to complete one cycle, this can be exhausting at most times and frustrating if you are killed in a advanced zone so be prepared for that, you can also pause the game and return but we both know that when you're in the zone this will not be your first choice. I think the fact that is a AAA makes it be longer and that enters in conflict with the type of game that it is (for me it should have short but addictive runs).

The game fails in giving a proper level-up if you one to skip early zones, you would find that doing a complete run will alwayd give you more level/resources/upgrades than not doing one and the game doesn't even try to compensate a little (so you don't have to do the first level over and over again), it just gives you a weapon scaling and that's it there is no health, perks, consumables or resources scaling which makes complete runs mandatory in order to be prepared enough (it's not necessary to do all the zones of the run but at least one).  Also it the game can be a little dumb at the time of giving you upgrades, this are supposed to be random (which is greate is part of a rouge-lite experience) but for example there is a resource that is used to increase the level of your weapon, I was in the last zone already preparing for the final boss and I used the last of one of the resources (keys, which you use to open great value chest) and it gave me a material to increase my weapon level WHEN IT WAS ALREADY AT THE MAX LEVEL -.- so I literally throwed to the garbage that key, I'm not saying I should always be given what I want but the game could be a little more intelligent it that sense and take out of it's random roulette that type of item.

It's final weak point is it's re-playability, in most games I enjoy collecting all the secrets of a game as long as I can do it in a very organic way by just playing and having fun with the game, however due to the randomness of this type of games, it can turn tedious to do it because you can do 5 runs doing all the rooms of a level and that one recording that you need to complete all the recordings of the level will not appear, so be careful if you want to obtain all collectibles. Also it's perks - downgrade system (called Parasites) is not as well done as I would like, something having great-pearks at very low cost or having horrible downgrades for mostly nothing but that clearly depends on the player.

I know that I talked a lot about it's weakpoints but as I am already recommending this game I prefer to talk about that, being that said, Returnal is a fantastic game, it's game mechanics are extremely fun to master and very rewarding, for me the enemies are very different from level to level despite people saying otherwise (it's true it recycles somethings but for me it isn't thaaaat of a copy). THE BOSSES ARE VERY GOOD, really if you like bullet-hells this a very nice 3D attempt, it's environment and world building is pretty solid to me is not fascinating but it gets the job done, also it has very good sound effects that are pretty immersive. A must-go if you like challenges and as I said before rouge-lite experiences.

Returnal is a roguelike game with two major problems. 

Even though the game have some good elements, the gameplay is quite shallow and boring in many aspect. Overall balance is not very good. The gameplay does not have enough variability.  Optimal play requires too much backtracking. The game is too long for its contents. Even though I beat the certain bosses at the first try, it felt too long.

The story starts somewhat interesting but becomes uninteresting eventually. The story looks like sci-fi on the surface, but actually it is that of [spoiler]a horror game.[/spoiler] Another point is that the storytelling is not appropriate for a game with this long playtime. The game never explain the story clearly and leave it to a guess. Constantly watching that kind of storytelling over extended period of time feels really tedious. Moreover, there are [spoiler]a normal ending and a secret ending. After getting the normal ending, I lost my patience and watched the secret ending on YouTube. They did not feel sufficiently meaningful to justify neither tedious storytelling nor long playtime.[/spoiler]

Additionally, the game have memory leaks and requires restart every couple hours. (I would still advise not to play this game even if the memory leaks were fixed.)

I genuinely do not understand what people see in this game. (not that I judge anyone for enjoying it!)

Considering that I only heard praise for this game and the combination of a roguelike with bullet hell elements sounded like a match made in heaven, I had very high expectations.
However, I was left extremely underwhelmed by this title.

While the game- and gunplay is quite fluid, fastpaced and fun, the roguelike elements are genuinely terrible.
There's only a handful of weapons to choose from, many of which don't even feel that special or unique from one another.
So you already have a small base-set of weapons to vary gameplay between runs, but the items you can find - which should be the lifeblood of any good roguelike - are super boring too!

It feels like 99% of items are just variations of "increase damage by 10%", "increase damage by x% if you can maintain your adrenaline buff", "increase max HP%", "increase damage reduction", "get lifesteal".
Congratulations, you've now witnessed the vast majority of upgrades you can find in Returnal.

This means that every single run feels exactly like the last one, because no item in any way seems to actually affect *how* you play, it's all just stat increases!

Now add on top, that a "run" will last 2-3 hours (!!!) and always features the same half dozen or so bosses, you can imagine there's little to motivate me to come back to playing this ever again after rolling credits.

I'm frankly just happy I managed to beat the game with just 3 deaths and 7 hours of playtime, because I don't think I would've enjoyed having to redo up to 3 hours of lost progress if I had died in the last biome.

Returnal, at it's base is a decent game in terms of gameplay, but in my opinion the roguelike elements add absolutely nothing to it and it would have benefinited much more from being a simple linear game instead.

I really wanted to enjoy this all the way back since I've heard people talking about it when it released on PS5.
But for the life of me I can't see how this game is getting so much praise.

Well known, easily encountered run ending bug (Portal Room) still exists a YEAR after release. What's worse it happens in the last zone so you're guaranteed to lose a lot of progress if this happens.

Brings it down to an automatic 0/5 regardless of whatever positives I had, no desire to play again. You should do right by the people who bought your game and address the problem!

 There's a fix to the graphic bug/memory leak after an hour or so, i shall linketh down below. Worked for me.

Go to "Returnal\Engine\Plugins\Streamline\Binaries\ThirdParty\Win64" and change the nvngx_dlssg.dll to nvngx_dlssg_o.dll.

I will probably finish this game eventually, but this game is really close to being good except for one problem.

Everything looks the same. Every enemy looks the same, items use the same colors for multiple different types of items. I can't tell when I am about to pick up a health upgrade or a healing item because they are both green blobs on the floor. I can't tell if the item is cursed or if it is one of the permanent currency items because both of them are purple blobs on the floor.

I can't tell if the enemy I am about to face is going to create a red circle, or shoot rapid fire following shots, or a shotgun burst of shots because all of the enemies look like tentacle creatures.

They need to sort out the colors and silhouettes of enemies so the game is more readable. THAT is the only thing holding this game back.

You may still have fun with this game, it is well made otherwise, but it is a terrible loss for what comes down to a failure of art direction.

I love roguelike games and this one hits the nail on the head. I am extremely picky and critical of games but this one I cannot find any flaws

This is still to date my favorite PS5 exclusive. Well, now it's on PC so it's  not a PS5 exclusive anymore, but you get what i mean. I'm not even a big shooter fan, i play this and the Borderlands franchise in that genre.

The gameplay is top notch. You can feel the weight of your character but never have the impression you're maneuvering a truck. The controls are very snappy and precise. When you die, it's to be put on you on and almost never on the game. It's hard, i won't say it's not, but it's fair. I never had the feeling the game was going out of its way to kill me, unlike the Souls games sometimes do (with debatable tactics like delayed attacks and such). Returnal is not 'viciously' hard and i rarely felt frustrated when i had to start over again.

If you enjoy sci-fi and weird atmospheres, there are good chances you will like this. The story is interesting but pretty cryptic, everyone will have their own interpretation of it i guess, it leaves a good amount to the player imagination.

Technically speaking it's pretty good, i play in 4K 60 FPS and didn't notice any major stuttering. In a sense it was to be expected as the game on PS5 was flawless in that department. Not sure in what state it was when it first released on PC, but now it's quite good.

One of the most addictive games I've played in a long time. Really pretty looking, runs super well, and the gameplay is SMOOTH. I also really am enjoying the story. It's a very ambitious game, and I think it does everything well. The story sequences are especially polished and feel straight out of the newer Resident Evil games.

The main (non Tower of Sisyphus) 'runs' do get pretty long, making it not feel so much like a rogue-like to me, more of a mix between linear game + rogue-like. It took my 5 hours to get through biomes 1-3. That's long! Compare that to other rouge-likes like Binding of Isaac where the runs are typically much shorter (and frequent). It definitely IS a rogue-like though, it just feels very different from other games I've played where in a play session you'll do multiple runs. With Returnal, I found each run to be way longer.

However, the Tower of Sisyphus runs are a nice diversion from the main runs. They are faster paced and just focused on combat. No running around big maps, looking for secrets. These runs are more like Binding of Isaac and they offer their own scoring system.

I'm in shock at how polished this game is! It is just plain fun.

"Frustrating, Buggy, and Held Together by Gaps and Glitches"

I wanted to like this game, but it’s a frustrating mess. The combat, reliant on a Gears of War-style active reload system, should have been satisfying—if it weren’t for the clunky, unreliable timing that drains any potential enjoyment. Pair that with a grappling hook that doesn’t even function in the first two biomes, and you’re left with a combat experience that feels broken right from the start.

The game’s core loop is uninspired, featuring bullet-hell patterns and floating platform mechanics that feel recycled from countless other titles (think NieR or Drakengard). It’s as though an indie developer pieced it together in a few hours using asset store assets—lacking creativity or any real innovation.

But what’s worse is the storytelling. It’s an attempt at being symbolic and melancholy, but instead comes off as inconsistent, poorly delivered, and unnecessarily depressing. The narrative leaves so many gaps, seemingly in an effort to make players fill them in with their imagination. What could’ve been a compelling story ends up disjointed and incoherent, feeling like a patchwork of ideas that never fully connect.

And the bugs? They’re rampant. During the Helio's home sequence, I encountered a game-breaking glitch where the stairs soft-locked me on the second floor, causing me to lose progress and artifacts. Worse still, I couldn’t even save my cycle during the story sequence. For a game with an always-online design, it’s unacceptable for it to be so unstable.

In the end, this game feels like a joyless grind—a frustrating mix of poor mechanics, incoherent storytelling, and constant bugs. Even at 75% off, it’s hard to recommend spending money on what feels like an incomplete and broken experience.

Yes fun. its a rouge like so when you die you restart. You don't need to defeat all the bosses once you beat them again. I rarely write reviews but this game deserves all the praise in the world! It is so rare to come across a unique experience having grown up with games since the early Atari. But - for this reviewer at least - Returnal offers just that. It is not any of its parts that make this such an immersive, novel, and satisfying title. It is the organic whole that blends the gameplay, storyline, and audiovisual elements together to give us something that almost feels alive. As for the difficulty level that many reviewers comment on, I personally find it just right for a formerly invested and currently very casual gamer. I use mouse and keyboard and have felt no need to switch to my gamepad. It is, I suppose, a matter of taste. But like everything else in this game, the difficulty and respawn cycle are intimately connected to the story line. Just sit back and cherish the ride.

Despite all my praise, there is one thing I do dislike, and it's something many people bring up. This game is very poorly optimized for PC. The game looks amazing, but that doesn't come with unstable framerates and occasional stuttering. I know it isn't just my PC either, because these problems persist whether I have it on the lowest settings or the highest ones. So, if unstable framerates are something that bother you, you may want to skip out on this otherwise amazing game.

Gorgeous god-Tier Gaming experience.  From gameplay and reincarnation mechanics to storytelling and design, Returnal did not disappoint, in fact, it excelled.   Loads of fun and loads of replay value (which is really what its all about with roguelikes at the end of the day - is it not?).  In an era where are there are so many beautiful games with compelling stories it can difficult to stand out in a memorable way like the games of yore but Returnal does exactly that.

There were major aspects of the story which were shocking and somewhat disappointing at first but I've grown to appreciate these narrative choices and the fact that they differentiate this tale from the typical sci-fi romp. I had fun with it and i think that folks to enjoy a bit of narrative depth, psychological horror, breathtaking graphics, and adrenaline-pumping battles will have fun with it too.  

be advised: make sure that you have the hardware to run this game smoothly (regardless of graphic settings) as it deserves at least that.  Furthermore, i was initially prompted with a warning stating that my hardware was incapable of playing the game and thus i closed the game and ordered the parts to upgraded said hardware.  However, as i was waiting for the new GPU to arrive, I realized that i could simply close the warning and play the game despite it (no fancy bypass or know-how required. i simply closed-exited the warning prompt).  That being said, my PC was running at relatively high temperatures whilst running the game smoothly on low-mid hardware settings.  After the hardware update, i no longer experienced the warning prompt or temp issues. points being, 1. make sure that your PC can run the game before you buy it 2. the warning prompt regarding hardware requirements not being met does not necessarily mean you will not be able to play the game

This game is amazing.

It presents a lot of systems and mechanics to challenge me, keep me on my toes, and incentivize trying new things. There's not a reroll system, which I thought was a bad thing at first, but have come around to it - The real reason there being no re-roll system is OK in this game is because it's very well balanced. There are for sure spikes of difficulty at times, but a re-roll system doesn't FEEL necessary, whereas it does feel necessary in many other games I've played. The lack of needing and having a re-roll system keeps the runs fresh and new - you're not able to re-roll for some effect, what you see is what you get - and it really embraces the ideas of roguelite games. 

So far, after 26 hours of gameplay, the only issue(s) I have encountered have been texture downgrading after the game has been running for an extended period of time, and the game run requirements being extremely high. On the plus side, for the first issue you can 'pause' your run, so relaunching the game is a viable option which addresses the issue. For the second issue, there's really no fix, you just need the hardware. This, unfortunately, means that the game isn't viable for the Steam Deck. 

The game has a non-linear method of storytelling, and it gives you little bits here and there and has really drawn me in. 

This game actually plays like what "AAA" games are said to be but often are not - fully featured games with fun gameplay and well thought out design. Everything really came together for this game, and it's top notch. 

TL;DR: As long as you meet the hardware requirements (which are quite high compared to most games), and you like roguelites give this game a go. It's an awesome experience, and I'm not one to rate games as highly as I rate this one.

It's worth noting that there are still some tech issues with this game.  Several people have reported a memory leak and lots of stutter.  I'm not 100% on the former, but I've definitely experienced way too much stutter.  On a VRR OLED, the flickering gets really bad too, so bear that in mind.  Also, don't play with ray tracing.  RT isn't properly optimized, and some late-game areas will absolutely tank your framerate due to horrible CPU under utilization not unlike what is seen in Jedi: Survivor and Ghostrunner 2.  Your mileage may vary depending on how willing you are to put up with these issues, I found it exhausting but it didn't ruin my experience.

That being said, Returnal is hands down my favorite PlayStation-published game I have played since Bloodborne.  It the most brutally punishing video game I have played in my life, but it is home to some of the best combat scenarios, levels, and bosses I have ever encountered.  When the game hits, it hits hard.  It also makes great use of the DualSense controller, though it needs to be plugged in for the haptic feedback and triggers to work.  I really love this game so much, and thoroughly recommend it to anyone looking for an ultra challenging bullet hell and/or roguelike experience.

The fact that the game instead of a lame effort on extending the playable hours of the game, trying to bait ppl in cuz rogue-like popularity of games this years went higher than it should have, being based on replaying over and over the same thing with a "different map" while barely advancing in the story, and the only mean on actually advancing... is

The main character quite captured what Metroid was to many of us (not literally in this game tho), a legendary bounty hunter ("not very fun fact but..." in the years it was developed it was a "hidden fact" in some countries that it was a woman, so hell yeah, an almost consumed fighter there that didnt need anything but a new objective and nothing could stop her! that was literally why i bought the game... it was like i saw her) Once again, not the same but u sure get some of those vibes the more u get to know Selene, the voice acting, behaviour in general... which i really liked most of the time, the character felt... kind of original and... honestly just in case u play the game or watch it, for me she was the best part of the game by far. wow with the "cutscenes"... just loved those.

Keeping the equipment? ever heared of upgrades for " YOUR CURRENT WEAPONS?" i get it, the idea in this game goes... in a different way, and sadly+mostly cuz of making it rogue-like... but still! at least make it an option, it just get tedious and repetitive as hell.

The map, SUCH an AWESOME designs they have, but they screwed up like the devs from Remnant (Other stuff that i love, but precisely this part sucks) again adding more "forced replayability", would have been infinitely better if you just made a map, big as it could have been and super awesome for what i saw they can do, and that you can actually enjoy.

The storyline, since it depends on spawn and... dying...  it gets 4kd up because of the same i mentioned before, imagine that you actually get to see the story of a game since u start playing it to the moment you see the "credits"? i have to say, its cool that when you die in game, you see a cinematic slightly changed, depending on where u reached and what u got to know, that is very cool, but not worth the rest of the game!

I wish they put some thought into it and made a decent story mode, and leave this... messs.... as an extra gamemode, i didnt play it online, but while you play u find some "holograms" of "other players" and when you finish watching them something comes and tries to... sure as hell not invite you to dinner xD

Imagine having Alien, Prometheus, Edge of Tomorrow, The Abyss, Metroid Prime, PT, and Nier all combined into a single game, together with stunning visuals, lash environments, and atmospherics music, you get Returnal.     

Depending on your luck (and skill), this game can be a treat or a living hell.  Due to the rouge-like nature, one moment you are obliterating everything in your path, and the next you just walked into an ambush and got absolutely pounded to dust by groups of over-powered enemies.  

The control is very well done, movements are responsive, firearms are varied and enjoyable to use.  However the RNG is kind all over the place, the difficulty spike can be very sudden and unforgiving, and that's what kept this game from reaching Hades' level of enjoyment.

The overworld is a chore to get through, however he boss fights are some of the most enjoyable moments in the game.  Each boss all have their own bullet hell patterns, which are beautiful and deadly at the same time, once you memorised their patterns it will be easy to beat all of them.  

The game can be brutal at times, but it also rewards patience and exploration, don't be afraid to sidetrack, you might just find something useful to help you live and fight another day.

[h2] Returnal[/h2]

I definitely enjoyed it - the game turned out to be a mix of Remnant and Risk of Rain, which is a definite plus since I liked both projects. I also appreciated Sony's approach. They managed to create a very dynamic roguelike with satisfying impact and shooting mechanics, incredibly beautiful visuals, and they added a cinematic approach to the storyline, which includes elements of mystery, drama, and horror.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3282463806
Returnal is a roguelike for the wealthy. I think the pricing policy became a barrier to the game's popularity, because for most people, roguelikes are typically in the mid-low price segment. But here, Sony suddenly makes an almost AAA game that no one asked for. However, given the costs, it's impossible to sell such a game at the same price level as other roguelikes, so it was a risk, and it's still unclear if it paid off.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3288343674
During the full playthrough, there were a few unpleasant bugs, like a camera glitch after teleporting, or instances where the teleport itself wouldn't open. But overall, these bugs didn't affect my impression of the game. The game isn't very long; at various stages, it seems like you're reaching the end, but then it turns out there's more to go, requiring you to gather your strength and keep going. The difficulty level is moderately challenging, as you would expect from a roguelike, so you will have to die one way or another. The bosses are also relatively challenging (relative to the Elden Ring DLC, hehe), but overall, the game makes you sweat.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3285666368
In the end, I recommend trying this product, but it might be worth waiting for a discount. It's a high-quality and interesting cooperative experience with a friend. I'm not sure if it would have been better if the co-op supported more than two players, but I think having up to three players might have been optimal.

I have the impression that the developer tried to make Space Hades in 3D but completely failed to understand what made Hades fun.

Hades offers a ton of variety and choices before and during every run. Hades offers you several very diverse weapons and allows you to tweak how those work by letting you choose between several interesting upgrades. 

In Returnal you don't really have any choices or any way to tweak the playstyle to you your preference. Upgrades basically just give you a stat boost and do not change the way you need to play and every weapon drop you'll just compare the damage numbers of the weapon in order to decide if you want to pick it up or not. 

Essentially, death after death you grind you way back to the next Boss fight until you learned the pattern of the Boss and then you move on to the next Boss. Imagine playing the darksouls 1 Bosses who did not had a bone fire right before the fog wall. It's like that but the walk to the Boss is way longer and you need to grind for weapons and upgrades before you can go back to the Boss.

It does not help that the game has some annoying technical issues. There soft locks which can cost you a run and for some reason the frame rate can drop below 20fps during Bosses even besides running on a solid 60FPS the entire time before the encounter. Let me tell you that's not a fun way to die against a Boss.

Oh and gyro aiming would have been grate, dunno why so many Playstation games refuse to give you this option, ti's a shame

This game is beyond boring. The regular enemies and traversal of the procedurally generated biomes is way too easy. Bosses, on the other hand, take 25-33% of your health with every hit, meaning you can survive at best 3 or 4 hits. Bosses are also an hour away for each attempt. So the game loop is to slog through the biome, to attempt the visual cluttered mess that are boss fights. The first two bosses have taken me 3 tries each to kill. One try per phase, where the visual clutter just gets worse.

I thought this would be ok because I heard the story was this amazing work of art. There is no story. It's awful so far. Nothing about it is captivating or interesting. It's just a generic groundhog day in space. But by far, the dumbest design decision the developers made was the healing mechanics. In most roguelikes you get a set number of heals with predictable refills. Healing in this game is backtracking 8 rooms to find the little green plus sign (+) on the map only for it to not be a heal but component to upgrade your max health.

This entire game is probably 10 hours worth of content stretched to 40-50 hours by horrible and boring design choices. I am bored out of my mind and uninstalling. Everything in between the bosses is worthless anyways, so might as well delete it. This game would have been 1000x better if it was just a boss rush game like Furi.

Overrated trash. OK, it's not unplayable, and it's partially even fun. They had some unique ideas, like monsters similar to games like Prey (the newer one), looping as in Edge of Tomorrow, mental issues made manifest in movies such as The Babadook or games such as Hellblade: Senuas Sacrifice. The gameplay is pretty unique too, a weird mix of 3rd person over-shoulder shooter meets bullet hell meets rogue like dungeon crawler.
But the game feels frustrating, unpolished, grindy, is 2x as long as it needs to be, stops being fun in 1/4 of that time AND it's already over after only 14 hours despite all the grindiness they designed. And they want 60$ for this without a sale? Are they fucking out of their minds? This game is worth 20-30$, tops. It neither has the well polished gameplay that addicting roguelikes such as Hades or Dead Cells have, nor the impressive action, motion capture, and interesting characters and story that great tripple A games from Naughty Dog like Last of Us, Uncharted 4 or God of War have. This game is pretentious and greedy and it pisses me the fuck off.

Pro:
-unique monster design and setting 
-unique gameplay idea combining 3rd person shooter, bullethell and roguelike

-Con:
-too expensive for what it is
-too grindy, and yet still too short. takes a special kind of incompetence to make a game feel too grindy and have it end after just 14 hours
-bad difficulty. early on too hard and RNG reliant, but in a good run with good RNG too easy. I oneshot the final boss and didnt even lose more than 25% of my max HP. meanwhile I died probably 10-15 times just to get this one good run. frustrating, unfun
-3rd person shoulder view sux for this kind of game. you need to be able to clearly see all the projectiles, enemy positions, ledges you can fall off etc. feels frustrating as fuck to play with this shitty perspective
-too few good roguelike features that the competition such as Dead Cells already had. not enough reroll options to lessen the impact of RNG, no guaranteed weapon etc drops at the start of certain zones, etc etc. you mostly just have to keep dying until you get the good run
-shit story & story telling. 90% is unsatisfying, mysterious and vague lazy ass story telling at the side, then at the end its suddenly like "oh it was all in her head". fuck that. writers should never have a job in the industry again. with great movies such as The Babadook that pulled this off perfectly theres no excuse to deliver this underwhelming story

Returnal peca mayormente de dos cosas: es corto y tiene muy pocos incentivos para ser rejugado más allá de sacar el final verdadero o todos los logros. Personalmente también lo he encontrado fácil pero entiendo que eso es ya una cuestión de cada uno (fácil para mí puede ser difícil para otro).
[b]Artísticamente[/b] es una pasada. El sonido te pone los pelos de punta en ocasiones y los enemigos, sin haber una gran variedad de ellos, cumplen bastante bien. Me habría gustado un poquito más de variedad en los biomas aunque no están nada mal. Los jefes finales son una pasada.
La [b]historia[/b] no es que destaque precisamente. Es sencilla y sirve de excusa para que te pongas al teclado y ratón a matar bichos. Aún así he de decir que, aunque la historia de Selene no me interesó lo más mínimo, la del planeta Átropos y de la civilización xeno me ha dejado con muchas ganas de más.
En tema [b]controles[/b] el juego funciona a la perfección tanto con mando como con teclado y ratón. El movimiento es preciso, rápido y fluido, al igual que el gunplay.
En definitiva, recomiendo Returnal a todos los que seáis fans de este género. Más allá de sus defectos es muy divertido, y en este tipo de juegos creo que eso es lo más importante. Eso sí, nunca pagaría precio completo por él y me esperaría a alguna oferta. En mi opinión es el típico juego que debería haber salido a precio reducido.

What to say about returnal, interesting idea, terrible realization. I dont recommend it.
Between one of the worst stories in a games i ever saw, non existent balancing and runs that can take 10 hours its hard to recommend it.

The length is a big problem, if you finish it in one go, the game is 7-10 hours long, but if you are more of a casual player failing few hours into a run will probably make your blood boil as you get into 40h+ of repetitive grind of getting stuck on some boss.
Dosnt help that "finishing it" dosnt come with any rounded up narrative, its an open to interpretation mess with no focus that might as well be summed up with "it was all a dream" or maybe not, who knows, game isnt interested in explaining anything.
Another big problem is that its not a typical roguelike, you dont unlock anything, you dont have to experiment to find what works, you get a linear progression of upgrades you need to progress and you will get it in a single run.
Finally the difficulty, for me it was way too easy, but i could tell it was only since weapon balance is non existent, i just picked best guns and face rolled everything, yet  i could tell that if i used a bad gun the game would be practically impossible for most people. Im really not a fan of games that punish you to this insane extent for wanting to try stuff out.

In the end its not a sucesfull attempt at third person roguelike, Remntant 2 seems like much more of a success.

The sickest, most creative game I've played in a long time. It still has me completely hooked even after I finished the game. You play as a deep-space astronaut that gets stranded on an alien planet where an elder sentient civilization met its ultimate demise. The alien technology and weapons are beautiful and reminded me a lot of the aliens from Altered Carbon aesthetically. The weapons and upgrades you acquire are so much fun to use even though the stats are randomly rolled, and you don't unlock all of the weapons until the last biome (biome 6). The art design, boss design, sound design, and every other aspect of the game blew me away completely. I will admit it is not an easy game, bullet hell is overwhelming at times, you die way too often as you're learning how to hack it, and it requires a great deal of patience, but I found the combat way more enjoyable and unique than most Soulsborne games. The bosses and enemies are a bit Lovecraftian and otherworldly. The level design transports you from overgrown forests with strange alien altars made of stone and advanced technology, deserts, subterranean frozen tunnels, and deep under the sea. I am so happy this released to PC, and I haven't had many issues at all with the port. This is a 10/10 for me. I love this game and yearn for anything even remotely like it.

I hesitated to buy this game, reading about the performance issues. But I gave it a try, and I'm so glad that I did. With a 2080Ti and 3900x, the game was more stuttery than other games, but to me it was still playable. I would get around 115 FPS at 1440p with DLSS. Now with a 7900XTX and 7800X3D, I can get 180-220 FPS at 1440p with FSR. And it is running incredibly smooth.

It's true that an unknown number of people have memory leak and serious performance issues with this game. Housemarque needs to address this for the sake of those customers. Looking at the negative review percentage can give you an idea of how many. I suggest you look into the forums to find out more. Just remember some people are giving this game a thumbs down because they don't understand that they bought a roguelike, and others because they think they meet the minimum system requirements, but they are trying to run this game on a laptop or handheld that is below the minimum system requirements.

In the end I wholeheartedly give this a thumbs up. Don't forget to try the "Tower of Sisyphus" content, it might be your favorite part.

I played this game for dozens of hours on PS5 when it came out - one of my favorite games ever. Couldnt resist dipping back in on PC to enjoy higher end performance. This game is not for every one. It's hard, it's punishing, its unforgiving, and the mechanics that allow you to get stronger between runs are not as obvious or intuitive as other games. It reminds me a bit of games like Sekiro, where its a game that forces you to learn its mechanics and play on its terms. If you don't, you'll have a terrible time and drop off. If you do, you'll be rewarded with one of the most immersive, flow state conducive, rewarding gaming experiences of your life. This is one of those games where years later I can still remember how it affected me playing for the first time. I wish I could wipe my memory and experience it for the first time again.

An amazing addition to the rouge-like library. With not only amazing graphics, but an engaging story and combat system. Interesting bosses and bullet-hell mechanics to top it off. Highly recommended for anyone who enjoys 3rd person shooters.

As a package, this is worth getting, and is at the very least interesting in a way that you wouldn't expect.

The story is a little nebulous, but in a good way. The house sequences about Selene's life are probably the best moments of the game, because they add tension so well. It's almost like the Silent Hills game we never got. You wouldn't expect for a rouguelite shooter to keep you thinking about the character and who they actually are, but it keeps everything just intriguing enough to make each run worthwhile. It does feel like they sort of ran out of time near the end and didn't get to flesh out the story as much as they wanted, but the multiple layers of symbolism at least make this tolerable.

The actual randomization elements are a little questionable; there really aren't that many permutations for each biome, and most of it comes down to whether a gun you get is helpful. There are some guns that are just straight up better in almost every scenario, and the same goes for upgrades. You can even tell that the game thinks some guns are nonviable because there's always conveniently a handgun waiting around near bosses in case you have a gun that just wouldn't work. In that regard, while most runs are generally salvageable, some runs just have a chance to end up on easy street through what feels like no strategy of your own. I think this probably impacts all roguelite games, but you feel it here.

I'd say the weirdest thing is that it feels like there are two permanent upgrade systems. The first one is the explicit one the game tells you about, which is the ability to unlock new items for future runs. Some of these are shortcuts to help with restarting runs with further progress into the story, but most of them are just unlocking the opportunity for new items in future runs. This system isn't great, because some items are better than others, and permanently throwing a new item into the randomization pool that you don't like makes future runs feel slightly less possible. However, I think there's a subtle undisclosed second system where it starts helping you out a little with each subsequent run. I noticed near the end it would just sort of give me more free stuff near the beginning, even throwing non-hostile enemies into the initial landing zone just to provide a little bonus. I finished the game after probably 20-30 deaths, so who knows how aggressive this gets. Take this for what you will: on one hand, you know there's help for getting to the end. On the other hand, it might make your wins feel cheaper.

Extremely strong recommendation, my current roguelike fascination.

Compelling and gripping gameplay with extremely tight controls. Interesting and engaging story delivered slow-burn over the course of multiple runs. Extremely addictive.

I experienced some performance issues, though those mostly went away when downscaling to 2k from 4k. Said performance drops were mostly dips from >60fps down to a little under, so locking the framerate to 60 may also help this feel less bad. Game still looks great at 2k on a 4k monitor.

Excellent Rogue-Like, Sci-Fi, Third-Person Shooter.

     Starting with the obvious: The story here is top tier. There's multiple ways to interpret this games story, as seen by the various videos online. It's mysterious, yet captivating. It gives good progression of information, as to not leave you totally confused at random points in the game, but also shadows information behind various details and descriptions like you'd find a Souls game. You can enjoy this games "surface level" story if you don't want to hurt your brain too much, or you can dig deep into the trenches and discover your truth of what the "underlying" story might be.

     The graphics and performance are also excellent. I will note though that I have an i5-13600K with a 4080. I didn't experience any graphical issues that other users have experienced, so perhaps it's a rig dif.

     Combat is fast and very quick to pick up. There's not 500 different mechanics to this game. It's as simple as picking up and playing. You have a weapon. You can swap it for other weapons you find on the way. Each weapon has a secondary fire/ability with a cooldown. There's traits each weapon has that's pulled from an RNG pool that you can level up to make the weapon better, and that's really it. There's consumables with different effects along the way but at the end of the day, this is a basic, fun shooter. There's no ammo, just an overheat gauge for every weapon. 

     So onto the not so fun part: This game is punishing. Note that I said punishing, not difficult. This game is also very difficult, yes, but the "bash your head against the wall" moments come from the punishment you receive when dying. If you've been around the block with Rogue-Likes before, this is nothing new, but to those that haven't, allow me to explain.
     As you progress through the game, you collect different upgrades via Artifacts (free buffs) and Parasites (trade-offs, like Corrupted Mods in Warframe. 1 good thing at the cost of 1 bad thing). Additionally, you get health upgrades, up to a max of 300%. You also get Weapon Proficiency, which I believe is capped at 15 for Act 1, and 30 for Act 2. The more Weapon Proficiency, the more damage and extra neon homing bullets your gun shoots. If you die, all of it is gone. You will literally "return" as though you started a NG. Imagine playing Dark Souls, starting out as a Deprived, getting to Anor Londa with decent gear and +'d gear, dying, and then losing everything and becoming Deprived again and starting back at the Asylum. That's what it's like. With the exception of the first "mini-boss" you're supposed to die to in the beginning, I got to Biome 3 before I died and lost everything. That was a depressing moment.

     When you die, everything resets. This is a farming technique for collecting Scout Logs, Ciphers, etc, because the game is like Warframe where there's "tiles" for the Biome, and when you die and "return", the world respawns with randomized tiles. There might be a Scout Log or Cipher that spawns in a specific tile, and if it's not there at the time after exploring that Biome, you'll need to die to reset the tiles. It's literally RNG hell. Note, in regards to story progress, you can skip to where you left off, such as when I died in Biome 3, I can skip through the enemies in Biome 1 and 2 and go straight to Biome 3. Provided a "lock-down" doesn't happen which forces me to stay in said tile until I kill all the enemies.

     So why is this punishing? Because each Biome is generally harder then the next. You thought things were tough when you had all that health and those upgrades? Now do it as a lvl 1 scrub. You'll essentially have no choice but to try and re-farm to get some decent weapon instead of your starter pistol, as well as some health upgrades so you don't get obliterated late game. Ah, but of course, while farming, you die and reset all over again. Or perhaps you got to where you wanted to be, battled the boss and then died. Now you have to re-farm all over again because there's no possible way you can beat that boss with even less health, less damage, and no upgrades.

     As you progress through the game, you realize that chests are basically useless as they primarily provide RNG weapons. Well if you already have a Weapon you like, then there's no reason to waste a key to open it unless you want to gamble a Artifact, which can be bought with Obolites at certain parts anyways. That, or level up a specific trait for a specific weapon which is more so endgame/completionist stuff. 
     Ether is only good to "un-curse" health upgrades. Using Ether on chests is a waste for above stated reasons. Ideally, you'll want to use the keys for locked doors to try and 100% the game (if you're a completionist), as some Scout Logs, Ciphers, etc. are in optional rooms, not main rooms.

     Point is, the players time is incredibly important, and when you waste the players time, you're disrespecting the player and it gets incredibly annoying. I played this game back on PS5 before they had a "suspend" feature. In other words, if you played for 2 hours and had to get off, if you didn't keep the game running, the moment you left the game/turned your console off, it was equivalent to dying because you reset when you loaded the game back up. The game was very punishing at launch to the point where the Dev's had to add that feature and then some. I actually Rage Quit at the end of Biome 5, right before getting the final key to enter Biome 6 (final area), because I had to battle a Sentinal, which I killed, and then 2 Sentinals spawned after that and killed me and I lost all my progress. I "returned" my game to Gamestop so fast. Never waste a players time. 

     Of course, I ultimately returned to the game once it came out on PC :)

     RNG also sucks. Like I said, this game is all RNG in regards to the tilesets, which effects collectibles. The collectibles are needed to enter "Act 3", so you have to get them if you want the "True" ending. The same goes for the DLC. If you want the true ending to the DLC, you need all the collectibles, which means lots and lots of farming, lots and lots of dying, lots and lots of RNG, and lots and lots of broken objects around you as you try and travel up the 60 stages of the Tower (you will NEED to beat the final form of the boss that spawns every 20 stages. The final form is essentially stage 60).

     I suppose you could use a Trainer to save yourself a boat load of headache but some people like the suffering. Anyways, the game is genuinely a great game if you have a rig that can handle it and you don't rage quit it. It's a sin not to experience this game at least once. And by once, I mean technically hundreds of times before you experience the full games story since it requires you to nearly 100 percent to get the true endings. Cool stuff though.

     Oh yeah, Co-Ops dead. Which is a shame because I wanted to continue playing it and also help people out who might be struggling with the games difficulty but alas, no one's there. You can only attempt one coop session per death. If your partner dies, you won't be able to do a coop session in that BIome until you die/return. But ideally, that won't happen, as you got two people kicking butt that can res each other, but you never know.

     Anyways, great game, just wear a helmet while playing it.

Make sure to watch a gameplay and understand what you are getting into. If you don't like what you see, it's a lot of that and it's awesome. Great rogue-lite, bullet hell experience. Has a crowd that will love it.

Difficult game at least to start with. Initial few deaths would feel very discouraging because your hour or 2 long progress can be dashed in minutes.

Permanent unlocks are weapon traits but it took a while to figure that out, You also probably get better with practise.

On the positive front, the gameplay is superb and it features at least two memorable boss fights that will leave an impression for sure. There is a secret ending which I haven't yet tried. Gameplay is fast paced and one must say you would generally prefer a break to come back to it later.

For all those who plan to check it out, there are three built in cheat in the game for people to figure out:
1. Toggle always run on in the settings
2. Aiming down your sight will slow you down, accuracy ain't required much. Go with hip firing and move!
3. Electropylon Driver

Best of luck!

Main thing I wanna rant about is the weapons. oh my god they are all very underpowered. I'm 6? zones in currently and with the vast array of weapons on offer I would only consider 3-4 actually worth picking over the starting pistol. I AM AWARE that weapons get stronger as you use them more often and unlock their unique traits, but what is the fun using a very underpowered weapon for a long time just so that it becomes usable later on. I don't want to have to throw away runs leveling weapons, I just want weapons that start ok-ish, and then grow to powerful. Right now the weapons start awful and grow to decent.

For example, the carbine that starts unlocked is at it's base form is a good weapon, with traits that change the playstyle of it and increase it's effectiveness a little. A weapon later in the game, [spoiler]the tripwire, fires 1 tripwire bolt per shot, and needs to be chained onto an enemy to deal good damage, is kinda awful. the bolts are a projectile, so they're hard to aim, and you constantly have to alternate between shooting a bolt at the ground and then at the enemy for some mediocre damage. In this state it's slightly better than the starting pistol but nowhere near the carbine with no traits. However, with the shotgun trait, this gun now fires 5 bolts at once in a pattern and it's the most broken run carrier I've ever seen[/spoiler]

Not to mention the whole range of weapons that are slow firing, 1 shot magazines, or the shotgun in a mid-long range shooting game. Recently I unlocked a weapon that charges a massive beam attack, but [i]slows you down while charging it[/i]. This is a bullet hell game that requires constant movement. Slowing down is death

Weapons aside, this is a really cool game with fun bullet hell mechanics and a gripping story. Is it worth $60USD? Hell no, pick it up on sale, if your computer can even run it. You're paying extra for the graphics, not the gameplay. If weapons were just tweaked a bit, a little more damage, traits unlocked quicker, necessary traits for a weapon to be not straight up detrimental unlocked by default or on every copy of the weapon, game would be 5/5 stars. Currently though, the weapons are too much of a run-decider depending if you run into one of the few good weapons in the pool, can't be more than a 3/5.

This is one of the best roguelike games I have played, but I can also find some things I would like to change.

What's good:
- The game is easy to grasp and at the same time have a lot of things to discover.
- The visuals, atmosphere and immersion.
- The amount of options and the quality of the graphics settings. Having a performance benchmark in game is awesome.


What's bad:
- The amount of content for the price. Compared to other roguelike games this is expensive, even when on sale.
- Some times it feels very unfair, like the difficulty spike of certain enemies was an excuse to force you to die and extend the lenght of your playthrought. I would like the game to be a bit easier in general too, like taking less falling damage and having more checkpoints near bosses or that those that you bought in another biome count. The general design theme of the game is don't get hit and if you do don't get hit again in a short period of time.
- The early biomes have a bit too many items locked until you get unlock skills later. In my case when I unlocked being able to dive and walk over lava I never came back to the first areas of the game, so those areas were always harder than they should be. This is something that happens in lots of games, but since I find this one harder I feel like this is something worth mentioning.
- Several important issues with coop. It seems like coop was an afterthought because there are several key points in the game where in order to even see the prompt to progress the other player has to leave the game and you need to save your cycle, restart the game and continue the cycle. Also if by some chance your partner gets kicked out because a disconnection, a game error or because they have to leave temporarily or for whatever reason, then in many points in the biome you are not going to be able to resummon him because you can't go back to the summoning sphere. Also your partner doesn't keep any progress made in your game, he gets your progress only when he joins you.

By far the only real next gen game Playstation has released.
A beautiful, disturbing and incredibly challenging experience that is flawless in execution. Having now played the game on both PC & PS5, the experience is also further enriched with kb/m controls.

It's fine. I like rogue-likes but was not expecting it to be so punishing that it feels like a grind. Long term upgrades are minimal so runs feels only like training your eye-hand coordination for the next boss. I don't like that there are so few positive-only pickups in each run; Almost everything is a trade-off so if you're risk-averse then the game trains you not engage with any mechanics except shooting.

Locomotion is hard to get used to at first because it's so quick and snappy, but it does help with the eventual bullet-hell flow state.

Weapons have neat alt-fires, but fall into the trap of them being useless in many situations. Especially against bosses. Hope you like holding down left mouse button.

Story is engaging and I'd like to see it culminate but to be honest I won't be able to get there.

Level design is dark and muddy. It's hard to traverse in third-person and breaks in the terrain or not always obvious.

This is the most expensive rogue-like I've played and I can't say it's worth it unless it's on sale.

Que jogo maravilhoso! Com certeza Returnal está entre os jogos que eu mais gostei de jogar na minha vida! Ele foi o primeiro e único Roguelike que eu animei zerar até hoje. Joguei sozinho, não usei o modo online porque na minha opinião estraga a experiência de jogos single player. No início do jogo eu tinha achado o jogo bem difícil, porém depois que eu entendi como o sistema do jogo funcionava e comecei a usar isso a meu favor, e eu parei de agarrar nas partes. Por exemplo, o único chefe que me matou foi o primeiro, morri pra ele 1 vez, mas todos os outros chefes eu matei na minha primeira tentativa, porque eu usei as partes anteriores do chefe para deixar o meu personagem o mais forte possível, e quando eu ia enfrentar o chefe eu estava muito bem preparado e conseguia matar de primeira. Sobre as questões técnicas, eu joguei em um PC com GPU: RTX 2080TI, CPU: i9-9900K, 32GB memória RAM, ssd de 5000 de leitura etc.. Joguei com resolução 4k com todas as configurações gráficas na melhor opção possível, com ray-tracing desligado, e desativei o borrão de movimento, a profundidade de campo e o bloom porque eu não gosto desses efeitos visuais. Usei V-Sync ligado a 60fps, e dessa forma no meu PC a performance foi boa, porém poderia ter sido melhor, em alguns momentos notei algumas quedas de fps, porém somente fora de combate, por isso não me prejudicou, e teve uns 3 bugs, 2 deles fez a tela ficar preta depois que eu caí em um buraco, aí eu tive que sair e entrar no jogo para voltar ao normal, porém não me atrapalhou porque o jogo voltou exatamente na mesma parte que eu estava. Vale a pena mencionar que depois que zera o jogo, o jogador pode continuar jogando para explorar e fazer o final secreto e verdadeiro do jogo, eu demorei 18h pra zerar + 24h pra fazer o final secreto, porém infelizmente depois que eu vi o final verdadeiro eu fiquei com mais dúvida do que eu tinha sobre a história. Única crítica negativa que eu tenho do Returnal além da performance que podia estar melhor, é o final do jogo que não esclarece nada direito, o jogo poderia ter tido um final bem melhor e mais interessante, mas mesmo assim o jogo não deixa de ser maravilhoso. Recomendo demais Returnal! Agora manda o Bloodborne pra gente Sony!

I really tried to like this game as a general fan of roguelikes, soulslikes and shooters. The atmosphere is great, controls are tight and the first couple of runs feel like you are really exploring some dangerous alien environment.

But the feeling of progression just isn't there. I am just running across the same rooms, while finding minor healing items.

I unlock something decent, get to a boss, die. Then I get stuck with a shitty pistol. I die again after a few rooms, rinse and repeat. Exploration is just too much of a risk. You get hammered for a minor upgrade you can't carry over, provided you even find an upgrade. You open a door and most of the time it means health -50% vs damage +5%. Explore the full map and you generally end up crippled with a RNG weapon. Rush the boss and you end up shooting it at lvl 1 with something crap.

I have mixed feeling about this game.

While a lot of point are mastered, the basics are lacking.

By that, I'm talking about the gameplay loop.
When you play something called roguelike or roguelite, you expect at least one of two things, upgrade during the game or between games.

Well, you have neither of them.
Between games you have nothing, you unlock items you almost never see in game at best else oudon't unlock anything but lore at most or just nothing.

During games, you can have better weapons but better because they have better stats not because they have a better gameplay or homing or anything, the same weapons but with better stats which only amount to moderate differences in the time you take to deal with ennemies.
Direct upgrades are so few I would never have dared to call this game roguelike or roguelite.

It just feels like a long straight line where one mistake = death.

While it's difficult, it's not impossible but the more you redo the more difficult it becomes and not in accordance with how good you are but just how many run you did so if you are bad, unlucky or just play game to enjoy them and not tryhard them, too bad you got scammed of 60 bucks or more depending of your country as I did.

I'll probably continu to play it for a while but that's for sure something I'll only abandon once and never comes back to it later which is a bit disappointing since the game has a lot more potential than just that.

Returnal is a rogue-like game in which each time you die the game gets significantly more difficult. Perfection must be maintained or your run is screwed, you cannot misstep or take the slightest damage or the run is broken due to losing your accumulated damage multiplier. Bullet hell combines with high platforms or nearby deadly environments such as lava or water, meaning it is easy to dodge into damage or death. Yes, water is as deadly as lava. Strafe off an edge or into damage and you lose. And the next run will be harder.
     In other words, this game sucks. On the very basic level of "Is it Fun", no. It is not fun. It's aggravating, frustrating, contrary, unfair, & a massive timesuck. Other than that, you might notice between 3-hour failed runs the gameplay is good, on par with Destiny 2. The art direction is consistent & very good. But since you are a very bad mom going mad for your sins, you deserve the horrible waste of lifespan that is Returnal. 
     Read the positive reviews with great skepticism. These are elitist jokers laughing up their sleeves because they are cooler than you. Unless you are an elitist joker, in which case this game is for you!

This is one of the most unique and underrated gems you'll ever play. It's a 3D inspired Metroidvania with roguelite and bullethell.  This means you will have different, alternating levels and permadeath each run. None of your progress is saved after death. The enemies will also shuffle and get randomized as well as the guns and perks. The game is more on the difficult side - Dark Souls style with only the default difficulty setting. Death can come from anywhere. Bosses are unforgiving but not outright impossible. Originally when I played the game, I rage-quit two or three times after each death and couldn't quite get it. But with each death came experience and perseverance. Eventually it started clicking and I fell in love with the game just as soon as I started getting good. 

The score and visuals are also phenomenal. This is where the bullethell comes into play or the amount of projectiles on screen (there's a lot, so much so that you could probably use it as a 3DMark benchmark). During combat you'll be forced to dodge and platform to stay alive while battling your enemies. Boss design is perfection as well. Gameplay is super quick, fast and precise. No hand holding. No timeouts. No long or tedious cutscenes either. It's got a sci-fi story about being stranded on a mysterious alien world with plenty of lore, secrets, and eeriness. Seriously the atmosphere is superb, filled with soul, depth, and plenty of feels. There's a twist at the end and though I didn't enjoy it as much as the rest of the game, it's all about the journey, not the destination. Also what's neat is that you can play with a friend from beginning to end (Co-Op). And if you are still having trouble beating the game just to experience it all, savescum your way to victory with cloud saves. 

Only downside is, optimization could be better. It's not Cyberpunk 2077 at launch bad but it's not Doom Eternal on a toaster optimized either. At any rate, I still HIGHLY recommend the game.  

Final Score: 9/10
Very fun, at times challenging, at times frustrating. Did have some optimization issues, running on 3060 12 gb, where stutters were frequent. Controls well with mouse and keyboard

This game was very fun. I had the settings maxed out and was able to stream gameplay with a 3080. Pretty much no issues except for the occasional frame stutter. I did have one issue with one boss where there were way too many particle effects and my game crashed. I had to lower the graphics for that one particular boss. Other than that, I didn't really have any issues with the game. It's gorgeous, it's frustrating, it's heart racing, it's trippy, and straight up fun. It's a hard game to recommend to everyone because it is pretty difficult and the runs can be quite long. The more you play and allow yourself to get absorbed into the game, the more fun you will have. My friend lent me his PS5 controller and it was pretty neat to feel the different haptic effects the game has built it. I wouldn't say it's a necessary part of the experience, but it definitely adds to the experience. You can tell that the developers put a lot of thought and care into every aspect of this game. I would give the game a solid 8/10.

My big problem is the plot.  It starts out looking like a interesting alien mystery, with alternate versions of yourself, finding your own body, etc.  Great start, but it's clear they didn't really know where to go from there.  We get some great and tense first person sections that have great sound design, but they don't lead to anything interesting.

Spoiler Warning:
[spoiler] It seems to lead to a "This is all just a dream" style ending, where it's not clear if any of what you experienced on the planet actually happened.  Some people have pulled off that ending, but it's not done well here, especially as we are left with so many questions.  

We're told that you are the one who shot down your ship causing it to crash.  We're told that you drove the car that crashed in the past and also the one dressed as an astronaut that you swerved to avoid.  Your mother also had an accident that worked in nearly the same way, which prevented her from being an Apollo astronaut, but you are exploring a planet that is explicitly outside the galaxy, which would be an impressive technological leap.

We never find out who sent the signal that lead you to the planet or why.  Was the strange creature you see at the end a real thing that drew you to a real planet, or is this all in your head?  If it's in your head, why the hell are you imagining weird tentacle beasts and strange biological weapons? [/spoiler]

At the end of the day, if you're looking for a good 3rd person shooter rogue-like, this fits the bill.  Just don't expect a satisfying ending.
