UPDATE: My point still stands for my original review, however I have found a work around that prevents textures turning to mush after extended play, and helps reduce (but not eliminated some stuttering). 
1. Update the Launch options in Steam (Right click > Properties > Launch Options) to use the argument -notexturestreaming. 
Be aware that this will load ALL the textures into VRAM so you'll need a card that has 8GB of VRAM or more. 
2. Disable VSync.
3. Set the max framerate to 60FPS. I've found the stuttering becomes much worse over this threshold. 
4. Under Screen Optimization enable DLSS and set it to either Balanced or Performance.

Unfortunately even with these changes in some of the later areas my framerate started to become really erratic and I had to restart which seemed to fix it. Not sure if its a biome issue or just the same issue as before with a different effect because it cant just throttle the texture stream pipeline.

Original Review Below:
Unfortunately (as mentioned by others here) this game suffers from a rather major graphical bug that seems to occur with extended playtime. Once I get about an hour or two in, the texture streaming just stops functioning. All the textures look like they came straight out of the N64, with a massive loss of fidelity. Around this time the game also starts to stutter with frame rate issues, which again is weird considering it looks like it should run much smoother with everything so flat and un-textured. 

The only way to solve the issue is to quit the game and relaunch it (sometimes a full PC reboot is required). I've tried playing with the graphics settings lowered which only seems to extend the time it takes before the issue occurs again, but it doesn't stop it happening. 

General consensus is this was introduced in a patch a few months back, and there is no real work around for it outside of restarting the game. Since then there hasn't been any further updates from the development team to resolve or even acknowledge this error, so buyer beware. 

Overall the game is a really good idea and solidly executed for the most part, but I cant give the game a positive rating in good conscience when such a glaring issue is present.

Returnal .. is Returnal. If you're looking for a comparison, there isn't a good one. 

Returnal has a great, dark atmosphere with a surprisingly interesting story that you pick bits up of as you play. For me, this separates it from other rogue-likes/rogue-lights. Many - if not all - contain similar story structures but this game's execution and the story itself is well beyond many others. For example, I'm playing Hades and a lot of people say it has a great story. I can tell you I keep trying to escape hell .. I think ... and I'm on run 50-something. Can't tell ya much else. It's boring. Returnal however, is pretty damn interesting.

Combat isn't bad. Like many of these it starts out harder than it'll be later. Once you unlock more guns and especially a specific upgrade that can aid in combat incredibly, you'll fly through the first biome like it's a joke.

The second biome is a bit trickier but after a few tries (or a few more) it comes down to one specific tricky enemy that again, that upgrade helps with (which you obtain in the first biome BTW).

At the end of the second biome you get something that really allows you to fully explore the biomes where you couldn't before and begin the third. 

The third biome is a bit tricker and where I currently am.

Enemies .. aren't bad. There's a weirdness. I swear with the same weapon some of the same enemies go down almost instantly where other times they'll take almost 10x the hits. Maybe I'm missing something, IDK. Maybe I'm literally missing and just not realizing it. I didn't start really getting good until a few days ago. This game takes some practice.

Stick with it. If the main game gets you down, there's the Tower of Sisyphus but you have to have beaten the second biome first. It's basically a gauntlet run but actually fun.

I'm tired... I probably could have left a better review. There's so much to say about this game. Like any Rogue, some runs are great. Some suck. Sometimes you're ecstatic. Sometimes you're pissed. Luck of the draw bud. I'll tell you though, this is my favorite when it comes to this type of game.

Just know one thing: Your runs are longer than average on here being what this is. If you play these games for short runs just be aware. You can suspend/exit and continue later however.

3. You aren't so dependent on RNG from builds so you never really feel under-powered.

Fantastic game. Reminded me strongly of Hades meeting Risk of Rain 2. 

First of all, to address some common things I saw in reviews: 
- Returnal advertises a strong recommendation to use a controller, specifically DS5. I didn't personally use a controller, and I think the game would be MUCH harder with a controller. Using a keyboard & mouse I still found it very difficult, but I'm pretty certain my enjoyment would be much less had I used a controller.
- I only had some issues with lag, mainly during particularly intense moments with a lot of moving particles and monsters. But otherwise it ran pretty well for me on max settings. 3440 x 1440 @ 120hz, 3080Ti.

When first playing through the game and exploring areas for the first few times, I was extremely immersed in the absolutely beautiful environment; you'd feel almost scared exploring new areas unsure of what's ahead, the variation of monsters/bosses, or unexpected environments since the map layout is randomised(not auto generated, just order differences). Even though you feel this way, you really want to explore every part of the map because at every stage of the game, exploration is rewarded and always feels good. Whether that's by getting stronger, finding secrets, or unlocking different parts of the story.

Returnal has a really cool take on Roguelike, whatever that means. In each half of the game, you restart from the respective half, and while you don't persist how strong you get, you have a permanent currency you can trade for an item that might give you a tiny edge at the start, and all other progressions are guns or items you can find in the game. It doesn't make you "stronger" between deaths, but does give you more options and playstyles. I found the story very engaging, fairly interesting and had that Hades style where each run unlocks new parts of the story, even past the credits. 

Overall for me, it's a high recommendation if you're into these types of games. At it's core price, it's a pretty steep investment and while for me it was worth it at full price, in this economy it's probably better to wishlist and wait for a sale. Also, the upgrade/roguelite items are pretty uninspired. They don't matter that much. The melee tree of items is also pointless since melee sucks and can't even be used on most bosses.

It was definitely fun to play as coop, but it's not a "hall of famer" if you are looking for coop roguelites.

Challenging in a good way, until it's not. 

Perfect port so it's a shame the game is so maliciously designed to just waste your time.

Even Lords of the Fallen, despite its high challenge.. you eventually punch through. That's not the feeling I get here. Here you're just struggling endlessly through the same section dozens of times.. with the same level zero pea-shooter weapons..each time a total do-over, and you never get anywhere.

Thinking about it more, they painted themselves into a corner with some of the key design decisions they made. 

Teams should always ask themselves: Is this mechanic really necessary, going to make the game more fun? 

Or is this mechanic just an attempt to compensate for bad assumptions and bad design decisions? 

By committing to a total stage do-over on every death, now you need to randomize the entire level so it isn't monotonous. A total do-over already diminishes your potential audience, and now you must commit to various compensations to make it work.

If your stages are randomised, they cannot have much depth. You're forced to template. So the rooms becomes relatively generic, with limited relationships or cohesion across rooms. The sense of permanence in the world is diminished - things the player already conquered are just back again and as we know almost no player prefers this. Acquiring items and progression requires little actual problem-solving, due to the template approach, so you add counter-mechanics like malignancy - again ask yourselves who actually finds that fun? Or is it there because you boxed yourselves in and had no choice. 

Now you need to worry about even the beautiful haunting first stage overstaying its welcome. The repetition of the combat music fading in every few seconds becoming grating on the player. Seeing the same basic enemies over and over again despite having mastered encounters with them hours ago. Picking up a health item knowing it made little to no difference. Picking up currency knowing it won't make any difference because the boss is going to require many more attempts. The list goes on. 

The argument could definitely be made that choosing randomisation and do-over instead of more depth is what polarised this game and caused it to reach only a fraction of the audience it could have.

Played though this on PlayStation a few years ago. Bought it again here on sale to play with a friend.
    I think this is the best PS5 game to date. Its not for everyone, but that does not diminish its quality. Anyway, enough about PlayStation. Now for the game.

        Its a 3rd person Sci-fi bullet-hell rouge-like. It has a creepy atmosphere, stunning visuals, great game-play, great voice acting, amazing sound design, and a surprisingly intriguing story.
      A while after it launched it received a free update. You can play Co-Op with a friend or matchmaking, which surprisingly doesn't seem effect the games balance much. And there is a new area with never ending floors to fight through with even more story added. Its great.
    The only con I can think of is maybe there is a little too many items and stats to deal with. The loot pool unlocks more items and weapons the more you play, and there is a LOT. I like it personally, but that's the only thing I can imagine might be a con.
      
    This game left me thinking about it to this day. The story beneath is simple and impactful, and masterfully woven into every aspect of the game and world. Very intriguing to uncover. The game can be very challenging, but very rewarding to make progress.
    You do unlock major shortcuts after each boss. You don't have to do everything again on each run. The runs can get long, so these permanent shortcuts are very welcome. You only have to defeat each boss and biome once to be able to run past most of it on future runs.

    I HIGHLY recommend this one. Its not usually my kind of game but this one just felt special.

[h2] Doom Returnal [/h2]


This is a great roguelike, a high-budget roguelike (?), the mother of all roguelikes. Definitely have played this roguelike more hours than any other.

Technically it's also a shooter, but I don't recommend it for that. More of a platformer, than anything else.

Too many reviews are talking just about the FPS, and not so much about the game itself. And because of that, it took me a while to give this game a chance. But I'm glad I did. The game runs more than fine, more on that later [ * ].

This is an absolute work of art, and a very unique game: a rather high-production roguelike shooter... a combination we don't see every day. I don't expect such a risky bet coming from Sony again in many years.

The game is trippy. The way the story is intertwined with the game is very interesting. In a way, it is impossible to make progress. In a way, it is inevitable to make progress. Like I said, very trippy.

The music and sound design are great. The boss fights are awesome. Jane Perry drives the whole thing with a "Sigourney-Weaver-in-Alien" kind of performance, for which she got a Bafta for leading actress... and then the game itself got Game of the Year, both deserved in my opinion.

The game is clearly made with PlayStation in mind, and that means a number of things:

- Makes good use of the DualSense features: adaptive triggers, haptic feedback. Some of which I didn't even know existed. You probably play shooters best with mouse and keyboard, but I recommend the pad for the experience.
- Not good for a small screen: 14-inch is as low as I have gone, and I think you lose the advantage of seeing far-away enemies.

[b]For the PC port[/b]: I have forced DX11 mode, and I haven't really had performance issues. My review would be very different if I had, this game is quite demanding in terms of reaction time and FPS. No frame drops worth noting.

[*] Holds over 90 FPS consistently for me on ultra (144Hz cap, vsync on, FSR off but DX11). Pretty much same performance as most modern shooters on this PC. However, I have observed that many people recommend enabling FSR or DLSS. In any case, you don't want to have FPS drops in this game, otherwise you are toast.
Pretty smooth performance on laptop too, which is less powerful but also smaller screen. I have played this game many hours on laptop, but I don't quite recommend this on a small screen.

I did't play much of this on locally on PC, because I constantly keep getting issues. From the 20 FPS framedrop (normally I am reaching > 90) to the game that was not able to open.

Besides, I am aware that game is not ready to play via remote play, but the fact is that most of the time out of 12 h played I was trying to make the game working via remote play and failed to do so. I wnated to play it on steam deck. 99% of times I had control issues, resolution issues, "audio only" issues, game not starting issues and others.

That said - the main problem is not really the remote play itself but the resoution change/minimizing the game. It causes problems locally on PC and make the game unplayable remotely.

Overall opinion for PC is negative. With RTX4060 and Ryzen 3600 i was not really able to enjoy playing it on PC + 4K TV setup. I was declined to refund because of having > 12h play. Its understandable. But on the other hand -> The PC port is not really there yet.

The ultimate failing of this game is that there is too little progress as a rogue-like and you will repeat rooms hundreds of times due to needing to replay parts either due to an unlucky run, a simple mistake spiraling out of control, or just because some of the plot REQUIRES revisiting certain plot rooms or beating end bosses multiple times to get the "true" ending (and then the "true, true" ending in the DLC). It's pretty unforgivable that you can beat the phase 3 DLC boss, then not have that "count" due to not watching some walking simulator scenes in another part of the game.

There is a huge hurdle in getting past the first boss, then things get easier and repetitive as you go through rooms you already know with no surprises, but you have to clear them anyways as you need all the pickups and need to destroy the destroyables for more pickups. Screw whatever designer/programmer put in needing to destroy hundreds of pots per run just to see if they have health/coins/etc. Double screw whatever designer/programmer put in all damage killing your adrenaline progress even fall damage or damage on pickups (with a parasite or malfunction). And triple screw whatever designer/programmer put in jumping puzzles in a FPS with fall damage from falling in infinite pits.

The story was OK. Mostly just layered symbolism with no explanation, not that I need a full explanation, but the plot seems to be <spoilers>you are the mother, daughter, granddaughter who is dead or dying and are also mentally disturbed by generational trauma, postpartum trauma, and cycles of abuse.</spoilers> I get it. But doesn't mean that the story is satisfactory when it just sort of spirals around mixing symbols with a blender. The DLC "true" ending is just a sputtering out, which it kind of would have to be for an infinite rogue-like. But they could have done something else. I agree with another commenter I saw who said the main game should have been metroidvania and the DLC the rogue-like. It's a kick in the teeth to have to play the horribly repetitive rogue-like to get the plot.

Returnal is undoubtedly a unique project and a fulfilling experience, unexpectedly incorporating both arthouse-esque driven storytelling and roguelike gameplay under the same roof. It’s a difficult game about choices and risks that you take, that determines your outcomes of success or failure of your mission. 
[h3]Base game[/h3]
While I understand that this game could be downright difficult, infuriating, and utterly beginner-unfriendly the first hours in, there is a steep learning curve that comes with it. Memorising mechanics could be rather tricky, which are ranging but not limited to: 
[list]
[*] memorising enemy attack patterns
[*] figuring out which weapons you like or hate
[*] effects of consumables, artifacts, parasites, and certain feature behaviors of active items. i.e: If effects could stack or completely cancel out effects of other consumables. 
[/list]
Once you have a rough idea of what’s going on few runs in, it gets much more fulfilling and engaging from there as you will commit less mistakes that drastically raise your chances in succeeding in your run.

Returnal’s story is heavy on metaphors, symbolism, greek mythology, and covers Carl Jung’s psychoanalytical concepts. The story boils down to exact same Jungian slogan of: 
[i]“There are three things in your mind: what you want, what you see, and what you’re supposed to be.”[/i] Represented in the matching characters as Helios, Selene, and the Astronaut. It’s also a game about loss, death, suffering, conflict in the perilous journey towards forgiveness, acceptance and finding peace and is very much open to a variety of personal interpretations.
[h3]Ascension DLC: The Tower of Sisyphus[/h3] 
Ascension introduces much more tense challenge mode, where arenas designed more compact with cranked up difficulty, but more firepower and consumables to balance the difficulty out. Despite having limited environmental progress (tower kinda remains the same after phase 3), I did enjoy this game mode much more than the base game, as the progression is much more fast-paced as well as it’s much more dangerous and rewarding.

An epic, cosmic horror Metroidvania + Rogue-like without peer. Returnal was amazing on the PS5, and absolutely stunning on the PC with all the settings maxed out. If you liked Soul Reaver or Control, consider giving Returnal a try.

It's difficult to overstate how this combination of eclectic ideas would amount to something authentically special within the medium of video games. 

Tight rouge-lite 3rd person shooting, nuanced cinematic performance capture, and a mysterious and astoundingly rendered science fiction world. It all amounts to an experience that's completely unbound by Playstation Studios' typical cinematic inspired experiences. 

Not dissimilar to the chemical make-up that made Baulder's Gate 3 a smash hit, there is no precedent for a title with AAA levels of production within the C-RPG or Rouge-Lite genres respectively. It's the signature Playstation production values in combination with Housmarque's mastery of game-feel and design that juxtapose Returnal from every other Rouge-Lite/ Like within the genre. 

If you have PS5 or an RTX 30/ 40 series graphics card, and are looking for something truly new and exciting, look no further than the modern classic that is Returnal.

Selene has a fever, and the only prescription is more cowbell.

Do you like pretentious? Seriously ask yourself this question. Sit on it for a minute or two & come back here... Okay, done? Regardless of your answer now, sit down & think on the next question. Who does pretentiousness serve? Is it you the observer or is it in fact the artist?

Welcome back. If you answer "yourself", then that begs the question of function as to how it does in your favor. You can sit on that one more & return (ha) back here if you have a satisfactory answer. I for one do not. You may skip the last question in that case.

If you answered "the artist", then what is the purpose of you even being here in the first place? Again, think about it, just don't think about it too hard. None of this is that big of a deal anyway... You return once more.

See, nothing makes a blood vessel pop in me quite like the pretentious self-serving avant garde nonsense. At this point & just a disclaimer all of this is debatable. I don't proclaim myself to be the ultimate authority on art. But at this point as an artist you've given up on a dialogue between yourself & me the observer completely. You made a piece of media for yourself & yourself alone. Kudos I suppose, but why am I expected to pay for it & more importantly invest my very limited time into? Time that could be better utilized far away from this incoherent mess. For all its pontifications on the tragedy of life, Returnal fails to realize that the real tragedy is to waste it. How very ironic.

Let's start off with the basics. The gameplay sucks. Selene's vast but very much underperforming arsenal hits with all the impact of a wet noodle (yes, singular). Also you don't even get to have the Halo cancer itself, the dual weapon system. No, a single gun is all you get. Considering how varied the guns are in utility, having at the very least two of them should be a no-brainer. But no, absolutely no brain power was spent to resolve this laughably easily resolvable game design conflict.

Then the game dares to throw bosses at you with not two, [b]BUT THREE[/b] health bars. In my opinion any developer who doesn't realize the impact the health bars have on the player experience has to stand before the Hague. Nioh hit the nail on the head with its singular health bar bosses & the seamless phase changes depending on the health percentage. As for myself I was done with triple health bar bosses all the way back when I first defeated Sister Friede for the first time. It is quite simply an insult to throw it around so frivolously as this game does.

This connects neatly to my final & perhaps the most important point against the gameplay of Returnal. It's a rogulelike & it should never have been one. This game tries to again marry the genre with a metroidvania & I can't help but feel that it would be better off just being the latter. Fighting normal enemies is ever really a problem (more on that later). The bosses however are just a wall you hit every single time you face them & unlike Dark Souls which allows the player to learn the boss before defeating it, Returnal just sends you back to Helios. Have fun redoing the same level a billion times before you finally luck out with the boss. It seems the best strategy here is to just watch a video of the boss fight & try to memorize patterns like that, which I hope I shouldn't tell you is anything but a good thing.

There's one positive in the game that is spoiled by an artificial restriction on movement & that's movement itself. Yes, I have one thing positive to say about Returnal. The movement is snappy & responsive. It just feels good to move in this game. Alas instead of implementing a stamina system we instead get a cooldown on dashes which breaks the flow of the game. I understand that having iframes necessitates a limit, but why not just use stamina? You lifted a lot from Dark Souls already, why not this?

Next to the aforementioned metroidvania & roguelike, Returnal is also a bullet hell game. If you played any bullet hell games in your life you know why they work & why this game doesn't. Making a 3D bullet hell is just a bad idea as most projectiles can easily be side stepped & since we have here somewhat intricately designed levels, most projectiles get stuck in terrain anyway. A good example is the minibosses that can be defeated by simply hiding behind a column, taking potshots at them from safety. The AI here does not help. It is really damn stupid. Your many foes can barely make a step without getting stuck in terrain themselves.

Now, for the bosses this dynamic shifts of course. The arenas are open, meaning there's nowhere to hide. Also the last phase tends to unleash the actual bullet hell on you. Being low on health already that almost guarantees demise. But again, they're not even hard bosses. They are however a drain on your resources & a roadblock that one [b]HAS TO BREAK THROUGH[/b] in order to progress. That takes a while due to the artificial lengthening of the whole process through the magic of the roguelike. Yes, it gets exteremely frustrating extremely fast.

I have one rule with roguelikes & that rule is: if the game dares to waste my time, then I'm not interested. This is why I to this day only ever recommend two roguelikes: Hades & Undermine. I even call the former "the roguelike for the people that hate roguelikes". I don't even hate roguelikes myself. I just don't tend to finish them, because the tediousness just gets to me after a while. To retain my interest you have to give me a reason to keep coming back, game.

Returnal just doesn't. Permanent upgrades are few & far between, mostly just dealing with traversal. Hardly exciting. Yet another reason why Returnal should just be a simple metroidvania instead. Also we have a clash between the two genres even here. You will just invariably get burned by something you're not supposed to interact with because you lack a certain upgrade. Losing half of your health or even dying because of it just feels cheap & undeserved. Especially when the stakes are this high,

Now. Does this game have anything at all to offer? Yes & no. The graphics is nice, but we have here the same issue the carcasses had in Lies of P. The enemies just blend with the background, especially in the lush ruins. Green blots everywhere all over again. I just tend to identify foes on the mini-map & reverse track them from their projectiles. Which is obviously very, very backwards. The atmosphere is alright, but the levels are very repetitive visually. The biomes hardly change in anything other than the color palette. As the result the game just looks the same from start to finish. It seems like every barrel of honey Returnal offers contains a fat spoon of tar. As a result the whole experience gets infected & poisoned the whole way through.

I already touched upon an aspect of the storytelling. At first it intrigues you. But alas it doesn't stick the landing (haha). The ending is just as unimpactful as the rest of the game. It clearly took inspiration from Stanislaw Lem's Solaris. Which would be a good thing, yours truly being a Lem fan. Alas the lack of anything to say in favor of pretentious meanderings just kills it. That's truly sad, because Lem has a lot to say in every novel of his that I read. This to me is the crucial distinction between his works & the pale imitations such as Returnal. Also becoming the ultimate piece of evidence to support my original thesis. Returnal just doesn't care about your time.

This is even more so reflected in the "true ending" that apparently adds nothing more to the game & is just teethgrindingly difficult to achieve being purely RNG based. The fact that the game invites me to waste even more of my precious time for no payoff what so ever is adding insult to injury. Of course I did not bother. Neither should you in general with Returnal.
Triple A roguelike finally. Too bad optimization isn't great though. I can usually run games at 120 no problem, but this one, not even close. 80-90 max.

I was looking for a good roguelike so I could stop playing Risk of Rain 2, but this game just wasn't it. It did capture my interest for the first couple of hours but then it turned utterly joyless. The game is clearly not optimized for PC -- just read all the other reviews about various bugs. For me textures would progressively stop loading the longer a run would go until I was shooting undifferentiated brown blocks.

The story has a few genuinely effective, engaging scenes early on that had me hooked to find out more. It turns out there's no real depth beyond those first scenes. Imagine a first year English major thinking themselves really profound for coming up with the idea that you can represent trauma and self-destruction as literal monsters, but not having the life experience to take that concept anywhere. I got to the main ending, was very disappointed, and just decided to read the secret ending online, and was really glad I didn't bother to try to play it.

As far as roguelikes go, I didn't think the game was actually that hard. At least, once you find a weapon you like and have leveled up your skills with it. The problem with that is that you can figure out the limited number of enemies and bosses much quicker than you can level up your weapons. This incentivizes you to not pick up and play with interesting new weapons, but just level up your one or two favorites for a few runs until you're ready to blow through the whole game.

Where the difficulty does come in this game is that the combination of bullet hell and 3rd person shooter really suffers for a lack of clear cuing. In 2D bullet hell games, you can clearly see every projectile, and it's up to you to figure out how to handle that. When you accidentally dodge into a fireball rather than past it, you want to smack yourself. Here when a wall of projectiles comes from some unseen angle, you want to smack the game. Compare to Risk of Rain 2, where I can be running like mad through a swarm of enemies, but the audio cues are all so distinct I can tell there's a wisp charging up behind me, a brass contraption loading over my left shoulder, and a malachite enemy spawning to my right. Maybe something with the audio mixing was as bugged as the textures were, but the sound design did not at all compensate for the limited perspective like it needs to in a frenetic 3D shooter.

Even outside of the texture issues, the game likes to start you in an aggressively ugly environment -- brown, gray, wet jumbled blocks. I think the starting environment actually works just fine as a contrast to the variety of other environments, but it's a real slog to start there every run (and in fact the ugliness gets worse halfway through the game). Some kind of randomizer on the starting scenery would have really freshened it up.

Returnal is something special.

So this game is a bullet-hell shooter, roguelike and metroidvania; in no specific order and it is deserving of all three. The story and setting is a dark horror.

Bullet-hell... Look at the screenshots! What I really like about this is the world's dark setting means the bright projectiles are really easy to see, so even when there's a lot going on you know exactly what's coming at you and from where. The same can be said about the enemies, they generally have bright colours so you know which way to point your gun. This game is built with heavy quality of life. You're very fast, have invincibility frames on dashes and the aiming auto-assist allows you to keep firing while using this high mobility.

Roguelike. You crash land on a planet, wake up, go kill stuff and then die. Upon dying you have a vision and are returned to life. Each time you go forth on your adventure the world rearranges itself. The main biomes and boss fights are sequential but the biomes themselves change their layouts. The developers did right by it and there's plenty of variety in the biomes. The game is more roguelike than most because there are no upgrades outside of each run. You can unlock new items to find on a run but you cannot upgrade your character, this is a plot based decision as you always return to the point in time when you crashed.

Metroidvania. Look... I don't think metroidvania games and roguelikes belong together... Then there's Returnal. To give an example I recently played Roboquest. You can get from start to finish without any of the extra abilities like a grappling hook. In Returnal, the game's Roguelike engine builds a randomised biome with the next essential ability along the way. When you die you ALWAYS start at the beginning with no checkpoints at each biome, so the game literally builds a new Metroidvania every time until you hit the end of the story.

As a horror it's creepy as hell! The world around you chitters, squirms and howls as you work your way through each biome. It's the story of a world of highly intelligent creatures in their post apocalyptic era. It's a harrowing and desolate place void of life and full of dangers. And to make matters worse, the first corpse you discover... Is your own, with an audio message in your voice. There's even a room with a depiction of your ship made from large stones and around it on pedestals like statues are more of your corpses.

Everything from the mechanics to the story are spectacularly integrated together. Well worth the purchase.
Playing this game in VR on Quest 3 with Praydogs VR mod + 3D Sound + Haptics = mind blown! What a world to be in.

Arguably, one of the best 3rd person shooters ever made. It sure is for me. Over 80 hours on PS5, 38 hours here (and going) and I can't stop playing it.
Incredibly responsive, fast, fluid and insanely fun combat, amazing graphics and especially sound and particle effects. 360 audio with perfect enemy tracking and spacial awareness. Mind blowing boss fights that will keep you coming back.

The game is pretty challenging, especially if you don't have enough experience with bullet hells. It has long runs that can be stopped by a single enemy very quickly sending you all the way back. You will probably die a lot, over and over again. But that doesn't matter, because the combat and gameplay are so fun, responsive and addicting, that you'll be starting another run right away. However, if you get discouraged easily or just don't enjoy challenging games that require skill and patience, you may not like this, since it needs you to be focused and on point with your movement, otherwise your run is over quick.

It has interesting and deep psychological story and great atmosphere, but make no mistake, you are playing it for the combat. The combat that made so many other games obsolete for me, unfortunately. No other 3rd person shooter feels as good as Returnal, no other movement feels as good.

The game has that "arcadey" feel to it and reminds me of the old games that you had to beat in one go and can come back to try and get the highest score. For this there's a Tower mode that is endless and lets you level very quickly, trying to go as far as you can and get as many points as you can. Both game modes are super fun and have great replayability (if you like the combat).

It may take you a stupid amount of deaths to beat this game, but you will probably play it again and beat it in one go without dying, cause you will get so good and so agile that no enemy will be a strong enough challenge (well, besides the higher levels of Tower where anything one-shots you). The better you get in this game, the more fun it is to play.
I am not even going to talk about boss fights in this game, cause you just have to experience this for yourself, just trust me that you will remember them for a while...

This is one of my favorite games of all time, and I very strongly recommend it to anyone, who likes action games, and especially, challenging action games and "roguelikes" (although one could argue about "roguelikeness" of this game). This is one of the tightest, most responsive, dynamic and fun games out there, and it will make you sweat.

[b]tl;dr:[/b] Play "Dead cells" or "Hades" if you want a good action roguelite, if you are playing this for the story there are a million visual novels that have a better story than this.

This is the first time I'd like to have a "neutral" rating for reviews, but if I have to decide between positive or negative this game is on the negative side.

Positive sides:
- [b]Tight gameplay:[/b] The controls are very satisfying, the aim assist helps while not getting in the way. It's one of the best third person shooters I've played in this sense
- [b]Deconstruction of the genre:[/b] I won't get in the details, but I have been very positively surprised about some of the plot twists in the game. Makes me wish more games would try to analyze what it means to be stuck in a roguelite

Negatives:
- [b][i]Very[/i] poor scriptwriting:[/b] I am not sure what happened here, but the main character is one of the main reasons I am giving a negative rating. She keeps on talking, most of the time to add nothing of value neither for the player nor for the story. She's also one of the character I've felt less emphatic about. I don't care about her struggles, nor her background, nor her issues. How they managed to write such a bad character is a mystery to me. All of the non-action parts of this game feel like obstacles to the real game that exist only to gratify the scriptwriters instead of giving the players something more. 
- [b]Roguelite?[/b] It feels like the designers of the roguelite part of the game did not really understand what it meant to play a roguelite and just took the "random rooms + persistent unlocks" part and called it a day. There is no way to build a character during a run. When you play other roguelite games you have multiple opportunities to decide whether to pick up something or not based on the synergies of your run in order to get to the final boss with a "build". In this game this is not possible. The things you pick up are so few and in-between that a "build" does not exist, it's just a set of random pickups, no matter how many optional rooms or mid-boss fight you choose to take.
- [b]Useless choices:[/b] It's an extension to the previous point, but slight different. The game has some choices regarding some items you pick up, but they make no sense in most cases. There are some pickups that give you both a bonus and a malus, but in most cases the malus overwhelms the bonus, so you leave it there. There are some pickups that are literally "This item either heals you or damages you", which make no sense as why would you risk to damage yourself if you need heals? I would understand if it was "This item either gives you a damage boost or damages you", because then it would be a decision of whether you want to risk your safety for more damage, but in the case of health you want it when you need it.
- [b]3D bullet hell:[/b] Make no mistake. I love bullet hells. Hell, I love "Nier" and "Bayonetta" to a fault. But there is a reason why this sort of "Bullet hell / TPS" games are such a rarity: [b]it's hard as hell to make them fair[/b], and this game is not fair. The amount of time I have been hit by random shots coming or, worse yet, by enemies charging in melee (because they are not even notified, contrary to bullets) from outside the camera view is too large for comfort. That's why games that do this in a proper way avoid some types of attacks if outside of the player view or change the camera type if they intend to go all out. Also it feels like sometimes bullets of specific colors hit you regardless of whether you dodge or not.

Housemarque's traditionally super tight gameplay translated to a 3rd person perspective. I'm not always into rogue-lites, but I keep coming back for more because it's simply so much fun to play. Co op works pretty well except the remote player doesn't unlocked any permanent upgrades, so that's a bit of a downer. Still, one of the best games I've played in a while.

[i]Returnal[/i] is a good game, but a bad roguelike. After beating it a bunch of times and achieving the "true" ending to the point it all feels rather pointless and esoteric, there are some major flaws pulling down what could otherwise be a great game. 

For starters, much like how the term souls-like has become ubiquitous, [i]Returnal[/i] suffers the same flaw as many of its fellows: map variety. Don't get me wrong, in terms of the visuals, the game is second-to-none. Running this with raytracing and DLSS is a real treat and Housemarque have pulled off something that's deserving of the generational leap. (And there goes my only reason to ever get a PS5.)

The problem is that these sections are very, very limited and you'll quickly memorise everything, thus hampering replayability. The only thing that really changes is where (and which) enemies will be placed between runs, which doesn't exactly help the roguelike nature of a roguelike game.

Speaking of replayability, beating the game and progressing to the next set of biomes is made all the worse because in a game that should be rewarding skill and progress... decides to reset it. [i]Returnal[/i] has the baffling habit of telling its story through making you play through the game again from square one, ironically feeling like a Sisyphean task of its own.

And by far the biggest flaw is that very story. The time loop trope has become almost as tiresome as multiverses in recent years and Housemarque decided to use cosmic horror to explore Selene's past and her connection to Atropos. You'd think that would be right up my alley, but the problem is that when I don't know what's happening or, worse, don't care, there's really no drive to learn more or engage with the worldbuilding.

Reaching the credits the first time took about 12 hours, at which point the game just ends and then has the audacity to say keep playing to unlock its true secrets. If that annoyed the hell out of me when [i]Nier[/i] did it, you better believe it does here too.

I ended up beating [i]Returnal[/i] another few times, which might sound like a contradiction given that I criticised the replay value earlier, but as you get better at the game, runs can take an hour or two at most. At that point, I threw some podcasts on to see whether this true ending was worth it.

Spoilers: it's not.

To even claim this is a full "third act" is extremely charitable at best, as all it involves is going through the same six biomes again to collect parts of a key item. There are no changes in bosses, no secret areas, nothing. On doing that, you get another short cutscene that doesn't really answer anything and... that's it. Seriously?

Sure, someone's going to argue this was a stylistic choice, that the game wants to leave everything open to interpretation through trippy imagery and metaphor, but again... I don't care. And it all feels like a waste of time... because there basically is no story.

That's not to say it's all bad, however. Movement might sound like a weird thing to praise, but damn, does it feel good... especially when you unlock all the upgrades like the grappling hook. 3D audio is always a neat addition and the game as a whole absolutely nails feedback. [i]Returnal[/i] lives up to the bullet hell name with some great music to boot.

Bosses themselves are... fine. Strangely, I found them to get easier as the game went on with the final one being the easiest of them all. This sucks given that combat otherwise feels amazing with a decent range of guns and unlocks to each, but it's not a huge deal.

Performance overall was pretty good, although I loaded in falling under the map on too many occasions for my liking. The first time I tried a daily challenge, the map didn't even load at all and I was left falling through empty space. 

The amount of particles and stuff happening onscreen generally isn't a problem and there was only the occasional drop in performance. Given that it's the middle of summer here in Australia and I was playing in a hot house, that's more likely to be on my end than an otherwise solid PC port.

[i]Returnal[/i] is probably the most neutral game I've played in a long time, but given how solid the foundations are beyond that, I'm willing to give it a recommendation, albeit with some caveats. I'm glad I got it on sale, but even then, it felt like it was pushing it.

If you're looking for a roguelike to sink a tonne of hours into, there are better choices out there, but for a visual feast with rock solid gameplay, it's worth a look. Just don't bother engaging with its story.

Game is unbelievably good, especially if you never heard much about it while it was PS exclusive. Reviews mention the PC port issues, not sure if that was fixed at some point because aside from a couple crashes my friend experienced while hosting co-op, there's been no issues.

(on top of my 20 hours here, i have about 60+ hours on the PS5 version, and achieved all 4 endings on that playthrough.)

at the risk of sounding hyperbolic, Returnal went from something that wasn't even on my radar to becoming one of my favorite games of all time. i'm talking RDR2-tier, one of the greatest experiences i've ever had playing a video game. at the risk of sounding like a total dilettante, it's one of the only games i would even consider putting the term "masterpiece" near.

why wasn't it on my radar? well, i was initially put off by the progression/style of the game. i've never personally been one for the roguelike genre, as banging my head against a wall unrelentingly when i'm supposed to be having fun playing a video game didn't quite sound like... well, fun. i've never really been one for Dark Souls (tho, like everyone else, Elden Ring eventually won me over) and i'm just not a fan of this whole "get gud" style of game. i have limited time, i don't want to waste it on failing to do the same thing over and over. so, despite having a PS5 and everyone claiming to high heaven that Returnal was *the* game to play on it, some even calling it the game of the generation while the generation had barely started, i just shrugged and was satisfied putting 100+ hours into Gran Turismo 7 (which is far better than online discourse would have you believe, but that's for another review.)

but once i had worn out a bit on GT7, hit a wall in OlliOlli World, tried and failed numerous times in the Demon Souls remake (this was before i was won over by ER), etc etc, i was itching for a new game to try, and Returnal was sitting right there in my Playstation Plus library, waiting for me to give into the so-called game of the generation.

immediately, i was struck by the art direction of the game. the mixture of sci-fi and natural environments, the insane particle effects, the enemy design... it all felt fresh, unique, and intriguing. it made you want to push on to see what else you could find. that is, if you could.

secondly, i was struck by how goddamn hard this game is. it is unrelenting at first, punishing you for every single mistake without hesitance. any act of hubris will be rewarded with an act of swallowing your pride. but, unlike a lot of other games with this vicious gameplay cycle, there was something about it that somehow felt like galvanizing instead of demoralizing. when a mistake was made, when a death had to be taken, i always found myself going "i know what i did wrong", never "what the fuck, that's total bullshit, i couldn't have done anything to prevent that!" it's difficult, and brutally so, but it never loses a sense of being fair.

and the more you try, the more you're rewarded. you permanently unlock new attributes for your weapons that help you push a room or two further. you learn enemy patterns and how to avoid them. you learn that there are i-frames you can exploit, all Dark Souls like. through an inability to say die and to constantly try again, the game slowly starts to reveal itself to you. persistence is rewarded, and feels rewarding, never begrudging.

then you eventually make it past the first boss, entering the second biome. and the world is just as gorgeous, but in a totally different way. you slowly unlock more movement techniques, and those ledges and ponds that were inaccessible before suddenly become havens for items that ensure further progression. it all builds at a slow, methodical pace that cues you into the main gameplay idea: the only way to fail is to give up.

the game truly clicked for me on a gameplay level when i realized this wasn't a game about accuracy, but about movement and defense. it has the pace and push forward nature of the modern DOOM games on higher difficulties, forcing you to always be on the move, always be aware of your surroundings, and never stop fighting. when i had this lightbulb moment, all of a sudden, i was able to progress at a far faster pace. and when you start to get that speed, when you start to get that confidence, the controls of this game shine bright. it feels responsive beyond belief, leaving you never feeling like you intended to do something that wasn't carried out. it feels smoother and more satisfying than almost any other game i have ever played, and is one of the only times i found that a game has stood out to me for its controls in a *good* way.

after fighting and pushing and displaying a persistence unlike anything i've been able to conjure before, i made my way to the end of the third biome, and all of a sudden, the story that has only been given to you in bits and pieces slowly starts to fall into place. first, the design lures you in. then, the progression keeps you fighting after dying a million times. the gameplay/controls keeps you pushing forward. but then the story starts to reveal itself, after you've already been won over by the minute to minute of the game itself, and it started to dawn on me that everything that has happened so far, every moment of struggle and triumph, has all been in service to the story of the game.

this beautiful wave of realization occurred that every single element and system in this game is interconnected in an unbelievably holistic way. every single piece of the game is intentional in a way i have never experienced in a game before, from the way things look to the way the game plays to the way you progress to the way the fucking game sounds... it all is in service to immersing you into a story and a person without you even realizing it. and as the narrative finally starts to blossom and you start connecting everything together in your mind like a crazed detective, the game deepens in a way i had never expected. all of a sudden, the game has a weight to every element that you feel deeply. the intentional nature of the design influences you to become just as intentional, and follow along a harrowing, heart-wrenching, truly masterful style of narrative that i truly believe could only be possible in the medium of video games. it shocked me, stirred me, made me emotional, and even called me out in a way that few games ever do. despite the brutality, the coldness of the world, the sheer difficulty of the moment-to-moment gameplay, this game is ultimately and deeply human and emotional in an utterly unique way.

i won't say too much more about the story to keep this spoiler free, but by the time i hit the fourth ending, 60+ hours into a game i previously wouldn't even consider playing, i understood where people were coming from when they said it was the game of the generation. i still think it's too early too call something like that, but i simply cannot think of another game that balances enjoyable gameplay, satisfying progression, immaculate sound & art design, and a masterful narrative in a way that doesn't alienate but engages, deeper than almost any game i've ever played. it's a true masterwork that lacks compromise, but doesn't prove impenetrable. it's a fucking masterpiece.

long story short, Returnal is worth the hype. if you open yourself up to it, you will find yourself changed by the time it is done. and for a piece of interactive entertainment in an age where endless debates about the value of the medium being considered "art" or not rage on, i think one simply has to point to Returnal as an example of how a video game can be both: an entertaining video game and an undeniable work of art. simply, Returnal is one of the greatest games i've ever played, and probably ever will play, and i implore you to simply give it a chance.

If you like Hades for its gameplay and difficulty in the beginning I think you'd enjoy this kinda game. It plays very similar to Hades IMO except in a 3D way and it's much less forgiving than Hades because of the fact that you can fall off the world on top of all the ways the game tries to punish you. 

Almost everything in this game is against you, weapons are RNG drops that can screw you, so are health drops, or money or what shows up in the shops or rewards etc. This game plays so fucking fast that it's a test of your skill even without any enemies on the screen lol, just moving around the rooms there can be traps all over them which will test your movement. So overall it's what many would consider a difficult game, many won't be able to finish this game's first boss even.  The game isn't like Hades in the sense that msot of what you get from dying doesn't truly make you that much stronger you can unlock gun perks and you won't have to fight bosses again, you can also unlock the ability to get new upgrades and then a few tools to help with the game. It does add up but isn't as impactful as in a game like Hades. 

I think if you come from Roguelikes though it should be fine for most of these people. There are aspects of jagged terrains which nullify running and some weird environment choices I don't agree with, but the game itself plays very well and I found it very fun ultimately. The graphics are great on PC, however I found a crazy amount of issues with things like shadow pop ins and other weird texture issues on this game even on a 4080. The shadow and lighting pop in was horrible and it gets noticeably worse in the later levels of the game. 

I don't want to spoil too much about the game but the bosses are all good and very cinematic yet challenging when you first approach them, I recommend not using a guide to fully enjoy the game tbh and learning what the bosses will do, haha jk you're not gonna wanna die after spending 3 fucking hrs on one run. But honestly I didn't except for the final boss and it was honestly kinda awesome just seeing these bosses first time without any idea what they did or how they would look. The game has a visual presentation about it that's really unique similar to how Control's environments are except in this case with enemy designs and the bullet hell you're in. 

The worst part  about this game? This fucking story is a mess, I won't spoil this either but this has one of those "we gave you the information now you figure it out" stories, no motherfuckers YOU figure it out. You wrote this bizarre story you could've went with a straightforward approach like Hades but you decided you wanted to do a deeper type of thing, at least give a good conclusive ending to this story or explanation, NOPE open to interpretation! I didn't find myself liking the main character or any of the characters in the game I know it's 2020 so forgive me for not liking the butch scientist female astronaut, yea I'd rather play a hot girl. But if you're gonna do the 2020 thing at least make a good story  for me to enjoy. 

Overall 7/10 there's flaws to it in gameplay, graphics, story, and design but overall it's very fun and challenging.

I'd give it a 9.8/10 (for some slight technical issues).

I was waiting to play it on the PS5, but by the time I started playing it, it was already out (and patched) on PC  as a superior version with full Dual Sense support (absolute must for the full experience).

I know Housemarque studios quite well, loved all their games so far. This title, however, marks their first attempt at a "triple A" production. And what a "triple A" debut it is! 

Let's be honest, the game was a pain in the ass on launch (no ability to save the game, PC performance issues). As it is, the game is now (after the patch) fantastic. An absolute masterpiece for anyone who gives it a chance.

Stand out features:
- The usual Housemarque gameplay - pure arcade level perfection.
- Incredible worlds brought to life in an astonishing way. The art direction is absolutely outstanding. Words and videos simply cannot sufficiently describe the awe you experience on each level of this game. Mind blowing!
- Very cool and original storytelling used to convey a very unusual history.
- Replayability after finishing the game.

Not so great aspects:
- Some stutter (mostly first level aka BIOME). A non issue after a while, unwelcome nonetheless.
- Four great weapons, but the rest is pretty useless.

Other things to keep in mind:
- The game is quite unusual for console gamers. For PC audience it might seem even more unapproachable at first.
- Ray-tracing reflections transform the way the game looks (LOW setting is amazing, and the difference between LOW and EPIC is negligible). It's visual impact doesn't quite show early on, but from 3rd BIOME on, it's undeniable. RTX shadows are the opposite, little impact overall.
- Stunning in 1440p.
- After you finish the game, go to the mods website. Amazing mods and make replaying the game so much fun!

Me and rogue-lights do not get along, but so many of these darn games are so well received, and when they look as cool as Returnal – it may be worth the shoot.

I can say that Returnal is a game that I do recommend. I haven’t finished it, and I have no intention to. I beat the first half of the world and when they ended my run there for story reasons; I just had no desire to push through. I just play these games wrong. I got all the way to world three on my third attempt. All bosses I attempted, I beat them first try.
Not because I’m ”pro-gamer #TTV”, but because if I don’t I won’t have the drive to play my way there again xD

I don’t might griding a tough boss or section or such, but I just feel like this genre is a waste of time.

My whining aside… Returnal is pretty darn competent. The story is a bit too serious for what the game actually is. However, there is interesting stuff there, and there are threads tugging at a bigger theme. There is a clear existential focus: who are we, where are we going and why are we going there? It’s portrayed nicely against the sci-fi backdrop of space – since space seems to so easily beacon these types of questions.

As for the gameplay, it’s intense and the shooting slaps. It has a rapidness to it that seems heavily inspired by “shmup-games” (bullet hell games). The frantic nature makes you feel pressured while being forced to make critical decisions or your run ends. Good ingredients for a rogue-light. While further enchanting the experience are a set of amazing guns. The shooting feels very unique to the game with each gun shooting what feels like a firework’s worth of crud out of each round xD

Combat plays well, the one thing that pissed me off was that sometimes bullets are hard to decern in all the chaos. I’d like for all enemy projectiles to be ONE color and not a slew of colors. It loses some stile, but it would serve gameplay better.

Overall, this game is good, but if you don’t care for the genre; it might not be worth it.
The random frame drops that I couldn't fix definitely made it hard to play at times but it was a very fun game.  My only issue is the performance. No matter what i set it to.

Even after over 75 hours and countless rounds that happens to me - I still can't get enough of this game.
Concerning the technical issues that some players are experiencing: I have a mid pc, play in full hd and it runs smooth (some very minor stutters here and there). Give it a try, its absolutely worth it.

I really liked this game; although I do think it is technically better solo. Co-op was added as a post-launch update and feels a bit afterthought, the majority of loot is not instanced to individual players so you are basically cannibalizing each other by playing together. This game is basically a third-person bullet hell shooter roguelike (similar to Risk of Rain) and you travel through a series of biomes, clearing procedurally-generated rooms and fighting Eldritch horror-like xenomorphs, collecting upgrades and weapons along the way. 

Health is _not_ dropped by enemies, only currency, so the game is pretty unforgiving, and there is very little in the way of permanent progress with the exception of certain upgrades that are more metroidvanian in nature in how they expand what areas are available to you (for example, clearing Biome 2 earns you a grappling hook which will open up certain optional paths in Biome 1 and subsequent biomes rather than actually bolstering your combat prowess. Most games in this genre released today (which would technically be considered 'roguelite') allow you to do things like permanently expand your HP pool (e.g. Hades) so subsequent runs are a bit easier and you don't feel like you're completely starting from scratch on each run, and/or they spoon feed you guaranteed upgrades at the end of clearing a room (e.g. Gunfire Reborn, Roboquest); Returnal does NOT do that. As much as I enjoy this game I frequently play it in short bursts because I don't really like doing more than one or two runs in one sitting for this reason. 

The cosmic horror feel combined with the brutal difficulty really do a good job of instilling a genuine sense of uneasiness and fear in the player. 

Although this game has keyboard and mouse support as you would expect and as a shooter feels pretty good on it, I personally opt to play this game on the DualSense as was intended by the developers when they conceived for this title on the PS5. After some controller adjustments (rebinding jumping and dashing to the shoulder buttons, and melee attack to the thumbstick) I find this to be my preferred way to play, the haptics just feel too good with this game. 

The game also looks amazing although sometime the bloom effects can be a bit overwhelming (although I feel that it is necessary in this game because of its emphasis on bright light effects). It is well optimized for PC and has support for the likes of FSR/DLSS among other upscaling algorithms. Sadly it does suffer from some glitches especially when playing in co-op, like not being able to interact with an item for example. These happen almost never in single-player. 

All in all it is a definite recommend but it is not for the faint of heart for sure. .

I absolutely love this game. The gameplay is fast, smooth and feels so good. When not fighting, exploring the creepy alien landscapes was a ton of fun. It feels fun and rewarding when you have a good run with powerful items and you find neat synergies between your artifacts, weapons and consumables.

My only negative, is the occasion slow-down during hectic boss fights and even some game crashes. The game feels poorly optimized for PC. To be fair, the game DOES give you a warning at the start if your hardware isn't up to the task. However, I am able to reduce the number of crashes by setting the graphics to low and clearing the shader cache before each play session.

If you have a decent rig, I really think you will enjoy this game if you like Sci-fi, rogue-lites and bullet-hell shooters.

I love this game. It’s beautifully atmospheric and balletically fluid—once you get the feel of it and get into the flow of the combat, you can sort of zone out and dance with an endless parade of vicious glowing tentacle monsters. It’s hard: if you’re not careful or even if you’re just unlucky you can die incredibly quickly and have to start over again. But it’s (usually) fair, too—once you learn the attack patterns and your own movement well enough, you can get through an entire area completely untouched, which is extremely satisfying after the many, many times you died there before. The story is sparse and mysterious, but piecing it together over the course of the game to try figure out what’s going on and how you got here helps motivate you to keep trying.
I’ve spent a bunch of time writing this which I would rather have spent playing this game. Which I’ve beaten more times than I can remember. Make of that what you will.

This is not a bad game. It has a lot of good things going for it: cool art (very much inspired by Prometheus), smooth controls, intriguing story, good level design, shooting can be very satisfying. But ultimately the game is more frustrating than fun.

I am not opposed to challenging games. I love Dark Souls, Sekiro, and Elden Ring. This game requires a lot of the player and is quite random. The last part comes with the territory of rogue-likes. However, I think there are a few design elements that make it frustrating to keep playing through it:

1. Each play through can be quite long. So if you die you end up loosing a lot of time
2. There is not much meta-progress. You add new items and weapons to the pool of things you can find. There are a few traversal mechanics that you unlock. But you start each run fresh. I guess this can be a plus or a minus depending on your preference.
3. The game is randomly super hard. Eg some rooms spawn mini bosses which have extra abilities and if the room is small you can get wiped out  very quickly. Also some items have "malfunctions" which range from minor inconvenience (scrambled map) to incredibly dangerous (max health reduced by half, ie you die in like 2 hits) or just nothing happens at all.
4. After you clear the room of enemies, you need to collect all the loot. This can be quite tedious. The rooms often have fairly large and complex 3d design which is awesome during combat. But afterwards you need to spend like 5 mins running and grappling around collecting everything. Also breakable "containers" often have valuable stuff so I feel obliged to try to get most of them just in case. This wouldn't be an issue if you didn't have to repeat the same levels so many times.
5. I think the items you find don't alter the gameplay enough. They give you buffs/debuffs but ultimately you play the game the same way.
6. Some of the later levels have a lot of platforming. Like you have to dodge moving lasers and jump on small platforms. And I think the controls are not quite precise enough for that. 

I think non of those elements are uncommon in rogue-likes but taken all together can be frustrating.

I dont recommend it for a few reasons:

1. This game has some serious readability issues. The UI is way way too stylized to be helpful at all. Clean icons are ok, but theyre so simple its almost impossible to understand what your consumables are or do. The blueish enemies are shooting blueish orbs against a blueish background while your crosshair and other vital UI information are the same blueish color. The game has a difficulty that demands quick reflexes and spacial awareness, i love it; the UI has NO place adding to the difficulty. Risk of Rain 2 has 1000x more happening on screen and its still more readable than the simple few things happening on screen in this game.

2. The story is very conducive to a rogue like game, Its proabably the only one to do so and I praise it for that, BUT the upgrades and progression in a run dont feel all that great, which is kind of the opposite of every other roguelike. Most of the artifacts and parasites that you collect dont FEEL like they are doing much of anything. You have to jump into the menu and read the description to even remember that you have collected much of anything.  It puts the game in a pretty unique for the genre position, skill seems to matter much more than luck of the draw, which kinda begs the question of if this game should have random elements at all. The story begs that it should be, but the lack of dopamine i get from the rest of the roguelike elements isnt much of a carrot.

3. Just put a fucking reload binding in the game. Theres an active reload like Gears of War, but uses the same button as shoot to activate it. This combined with the crosshair ui blending in with literally everything else in the game that makes it almost impossible to tell when you are running low on ammunition or even starting a reload, a causes the player to miss the active reload almost immediately when shooting a semi-automatic weapon, say the starting pistol. This is the most braindead, easily solvable problem ive ever seen in a game. Its indefensible. At best someone could say they dont mind it

Ok so, this game is incredible. I already play more of it in other platform and I recommended it back then, so here the only thing I can add is that the game runs well on my system (Ryzen 3700X + RTX 3060 Ti). No technical problems so far, unlike many other reviews claim.

I really enjoyed Returnal. 
The gamplay is snappy and you can feel yourself getting better on future attempts. Really punishing early on, but the trickle of upgrades and new weapons was enough to keep me interested.
The story is woven into the game in a mostly unobtrusive way. It can be a bit confusing at first, but makes much more sense near the end. The final cinematic of act 1 gave me chills. It's definitely not the main draw of the game, but it's there if you're into it.

I didn't experience any of the major issues some other users reported. I did see some slowdown in act 2 during later chapters, but it was mostly limited to opening and closing the map screen. 

I bought it on sale and it was definitely worth the price. I've finished the main game, but still have to complete the tower of Sisyphus. 8/10

Cons: The optimization~ 8700k 2080ti gets at best 60fps and in the other biomes it's 30-35 at 1080p all low settings and everything off.

The lack of information~ What does Killsight do? What does Enlarged Chamber do? I enjoy figuring things out but only to an extent.

The Co-op~ Why is there a twenty foot tether system? If I use a "Proximity Translocator" as a non-host it just tethers me right back to the host because it took me twenty five feet away AND only one person can use it at a time so as non-host you just stand there for fifteen seconds waiting, so much fun. We installed a mod that removes tether after ten plus hours and the game worked fine, I was 900m away from the host, no issues. Some items and things are host only, so again, as non host just stand there. The currency that monsters and things drops disappears in about 4 seconds so playing co-op means you get even less because spreading out is better for survival, so a mod was installed to fix that and game was vastly more enjoyable. Again, as a non-host, you get shafted with no achievements for milestones like boss kills and you get kicked from the game during cut scenes. Who ever made the decision that the tower mode is single player only needs to get fired, let's lock hours of content behind a no friends allowed wall. 

Game doesn't get harder/progress/lacks content~ All the bosses (ONLY 5) use the same attacks and mechanics and only one boss doesn't use a circle to fight in. The end game final boss was such a disappointment, meanwhile the act 1 final boss was super good and the best boss in the game hands down as the other bosses are just you running and jumping in a circle for three minutes. Each act has 3 biomes and each biome only takes about one hour to beat assuming you clear every single room, which you don't have to do, meaning the game is less than ten hours long including the cut scenes. The counter to this is difficulty and mystery. If you or both of you die, you start over from the begging of that act. So if you've spent 3 hours on act 1 and lose to the final boss back to square one, unless you know how to do the revive mechanic and if you find it before death. The 10 weapons (four are grenade launchers) are very hit or miss, either love em or hate em. Why devs think locking fun behind a time gate is a good idea is baffling because the grappling hook just completely changes the game and opens many doors. Weapons are suppose to progress and get better the more you use them but I never felt that.

Pros: Visuals, environment and atmosphere are top notch but, in 2023 you have so many games that have done this it's not ground breaking. Elden Ring, Dark Souls, Bloodbourne, Remnant, ect.

Combat/Gameplay are very good and mostly smooth, dash locks you out of shooting and other actions and breaks the flow, grapple does too but that's fine. Melee can be hit or miss as sometimes the auto lunge misses. 

Full price is not worth it imo but go watch a little gameplay and if you like it and games like Remnant and Dark Souls you'll have fun, just know it's only for a few hours.
Really good, a little on the short side though.

Top 3 Roguelikes of all time, not kidding. So glad to revisit this game on PC as I played the hell out of it on my PS5.

If you can run the game at its "recommended" settings, I can't stress enough how important this game is in your library, especially if you're into Roguelikes.

- Visually stunning
- Easy to follow, yet surprising and captivating story
- Engaging and intense combat (If you have a PS5 controller, I highly recommend using it as it's much more immersive and has special interactions with the haptics of the triggers)
- Enemy variety is plenty and keeps you on your toes (or off them depending on their attack)
- Bosses are CRAZY. They will genuinely make your jaw drop, whether its from an attack, their arena, or design. They are FUN.
- Online can be a real treat, but it's a bit harder to find people at times since it doesn't cross-play with PS5, it just crossplays with EGS players which I imagine are non-existent since the game is on Steam.
- Optimization seems great. I've heard it wasn't so good at launch, but I've had 0 stutters and overall the game runs and plays excellently. Some frame drops due to more intense situations with bullets flying everywhere obviously, but that's not the game's fault at all.

Buy this game. Now. I'm not asking.

An extremely strong rogue-like third-person shooter, I had a great deal of fun with this title and will continue to revisit it. I do not think Returnal has quite the replay-ability commonly associated with the rogue-like genre, Risk of Rain 2 for example, but I personally prefer Returnal over most it's contemporaries.

It is a bit buggy though, I did not experience any along the lines of a memory leak, but the audio can cut out for a second here or there regularly. Once I needed to restart my computer in order to fix an issue where the audio for the game broke entirely; I didn't have any audio issues with any other games and restarting Returnal wasn't enough on it's own.

I can strongly recommend this title despite any issues, but that's only if the game actually wants to work for your PC; considering how other people have experienced more serious issues, I really hope we see another patch at some point to polish this out.

Simply put . .  This game is visually stunning! I love the environment and feel however. . . This game is not very enjoyable outside of looking at it. I understand the need for a challenge as far as gaming goes but this game does not deliver a challenge  with the opportunity to adapt or learn from mistakes. The changing of the environment every time you die, plus adding mini bosses to the same environment you have visited before that were not present previously, plus changing the mini bosses abilities and powers, from previously, plus adding two mini bosses to the environment instead of one, plus not keeping all power-ups permanently, plus losing weapons after you die, plus choosing good power-ups with a known or unknown defect, is not a very enjoyable game.

There is defiantly a niche of gamers that this will hit in a good way, but again . . . This is a niche! This is a game best suited to a scientific study on human behavior but not something to enjoy on a day off from work at home. Please try again Dev's, and make a more enjoyable game that involves actual challenges and not endless torture, we have enough Demon Souls and Dark Souls like games out there to do that for us.

Honestly the game is far too unforgiving. I love almost everything about it, the weapons are fun, the world is great, the story is interesting so far...but when you finally get your build working, and have some great synergistic parasites, a high level weapon that you love, then you walk in to a boss room for your first time fighting something deliberately designed to be difficult only to be killed and sent back to the start of the game with basically nothing it's too disheartening.

I get that it's a roguelike and that's part and parcel, but where this falls in comparison to others is that the time sink for each run is massive. Roguelikes actually want you to complete them as the real fun in them lies in completing them multiple ways, and changing your decisions to get more interesting results...but this is narrative game about a woman trapped in an endless cycle of torment and they want you to feel that. When the game pulls away from bullet hell and puts me in a house scared shitless at every sound and movement, I'm on the edge of my seat.

Then I pick up some item and it puts my max HP at 50% then it puts me in a room with 8 octopus dogs flanking me from every direction and 6 jellyfish trying to ram in to me whilst a teleporting tree-man attaches me on the ground, and 4 turrets are blasting me from range and a big green pulse is healing everyone faster than I can damage them, then flashes "LOCKDOWN IN PLACE"...and I'm just like, where do I even start with this? And that's not to mention that I've already finished this level and I'm just trying to get back to the other areas to progress further.

If this game was a soulslike where I could take time getting the items I want and min-maxing my build, I'd happily bash my head against this wall over and over, but as it stands right now I'm not having any fun.

Let me tell you why I'm obsessed with this damn game.

Huge fan of roguelike games already, so that's an obvious plus. But in addition to all the technical reasons why Returnal is an ongoing treat to play, the story that the game slowly feeds you is haunting, tragic, exciting, and mysterious. Every bit of new lore I get gives me a new clue as to WHAT THE HELL IS GOING ON HERE. Seriously - what the hell IS going on here? I need to know!

I have half a dozen different theories at the moment, and any of them could fit. I need to find the next clue. I need to know what is happening to Selene. Who is she? WHAT is she? This game is not what it seems on the surface, and if you're a sucker for science fiction mystery and have the patience to find out for yourself, this is the game for you.
