An awesome rougelike concept! I am so glad this game got ported to PC because I can finally aim better than on a PS5. A must play for anyone who likes tight shooting mechanics and lot of movement. The worlds are beautifully designed and the random generation of each room encounter adds a new flavor every time you go through a run. 

My only complain is that sometimes the game can really feel like its "out to get you". There are too many ways for the player character to be de-buffed and not enough pickups that really feel really powerful. The odds are always heavy stacked against you and with heavy penalties put on getting hit even once, the game can feel like a real soulslike game. 

If you are up for the challenge, the gameplay loop is really enjoyable and addictive!

I saw everything that was being said about the memory leaks and I decided to ignore them because I saw ONE redditor say that it wasn't as widespread as people make it out to be so I listened to him and thought to myself:
"theres no way that with my completely new setup and 16 gb of VRAM that would be an issue for me"

What the hell was I thinking.

On my second day of playing i got the memory leak within 30 minutes of opening the game. My frames cut down from 200 fps to 100 within the course of seconds. My VRAM usage went from 4 to six to 12 every time I blinked my eyes.

I'm genuinely torn that this happened because I actually REALLY like the combat, even after requesting and getting my refund I find myself wanting to get the game again but the memory leak issue is too much to ignore and unfortunately the devs have appeared to abandoned updating it.

The game is fun, but there seems to be a memory leak or something of the sort. After about an hour of gameplay, you need to reboot the game otherwise you get performance issues. Until they come out with a patch, I recommend getting it on PS5.

Though Steam shows I had 30 hours when I finished Returnal, it felt like weeks.

I'm not a bullet hell player, normally, but enjoy a rogue-like on occasion and Returnal knew just how to balance the former with the latter to draw the player in. I ended up playing longer than I thought and digging further each iteration without realizing how much better I'd gotten at the game's mechanics. The skill development system is rewarding enough that it feels natural, while still being challenging if you have a so-so roll on a run.

As for the story, I found it a good driving force without being too heavy in the gameplay loop. Again, the developers knew how to give just enough to balance multiple iterations without feeling grindy or stingy, to me. The community's discussion and unraveling of the story was also something I enjoyed; theories and discussions are something I like in a game's community and Returnal, again, delivers.

As I write this, I think it might be time for me to pick it up again and try to complete(?) the Tower to unlock a little more story.

What I liked:
It took me quite a while to "get gud" at this game, but as I got familiar with the controls, the enemies, the gameplay, I really found that this game is excellently balanced and fun to play.

I also really like the gameplay itself - a very satisfying shooter - with great variety on weapons, powerups, build options for different gameplay styles.

Having started with this game on the PS5 - moving to PC with much better graphical capabilities proved to me that PC is the way to play this game - it was startling to see how much better this game looks - the PC version really looks fantastic. 

The Story is organic, and very interesting to me. I fully enjoyed unlocking story pieces, and finding my way into things, finding random items, and searching for things I needed. Great integration of story and Art. Really a ton of content was put into this one.


What I didn't like:
I didn't like getting killed all the time - and I did - a lot... but, I guess that's the learning curve - I died a LOT playing Metroid Dread too...

For folks who don't appreciate hard games - this isn't for you. It's hard.

Returnal keeps getting harder and I just keep coming back. When you get that perfect run where all the artefacts just works for you it is gonna be freaking great.

But I will warn that it is not really well optimized and I do find that theres abit of stutter.

Sadly this game is a wasted opportunity. There is lots to love about it but ultimately it doesn't come together into an enjoyable experience. 

Here's the deal: the core game play loop is very fun. The combat is awesome, I love the world as well, the story, the atmosphere are all done very well. 
But, this is a rogue like, and these games are very difficult to design well. It's a balancing act where you have to make the player want to come back for "just one more run". Unfortunately I feel the opposite when I die and my run ends.  To be fair I don't normally like this genre, but I thought Hades did an amazing job with it where even I enjoyed it, and completed the game 10+ times to get the true ending.

There are a couple things that made that possible: in Hades once you figured out your play style and leveled up your character, you breezed through the early levels with ease, and so the run length was pretty much always around 30 minutes. It was more generous with permanent upgrades to make this possible. 
This game is the opposite. On the one hand it does give you shortcuts to the later biomes, but if you go there you will die immediately because there are under powered. 
So it makes you grind the early levels over and over and over again. Who thought this will be fun? I don't know what the balance fix would be, but they gotta do something where you can jump back in clean up the early sections real fast so it doesn't feel like a grind.

As it is, I might finish it if I got nothing better to do, the story would motivate me, but I am really not looking forward to the early level grind.

I played Returnal on PS5 and on PC and I liked the game on both systems. However, using keyboard and mouse just makes it more enjoyable and (for me) easier. Works great on Steam Deck! Utterly fantastic game. Lowest graphical settings still work pretty well. Amazing storyline; tough but fair; rewards exploring after you've cleared each biome (so that weapons are max when you open boxes and healing items increase your health). Game blew my mind and how it ran so well on original Steam Deck (not the new OLED one). Steam Deck issues: it stuttered once really bad so I had to close/suspend. When I rebooted the game (didn't have to reboot Steam Deck), it worked fine. I suspended twice more just to make sure the fourth and fifth (sixth biome) boss didn't have any issues. Steam says this game isn't verified for Steam Deck BUT it worked fantastic for me :)

Need more games like this honestly. The gameplay slaps, the music's great, the story is actually really complex and deep and gets you thinking if you let it, it's got such an incredible atmosphere with well crafted environments and hostiles and it has it's challenging moments. 

That being said, like any rouge-lite, since it is primarily a story driven experience with a bit of replayability, the difficulty can start to drop off if you play more safe and as you learn enemies and the specific maps and weapon niches, etc. 

If it is approached from a perspective of a re-playable story or even if you just really enjoy the mechanics and what kind of builds you can make and wish to level stuff fully to be a completionist, this game can easily last you quite a while. That isn't even including the sort-of-separate tower climb experience included also, oh and multiplayer shenanigans.

Overall, so glad this game came to PC, as it was one that I always wanted to play and experience. I look forward to hopefully 100 percenting it soon!

What a great game Returnal is. I can only praise it.

The graphics are top-notch. Never have I seen a prettier use of particles in a game. Though I had some problems with textures stopping to load properly after some time. A game restart was necessary in those cases.

The music is ominous and really well-fitting to the theme. The sounds are also really well integrated, from guns and monsters to splash effects of cracking slime eggs. The voice acting is also really great. You can feel the AAA budget here in all aspects.

The setting is dark, forboding, Eldritch-like, and really interesting. When I sank into the Abyss I really thought: "How the hell could the atmosphere become even more  uneasy than before?"

The story is fragmented (comparable to Dark Souls), vague, and ambigous to leave room for the players interpretation.

The weapons feel great with all their unlockable traits. The same gun can play vastly different with with different combinations of traits.

The replayability is high, especially to get the whole story, multiple playthroughs are necessary with collecting various items. Other rogue-lites like "The Binding of Isaac" still offer more replayability.

The third-person-shooter bullet-hell combination feels really good which is really highlighted in the bossfights. Those will ask alot of you at your first time, but I could beat practically all bosses the first time around.

So I'd rate the game as not too hardcode challenging.

With its DLC "Tower of Ascension" youg et even more action in more compact form, which adds even more fun to the mix.

I highly recommend Returnal to you if you like Rogoue-lites or action-packed Third-Person shooters.

A combination of fast third person shooter, bullet hell and roguelite that doesn't gel together as well as you would expect. I recommend getting it only on sale.

Some of the bigger turnoffs for me were:

* The first boss seems to be designed in a way that will give you way more trouble than later bosses and will only pad playtime.
* Some skills that feel like they should be permanently unlocked are instead luck dependant items (enjoy having yellow portals you can't open because the upgrade will drop next level).
* Similarly at least one key permanent upgrade is locked behind a door that depends on random key drops.
* Act 2 ramps up encounters by just throwing more enemies with denser bullet patterns at you, doesn't do anything new
* Melee attack can't hit certain enemies at melee range, because of crappy hitboxes
* At least in my experience I got severe graphical bugs that force me to restart the game (screen turning permanently black after falling off a ledge or into water)
* Using Parasites does not seem really worth it unless you have some extremely lucky combination of items.
* Same for the malignancy mechanic, the risk is usually pointless, because normal drops are enough to finish the game.
* Only a couple of weapons are worth using (late game hollowseeker usually beats everything)
* One of the game endings is super easy to miss, and the payoff is not worth the effort it takes to get it.
* Coop has the super annoying choice of not letting your coop partner wander too far, and you can block each other's way. The netcode is so-so.
* Coop has strange rules regarding which items stay on the map for both players and which ones don't.
* No coop in Tower of Sysyphus without modding the game.

It's no wonder the character is so confused, you can't break the loop. You can never get ahead of the curve. It's a game that could be good but the developer was too focused on making it difficult and not focused enough on "is this game mechanic fun?"

This game is as buggy and broken as all the negative reviews say it is.  No, it's not your system.  Running a 4060 and a Ryzen 7 5700X, more than enough for the game.  I encountered numerous bugs on my run, some of which my co-op partner also experienced:

-Textures turning low-quality after a period of gameplay, despite being on High.
-Collected items continuing to appear on map as if uncollected
-Weapons and items not appearing for one player or the other
-Spawning in to a room in the air, and falling until damaged, infinitely until dead

Aside from the last one, these aren't game-breaking, but they are incredibly annoying, and genuinely unacceptable.  These issues are not unique to me, multiple posts around the internet speak of the very same problems, particularly the texture quality drop over time.  Despite these issues, the game is still very fun, but due to them I strongly suggest you do not buy Returnal on PC.  Get it on PS5 if you have one, and if not, do without.  You deserve better for your money.

One of the best games I have ever played. Yes, it was quite challenging at first - but the brilliant gunplay, sound, atmosphere, graphics and haptics (if you are using a dual sense), kept me going. The gameplay loop is just awesome, and the RNG elements are perfect and keep you coming back.

Once it clicks, and you begin to upgrade weapons, it becomes a whole lot of fun. I beat the game weeks ago, but continue to play more than any other game. Replay-ability is off the charts because it's so damn satisfying. In addition to the 61 hours I've put in on PC, I've also played for 40 hours on PS5. I have never played a single game for over 100 hours, until Returnal.

If you like good video games, you should play Returnal.

The roguelike gameplay loop is done very well. There is a decent sized suite of weapons to experiment with, each with unique modifiers that meaningfully change up how you approach areas. In addition to weapons, there are also [i]a lot[/i] of other modifiers in the form of artifacts (passive upgrades) and parasites (one good effect and one bad). Playing hard into risk vs reward kept each run interesting.

Every region you fight through has an impressive amount of detail and they all look really good. The same is true for the enemies and especially the region bosses. The boss of Biome 4 is particularly cool.

Sound design is incredible. It's not something I normally pay that much attention to, but it was too good to ignore here. Everything just sounds right.

The git gud is real here though. This was definitely one of the most git guddinest games I've gotten gud at.

[b][u]Highly recommended.[/u][/b]

While the gunplay on its own feels good and mechanically it feels great and buttery smooth to run around in, ultimately I can't recommend this because the actual roguelike elements are so sparse and the runs take too long so it just feels very samey and I lost interest in wanting to beat the game.

First found this game after watching the Jacob Geller video, which mentioned that at the time that it was recorded, very few had actually passed the first level. You can absolutely assume I took that as a challenge.

That was a mistake. Among my friends, I am known as a masochist. Instead of attempting to break these habits, I decided to harness our mutual enjoyment of my (overly dramatic) suffering. 

Then the gameplay loop kicked in. Each weapon feels responsive, and they all have their own perks and drawbacks. Strategies need to be tweaked and sometimes scrapped. I have to remember to pick up

~THAT_DAMNED_ASTRONAUT~

Constantly going through the ringer again and again, I find myself fighting bosses with knowledge I wouldn't have if not for all the other failed attempts. Trial and error. What works and what doesn't. How to do it again, but faster and better. Perfection while eternally seeking rest and penance. Selene can't escape, but she might as well try.

The story, while on the backburner on account of spoilers within Geller's deep dive, absolutely encapsulates my favorite type of time loop-everything changes but you. Selene's personal hellscape and its symbolism-hidden under completions and encounters with an Apollo-era astronaut that haunts her-along with elements of her home world merging with Atropos grip tightly, and ensnare the player with an adamant decree that every single element of potential lore and subtext be analyzed and every single Greek term and name be traced and researched in an effort to leave the changing planet.

At the time of writing this, I have not finished the game. Hell, I don't even have a completed run. But I remain adamant, and, after having taken a good break and returning as of this review, I have faith that I can beat the loop, even if it is ultimately futile. Even in death, you are not free. You should still try, however.

Don't fear the Reaper.

In the cosmic abyss, where dimensions intertwine and reality splinters, a lone astronaut named Selene found herself stranded on a desolate planet. The alien landscape seemed to writhe and pulsate with an unfathomable energy, as if the very fabric of existence quivered under the weight of the unknown. Selene's mind, fraught with doubt and disorientation, questioned the veracity of her surroundings, for the shifting terrain seemed to defy the laws of physics she had long held sacrosanct.

As she traversed the eerie topography, she perceived grotesque, amorphous shapes that slithered through the ethereal mist, their shadows elongating unnaturally as they pursued her with a sinister intent. The celestial bodies above, with their eldritch luminosity, cast a ghastly glow upon the land, revealing spectral ruins that hinted at an ancient, malevolent civilization long lost to time.

Her senses became ensnared by an otherworldly chant that echoed through the alien winds, whispering secrets of forgotten love and abominable truths that threatened to unravel her sanity...

This is a solid game. 

The story and cinematics left a substantial impression. Although there are deeper themes in the game that might require a bit of outside searching to really understand, you get the gist of what is going on slowly but surely. 

The environments are oftentimes ornate and creepy, featuring a mix of Giger-esque themes and some aethetics I would expect from a Zdzisław Beksiński painting. The visuals in general are quite stunning, and the worlds are pretty large - but you also will traverse them quite quickly.

For gameplay, it is intense. It has great dodge mechanics - both on ground and mid-air - plus excellent maneuverability. You'll need that for constant dodging of brilliant neon projectiles while shooting at their sources. I used a PS4 controller and it worked great for this game. You can also put together somewhat different builds depending on the weapons and accessories you pick up, but you should be ready to toss those for better things that come along - and they do get dropped often enough to make you consider switching.

There is also a game mode that is a sort of endless gauntlet that you can play. There are people out there that have gotten to Phase 18 and beyond on it, but I've never gotten far past phase 3. >_> Still, there are some story items you can unlock by just replaying those initial few levels/phases, so there is reason to do the gauntlet that goes beyond just challenge.

I'm not sure I have much to critique. The only thing that comes to mind is that although the main campaign's maps are relatively randomly generated, there is a bit of samey-ness or overlap between the first three areas and the last three areas.. or at least areas 1&2 with 4&5. It is intended for story reasons, but I do wish things differed a bit more.

When I saw trailers for this game, it seriously made me consider getting a PS5. Since there wasn't much else on that system that I couldn't already access via PC, I am *very* glad it was eventually ported to PC.

I believe this title to be simply amazing. While growing up, I found it more and more difficult to be really impressed by a new video game, Returnal managed to accomplish this task.

Great game with an especially well crafted story, Immediately intriguing and it only gets better, the greek mythology inspiration is sometimes too on the nose and the symbolism can get confusing if you aren't planning to watch a youtube explanation.

boss design is top notch but for a game that takes inspiration from bullet hell shooters, the third person perspective can get messy and all over the place, with so many projectiles coming from every direction.

While the story can keep the intrigue going with some amazing twists, the difficulty unfortunately lets it down, boss fights can sometimes be obnoxiously difficult and even attempting a boss fight again is multi hour venture, the payoff for the story feels disappointing when weighed against how difficult it was to get there, if you don't enjoy the gameplay you might as well find a Youtube essay to explain the story because the game will not make it easy to get to them on your own.

In summary, fantastic game, great story, found the gameplay decent but sometimes frustrating and the difficulty can get obnoxious, but it's one of those games you really ponder after finishing and find yourself thinking about it and analyzing it over and over again, definitely well worth the time for me

This is one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had. The atmosphere is so cold and alien. The music is powerful and haunting, the perfect soundtrack to frantically blast your way through waves of aliens while maneuvering deftly past streams of radiant projectiles. The mobility and gunplay are perfect for me - my keyboard and mouse seamlessly controlled Selene. Never once did I feel out of sync with the game, a perfect flow. The boss fights are hypnotizing, both calming and engaging. There aren't really any cheap one-shot mechanics, you just learn the moves and weave back forth all the while unleashing hell at some giant emotionless, alien god. There is one boss in particular that will burn itself into your brain. I won't spoil anything here but the buildup and showdown is just something I can't forget. Housemarque really made something magical. I joke with my friends, this game is what it feels like to chew 5 gum.

There is a story here, too. Something dark and tragic. It's never outright explained, but it left it's impression on me. I can still hear Selene remarking "Abandoning Helios" every time a brand new run starts. To me it's a sad game, victory is fleeting and you are alone, fighting an endless battle.

I believe the game is worth the $60 asking price, but I did buy it on sale for around $47.

[spoiler]Don't Fear the Reaper was already a great song, but having it be a recurring theme in this game was such a welcome surprise. I can't help but be taken back to the ruins of Atropos whenever I hear it.[/spoiler]

Returnal. Is a great game, and I absolutely recommend it.

For my roguelite enthusiasts, I'll put it this way. Imagine a AAA game built loosely around the Commando and their kit from Risk of Rain 2. Give the bosses Dark Souls levels of difficulty. String the areas together as if it were an action RPG. Boom. That'll get your mind pretty close to how Returnal plays, and man, it is fun.

One reason to enjoy it: The gameplay is so tight and refined. I played on a PS5 controller and thought that might impair how I normally play with M&K but it didn't. Guns feel impactful and all the while the music increases in intensity as the tension rises, as you attempt to clear rooms and waves of enemies without taking damage. It creates amazing spectacle encounters in every room and can often make you feel the pressure of your potential demise. Sure, there are still times you can live out your power fantasy (as roguelites tend to let you do), as an unkillable god-being, but it's these intense runs facing death itself that make your spontaneous god-runs feel oh so satisfying.

The other part about Returnal that really made me fall in love with it is the mystery. The more you play the more you (think you) understand. You'll find glyphs in your run and slowly translate them into strange little conundrums. You'll find ruins of civilization and strange creatures inhabiting this odd world. Death is a part of the lore as well, so you're trying to understand the time loop. Just when you think you understand this game it gives you a well-earned reveal that changes your entire perspective. Not everything is as it seems. The twists in here go harder than freakin' Shamylan and I lived for them. I wish I could share more, but it's just best if you find these glorious moments yourself... and trust me. Understanding more about the game will just cheapen the experience. It is a wild and exceptionally good ride.

That being said there is more for me to experience in Returnal that I have not experienced quite yet (2023 has been unpredictably amazing in terms of releases which has pressed me for time), but I don't think completing these will change my opinion. I certainly intend to return (heh) soon of course. They can't just tout a "true ending" without me finding it. But just know my marked 21 hours isn't the reaaal end of the game.

I imagine most will complete the campaign in about 25 or so hours, and on top of that, you have the endless mode which is incredibly satisfying as well. Capitalizes on the speed and thrill of combat without the travel time that can make the "metroid-ing" around the campaign a little tiresome from moment to moment. Also has its own conundrum of a narrative it follows, which is quite cool. Aside, but co-op was something I wanted to try, but never got around to. Would probably be fun.

As far as some lower notes go: Ran into one unavoidable bug that is 100% replicatable and happens every time (I posted about it in community forums and their website). Not the greatest PC port in general really. It worked for me way better than other reviewers but YMMV. I also... had a difficult time with the time allotment this game presents itself with. What I mean by that is... If I'm not sure I'll be gaming uninterrupted for like 2 hours I won't even bother to turn on Returnal paha. You can save and quit during a run at any time... but every time I do that in other roguelites I come back and die, so I'm incentivized per my own experiences to play one run all the way through to completion. Returnal is VAST. Runs can take hours. If you're stingy like me on saving and quitting you'll find it a bit difficult in that way as well.

But overall this is such an awesome game, with so many incredible high notes. The gameplay and progression feel great, the narrative mystery is excellent, and the presentation is absolutely top-notch. Because of the bugs and the lack of support on PC, it would be wise to wait for it to go on a bit of a deeper sale, but seriously, if you're looking for your next roguelite fix, I'm telling you right now, Returnal is a game you're not going to want to miss.

Returnal is a third person shooter which has roguelite mechanics. The player controls astronaut Selene Vassos who is trapped in a time loop after her shuttle crash landed on a strange alien planet.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

•	Combat is fast paced, and features enemies whose bullet hell style attacks will often flood the screen with energy projectiles, which means you need to be constantly moving to avoid taking damage. To help with this you have a dash move, which if timed correctly will let you pass safely through projectiles. And later in the game you’ll acquire a grappling hook which can attach to specific locations in the environment. While primarily designed to let you cross large gaps and reach high ledges, its also really useful for quickly avoiding nearby enemies.

•	When you die, you’ll return to the crash site at the start of the game and lose most of the weapons and upgrades you’d collected during the previous run. However, you’ll keep important story items, and you can unlock shortcuts back to later areas, so its not too punishing. You’ll find healing items regularly, and there are a couple of items which give you an extra life to extend that run.

•	Each time you start a new run, the world will have a partially randomised layout. Each individual room has a fixed layout, but they’ll be connected together in a different order, and will contain different enemies, weapons and items.

•	Your journey will take you from a jungle to a desert, a stone city, a frozen wasteland, and a deep underwater abyss. You’ll encounter hostile wildlife resembling big cats and squids (both have lots of tentacles), aggressive plants, robots, flying drones, sentry turrets and massive bosses with multiple health bars and attack stages.

•	The weapons you can use all have fancy sci-fi names, but effectively there’s a pistol, shotgun, rocket launcher, grenade launcher and a couple of assault rifles. Each weapon has an alternate fire special attack which operates on a cooldown, and you can unlock extra passive abilities such as homing projectiles or bullets that heal you based on damage dealt to enemies. You can also use a sword for close range melee attacks and to break enemy shields.

•	My one complaint about the combat is that you can only carry one gun at a time. Most areas have wide open spaces, which means in most situations I want rapid fire weapons that are accurate at long range, so I usually ignore everything except the 2 assault rifles. The other weapons are only useful in specific situations, so if I can’t switch between different weapons, I’ll never take those other weapons.

•	There are several risk/reward mechanics. You can attach parasites to your body which will give you a positive and negative perk, for example heal every time you kill an enemy, but you can no longer use medkits. You’ll find chests which could contain a useful item, but also have a chance to give you a negative perk. And you’ll enter trap rooms where tempting items are placed in the middle of laser traps or on the other side of bottomless pits where you’ll need to navigate small platforms.

•	Combat can be very challenging at times, and it wasn’t just the bosses that gave me problems. Sometimes I’d encounter a particularly annoying group of enemies in a room that didn’t have much cover, or there would be so many enemies and projectiles on screen that I couldn’t keep track of everything. However, I made some kind of permanent progress every few attempts, and finally defeating an enemy who had previously killed me multiple times felt great.

•	It took me around 20 hours to complete the main story, and in addition to this there’s an endless mode where Selene must climb the “Tower of Sisyphus” one floor at a time, fighting waves of enemies along the way.

[h1]Story[/h1]

•	Story is interesting, and there are plenty of hints that things are not exactly as they seem, but it ends just when we’re starting to get answers about what is happening.

•	Story is mostly told through audio logs and a few flashback cutscenes. Voice acting is quite good.

[h1]Technical[/h1]

•	Controls are fully rebindable and the combat feels great with mouse and keyboard.

•	Performance is excellent. I have a very smooth framerate at 1440p with all settings maxed except ray tracing which is on medium.

•	There’s a very useful benchmark which shows what effect each setting has on CPU and GPU load. I wish every AAA game would include something like this.

•	I’ve crashed twice, but haven’t encountered any other bugs.

[h1]Recommendation[/h1]

Returnal is an excellent game, and is definitely a must play for fans of shooters. You might want to wait for a small sale due to the length of the game.

This is a hidden gem. A massive roguelite with great writing and super-engaging bullethell gameplay. I am not a fan of horror games, and this is not a "horror" game. Even though I was scared multiple times, I was overall gripped by the secrets and the story of Selene, the main character.

The only issues I encountered while playing were that every cutscene had audio desync and few hectic moments of the game had frame drops. The cutscenes were the worst part since I ended up skipping most of them and actually watching them on youtube as I was making progress. I was not the only person to have this issue, but I couldn't seem to find a solution online.
So bad yet so good.
so fucking cool

As a veteran of Rogue likes this game is amazing! 

While the AAA space definitely did not invent the genre, and this isn't revolutionary, the gameplay and narrative are nicely intertwined, and there's a lot of very cool details on display here. It feels very solid, and is an excellent benchmark for testing new hardware, with trance-like gameplay if you let it.

So glad this finally made its way to PC, because it is fantastic. There is the usual UE issues, but my biggest issue was Memory Compression killing my framerate. I upgraded from 32GB to 64GB and then was able to use powershell to disable memory compression in Windows and my performance skyrocketed. Seriously wish I knew about that beforehand, but once that was sorted, I had no complaints. This game has such great systems in place for you to really sink into. The guns all have pros and cons (Electropylon Driver all day for me) but the risk/reward system is just so addictive. The story is great too, not too overt, not too abstract, just a really good scifi tale that you learn more of the more you look. It's not like a FromSoft where you have to read essays in every description too, they actually have lore that plays out, as well as can be read. It's really just so well balanced that I have to say that it is one of my favorites of the past few years.
I like the game play and how it kinda randomizes the rooms after death

If you are interested in this as a roguelike I would say it's not really worth. You can't really build up unique runs by combining items and status effects. It's more about building up health and finding higher level weapons. From there it's rinse and repeat since you more or less get the same items every run. Some items can help this out and make a pretty big difference in that respect, but I never really found any items that made the game play any differently. Some of the weapons have cool and unique mechanics but in all honestly they don't change up the game enough for it to really matter. Runs can easily be 5-6 hours long and without any promise of cool builds, combining artifacts for an OP run, or something of the sort, the game started to feel really miserable. Because of this once you have a completed run there isn't really any reason to play it again imo.

It's not incredibly hard, but definitely challenging enough for the average person. The game is beautiful, the base mechanics are really fun and fluid, and the story is solid enough. Also I gotta give it up, the bosses are all really fun and interesting. They each have their own thing going on, not super difficult, but definitely challenging and fun. However performance is not great. Even with a 3080 and a 5950x there were some rooms where the frames were just awful. The game relies super heavily on timing and in crowded rooms the frame drops can be a real problem. I more than once found myself 2-3 hours into a run, entered a crowded room, and instantly dropped to 30 fps. When you're that deep into a run, dying to the game not performing well is super aggravating.

*SPOLIERS*

Once you are in act two the balancing just goes out the window. I have had two runs that start in act two and the second room is a mini boss room. It's definitely beatable but starting a run off, having no items, and immediately being 1hp is just not fun. The ability to skip bosses both helps and hurts the game, in act one it was such a relief being able to get back to where I was in about 10-15 minutes, kept it fun for me. However because of this mechanic I never fought any of the bosses more than once. The risk vs reward system was really fumbled imo. Much like risk of rain 2 with lunar items, most items have a good and bad effect attached to them. However in this game the good very rarely out weighs the bad. Some of the chests can trigger waves of enemies in an already cleared room, and then the item you get is most of the time not worth picking up as the negative status effects would kill the run. Some chest are "malignant" but they come with the promise of "very valuable items". So you have to either clean the chest with 3-5 ether which in the early game is sometimes a lot, or you take a negative status effect and even then the items in the chest can be things that you are able to find on the ground at no cost. Additionally some of those chests also require a key that if used on a chest may it may prevent you from accessing rooms later in the run. It just feels like a big "fuck you" if you invest that much into getting item and then it's not worth picking up or it's something the game already gives you for free. Very often led to me not risking anything.

Overall I would say the game is really cool, but it wasn't very fun, for me.

Well, I bought this game tempted by positive comments and nice trailers. Unfortunately, I quickly learned that this game is simply over hyped. The most important problem with this game is its concept. You go over randomly generated map, killing monsters (easy and boring), gaining weapon skill points from killing them, gathering some upgrades and a kind of currency to buy items and upgrades in special machines. These are all required for you to have a chance to defeat a boss. And killing a boss is of course required to progress to the next stage of the game. It typically takes you minimum an hour or two to grind and reach to the boss. The boss kills you. You have to start again. You loose all the skill points, currency and upgrades which you gathered. So you explore the map, kill the same type of boring enemies, grind the same resources and items. You thing it goes well that time. Then suddenly the game throws you powerful enemy on your face and locks you in limited space. You dies. You need to start from scratch again. After a few hours of repeating these boring activities, you might finally defeat the first boss. You think it is great. Then you will die somewhere on the second stage (and there are plenty occasions for that). And guess what? You need to start from the beginning. Or the second boss will kill you. And you will start form scratch again. This concept of dying and resurrecting was funny maybe 4-5 times, because with each iteration I was able to find or learn something new. After that there is nothing new to explore or to learn. The same enemies, the same weapons (there are only 5 or 6 types in the game, so don't expect too much), the same items. Map layout changes every time, but that's all, still many areas and rooms are repeatable just placed in random order. You cannot save. You cannot lower difficulty. You can only start again from the beginning with a hope that after 2 hours of grinding and killing boring enemies, you will finally manage to defeat extremely powerful boss. But if you won't? Sorry, you die, you start from scratch again. After a few tries when I learned that this is too boring to continue, I found a way to make a backup of local save files and restore them. Then I learned why this concept of perma death exist. Without it, you will be likely able to complete the game in less than 10 hours and the story is so thin... I really wanted to like this game. But it did not allow me that in any way. If you like doing boring stuff again and again, go on with that game. I don't, so I gave up with this. There are plenty more interesting games or things to do rather than wasting my time like that.

Returnal is a great game flawed by its not-so-great performance (optimisation).

I have to mention the performance as I don’t believe the game is that well optimised. I couldn’t run the game consistently at 100 FPS at a 1080p resolution with an RTX 2080 even on Low Settings (with DLSS enabled). The game would frequently stutter (drop to 70 FPS even when areas are empty of enemies) and I couldn’t find how to best fix that online. There were a few options to turn this or that thing off on your computer but no one explained how that would affect anything else (like other games or applications) so I dared to not try. So what I did was enable V-sync and played at 60 FPS. Even then the game would sometimes chop a few frames here and there but there were very few times where I felt noticeable stuttering.

So, if you’re comfortable playing at 60 frames (with 2080 or low end GPU) at 1080p, then you should definitely consider picking it up as this is a great roguelike.

The gameplay is tight and responsive. The enemy variety was good but not amazing. For 10 hours it was great but after that the monsters overstayed their welcome. Same goes for the arenas.

There’s a bunch of weapons to master and play with. Biomes, collectibles, secrets - it’s all there for you to explore and unlock.

The game setting and soundtrack are great. Returnal does feel like a love letter to the “Alien” movie with a roguelike twist on it and mythology influence.

As for the story - it’s good. It does leave you wondering after the first playthrough and I love those kinds of games that you talk and think about after you finish them.

Overall - great game but a better optimisation would have been great.

Returnal is a seriously good game. Every 10 minutes while playing this I picked up on some new clever mechanic, or was engrossed further in it plot, or came across an unexpected discovery. The entire run time I was totally glued to the screen. It really does nail almost everything - Story, music, gameplay, graphics, acting, etc. My biggest complaint is probably that once I 'got it' I flew through the whole game in one super clean run with little challenge; for the game's notorious reputation for being challenging, that was pretty disappointing.  To be clear, the balance is really good, where things are stressful and make you work for it, but it feels pretty fair, and the pacing is nice with good down time, but I kinda wanted something a little more challenging than what I ultimately played. In the end, though, I can't recommend this game enough for those of you that like deep mechanics, numbers, and reaction-based games.

P.S. I also want to add, though not really relevant to the game itself, that this is an excellent port; probably one of the best out there. Ran like butter, a huge number of graphics, UI, audio, and accessibility options. Just a wonderful way to bring this to PC players.

P.P.S. It would be really killer if we could get this running on the Deck.

Returnaled all over the place

Things you should know about Returnal:
-It runs like complete ass at times, inexplicable FPS drops, textures just refused to load regularly for me, according to google there's still this persistent save deletion bug around which thankfully didn't happen to me
-Calling this a roguelike is an insult to actual roguelikes since there is essentially no variation between runs because all the random stuff you find is just straight stat buffs
-The story starts off very interesting and then takes a complete nosedive towards the end with the game ending literally without explaining anything other than increasingly implying but never stating that everything was just hallucination anyway
-Weapon balance is atrocious, some things like the automatic rocket launcher instantly delete everything including bosses, while even clearing the game becomes difficult even for seasoned players with others; you simply do not get enough weapon drops per run to justify this amount of variation in power
-Similarly, enemy tuning is also scuffed beyond measure, you think the big spectacle bosses at the end of the act are the most difficult thing in this game? Try the elite monsters that randomly spawn in some rooms, I died about 10 times total to all major act bosses combined this game, while there were times where i couldn't get out of act 4 for 2 hours straight because the elites kept deleting me in one of the first rooms

So wait, I just wrote an essay complaining how bad this game is, why is this a positive review: The core gameplay is just really fun, which is kinda the most important thing in a game like this. 

This is not a roguelike you can play for a very long time, by the time you are done with the story you will most likely become bored because there is so little variation, the story itself drops the ball really hard and the technical state is insulting, but as a purely gameplay focused single player title this game absolutely delivers a solid amount of fun for your money.

Also if you're playing this with KBM controls, the game difficulty is way overstated by everyone; don't get me wrong, this isn't a cakewalk, but if you don't intentionally summon the murdertrains that are the online only dead scout elite mobs, you won't have any trouble clearing this since its very obvious the difficulty was not tuned with the aim and mobility of a mouse in mind.

Returnal was a surprising hit for me. I wasn’t sure if I would like the bullet hell aspect of the game but when you get in a rhythm and know the move sets the game is fantastic fun. The game rewards you constantly and it feels like you are building Selene up to be a badass.

The game runs well although it does stutter when transitioning to a new area. I also haven’t encountered any bugs while playing so far.

I love the story; it was unexpected the direction it went in but made the journey feel more meaningful. The music complements the fights and environments beautifully. I kept wanting to come back for more. After beating the game I still have so much fun replaying to find every item and entry. Returnal is enthralling and I highly recommend people give it a go.

Aesthetically, it shows the DNA of the Alien series, with dark Gigeresque structures, monsters that are masses of writhing tentacles.

Difficulty wise, I thought it was adequate. It's a challenging game, but it gives you multiple incentives for getting good at it, with the integrity and adrenaline systems rewarding players who dodge effectively.

I found a few visual glitches and had some issues with frame stuttering, but nothing gamebreaking or that would take from the experience. Expected from a Playstation port.

I just finished the "true" ending of Act 3, and I have to say, Returnal has been one of the most intriguing, immersive, and white-knuckled gaming experiences I have had in some time. At a surface level, it almost feels like playing a darker roguelite version of Metroid Prime as you explore haunting regions across a broken alien planet. Look a little deeper, and you also have a tense and gripping narrative that explores themes of loss, trauma, and guilt.

I don't want to gush about the game for too long, as the positives of Returnal have been covered well enough by now, given that it was a AAA launch title for the PS5. I do have to give a special shout-out to the art direction and sound design, though; I don't think I've ever seen a more unsettling, rich, and enrapturing world in any other game. Each zone is absolutely beautiful, brimming with a sense of foreboding mystery; the developers have done an astoundingly excellent job at creating what feels like a real world, with a real alien society, that you explore the ruins of. Atropos is so engrossing and engaging that I just want to spend time exploring the gorgeous landscapes. Props must be given to the Abyssal Scar --one of the coolest zones in any game ever-- as well as the Crimson Wastes and Derelict Citadel for their sense of depth, breadth, and history. Truly, Returnal transports you to another world, and a system of Metroidvania-esque permanent unlockables adds a dynamic of unfolding exploration throughout the game's runtime. This is all supported by tense, horror-style narrative sequences that add emotional heft and context to the expanding scope and drama of the world.

Of course, the gameplay itself is tight, with a plethora of destructive tools and evasive maneuvers at your disposable, as well as a wealth of unlockable artifacts and consumables. The item system doesn't go quite as deep as something like Risk of Rain 2, but there are cool passives to be found and some interesting synergies to be assembled, even if it doesn't appear like it at first. Aside from items, the flagship in-run progression system is weapons: more specifically, traits and stats, which are two genius systems that work together to enable nearly infinite iterations of the already-fantastic base weapons in Returnal. Every weapon drop is a chance for analysis and decision-making as you assess each new, randomly-generated gun. And, for the ultimate risk-reward decision-making, corrupted "Malignant" items, currency, and health pickups will taunt you throughout your run, challenging you to take risks as you try and scrape together every bit of power you can.

I'd also be remiss not to mention the Tower of Sisyphus - this is an extraordinarily good addition to the base campaign worthy of its own review. I often split up my "core" game runs with Tower runs - while they don't quite have the atmospheric immersion and deep narrative of the "standard" runs across Act I/II zones, they offer a lightning-paced combat romp that captures the arcade-like sense of action and progression the roguelite genre is known for. It really shows off how great the core gameplay of Returnal is: laid bare, the combat shines as some of the best in the genre (and of any bullet-hell or third-person shooter, for that matter). And, all that being said, there still are intriguing, unsettling pieces of the narrative to uncover throughout the Tower, and these perfectly complement the primary story of a "normal" run. While I have plenty of unlockables to get from the main game, I foresee myself spending many hours in the Tower of Sisyphus, pushing myself to see just how high a score I can get.

All this is to say, Returnal is a truly special game well worth your time and money. I was hooked immediately when I started playing and had a feeling it may become one of my all-time favorite games; now, It's firmly settled in a top 3 spot, if not higher! I have immensely enjoyed my time with the game, and I really believe it shows what games are capable of as an art form: entertaining, exciting action; deep, multi-sensory immersion; and complex, satisfying storytelling. Returnal is one of those rare games where the gameplay mechanics support the narrative and vice versa: everything, and I mean EVERYTHING, is working together in Returnal, and it's working together splendidly. I could not recommend this game more highly: it is a definitive gaming experience worth a place in every person's library.

If you have never played this game before, Returnal is an amazing single-player experience. The grind to develop the skills to play the game well enough to finish a cycle for the first or second and so on times is paralleled by a story that is often told in pieces, but not always linearly. To tell you much more about progression would likely spoil you, so I'll leave it at that.

Once you have largely finished the main game, though it is accessible beforehand, is the game's Tower of Sisyphus score attack mode. This mode is single-player only, and includes an additional chunk of story and lore to take in as your reward for climbing higher and higher in the tower, though this reward is somewhat limited and delivered in a... in my opinion somewhat awkward fashion.

If you have played this game before, your primary reason to get it would be to play with your friends who haven't played this game before, as the co-op features in this game are restricted to players on other PC platforms. If you're an anti-Epic Games person, the co-op experiences- and many online features- are still beyond your reach, as Returnal uses Epic Online Services for multiplayer and online functionality.

I cannot talk about my experience with co-op as I haven't actually played it in co-op before. This is due to my insistence on wanting to play with my own friends, specifically, but if you're less interested in that and just want to play co-op, you do have the option to join or host a public cycle for other players to join.

Currently I'm playing through the game again on PC to scratch the itch that remained after I played it on PS5. Somehow, I'm still discovering brand new things- cutscenes I don't remember, areas and secrets that I felt like I never encountered- and it's been weirdly magical getting to experience this game again on my controller scheme of choice, mouse and keyboard. That said, if you've got a PS5 controller (a DualSense?), the adaptive triggers and rumble features are really something else, I highly recommend trying the game with it at least once.

I do have two main complaints:
1. This port features some significant graphical bugs and glitches compared to the PS5 version. Volumetric fog appears pixelated, even at the highest in-game setting (Epic), like it's rendering at a lower resolution than the rest of the game. Reflections in certain parts of the game can stagger awkwardly. Shadows and lighting sometimes shift dramatically from room to room in an instant, which is especially notable in the first biome. Props sometimes do not animate correctly, moving out of sync or in shifted positions during cutscenes. Some of this apparently depends on your frame rate.
2. Once you have finished the game and developed the skills to play it well, it stops feeling so challenging without deliberately making it harder for yourself. I wish there was a way, in-game, to scale difficulty higher- add more projectiles, more enemies, more damage, more enemy health, etc. In the Tower of Sisyphus mode, this already happens to an extent- and I'd like to play the main game now feeling like it's a similar difficulty to my first experience with it. A difficulty marked Easy -> Extreme would be a start, but I believe Housemarque has mostly moved on to newer things.

Even so, my complaints are largely superficial compared to the overall experience you get from this game as a new player. If you have a PS5, it might be slightly wiser to get this game on PS5 and leave it at that. But if you don't, this version of the game is more than equipped to take you on the same journey, both as a player, and in your role as Selene.

Overall – Returnal is one of the best games I’ve ever played. This game feels like Risk of Rain 2 meets Metroid, it’s just awesome. The gunplay feels unmatched by nearly anything else I’ve ever played. The co-op is a blast and the boss fights… the boss fights… they’re so incredibly well designed. You’re constantly having to balance bullet hell mechanics and platforming, but the fights never feel cheap, you might die a few times, but it always feels fair. The Nemesis boss fight is seriously so good and ridiculously fun. Each biome features unique enemy types, and the map layout is procedurally generated, which helps the restarts feel interesting. The story is unfortunately the weak part of the game, but the entire package around it is just so good! Highly Recommended.

Returnal is an extraordinarily underrated gem of a game. Never has a game kept surprising me over and over with its new mechanics, enemies, and story.

To best explain Returnal's experience, think of it as a Roguelike Metroidvania; every time you die, you come back to the starting location, and you need to start over again. However, every time you go through, you'll find locations that you simply can't access under normal circumstances because you just lack the necessary tool to get through that specific part.

Not to mention, despite the overwhelming appearance of things, Returnal is a challenging but relatively fair (and easy) game. I've managed to beat the game with only 3 cycles, which may say a lot about me personally, but the game works best when you die a few times so it can unlock new stuff for you to find and keep you hooked into it.

All being said, this is a brilliant game that you should play, even if you've never played Roguelikes before.

Where to begin....Returnal is my favorite game. My desert island game. I have 245 hours on my PS5 so it's amazing to have this on PC now. For me, this game has the tightest, most responsive controls I have ever experienced in a game. Everything just feels perfect. Right down to the aiming and jumping, it all feels dialed in to a level I have yet to find in any other game. The dualsense PS5 controller imo is a must to truly appreciate how good this game plays and feels. Every single detail in the environment (especially combat) is communicated to the player through the controller. I personally love how everything is randomized. You don't get to pick the weapons you start with. This, I feel, forces you to learn every weapons strengths and weaknesses which in turn makes you a more skilled and experienced player. Simply put, this game is a masterpiece. Of course it's not perfect, no game is....but If you enjoy challenging games with near infinite replay value then you owe it to your gaming self to play this amazing gem.

This game is a good contender for the middle recommendation button that steam does not have and so i will go with won't recommend this game.
 
The game has a presentation that is 10/10 and that's what made me buy it. The graphics are jaw dropping if you have everything on ultra + the rtx features turned on.

Here are a few things that make me not recommend this game:

-The movement is sometimes unpredictable when you need precision jumping on platforms. You somehow always manage to jump further than you wanted and the mid air controls are not the best (i'm not talking about the longer dash, just the jump itself).

-The weapon upgrades sometimes make you feel like a god getting that extra damage you needed and the other times makes you feel like the game hates you by not giving you a good upgrade to keep up with the ever harder enemies.

-The convoluted way of advancing the story and getting the real ending. That last sunface fragment in biome 6 almost made me go crazy.

-The performance is horrible. I'm running a 4090, ryzen 7950x3d and 64gb ram. I had some crazy drops from 150+ fps to around 70-80 in some zones. Ohh and the crazy amount of vram usage. This game 100% has a memory leak because i would start up the game and have 7-8gb vram used not even 2-3 hours later it would jump up to 11-12gb vram used which is insane if you think about it. Not everybody has a 4090 to play this game without using all of the available vram.

-The price way too high for a 2 year old game, yeah yeah it just came to steam in 2023 but the release was in 2021. It's almost as Sony doesn't want this game to sell and have more people play it.


Do i recommend the game at this current miserable 20% sale? Nah! Maybe a 40-50% sale and it's a worthwhile purchase, but be ready for some performance issues if you have a low to mid pc build.

Decent game + story, intriguing atmosphere, think Dead Space minus corridors but open level gameplay.  However there are several gotchas:
- beginning levels are to dark and compact, had to use Detective Vision to often; hard to see, died regularly
- starting pistol is absolutely useless even if several cycles later with higher weapon proficiency
- standing | slow walk aim function is useless during live combat with multiple pursuing enemies - game designed as run-shooter only
- cannot carry more than one weapon type at a time - very bad design, no in-combat weapon selection
- half or so weapon alt-fire functions are useless in live combat with multiple pursing enemies
- story is meh, don't care about main character personal relationships however alien connection is fascinating; plot could have been more generic to facilitate custom user character from start - playing as blondie chick interrupts immersion
- dash function almost useless during live combat - cool down to long, sequencing to short; great for exploring though
- Tower of Sysphus is meh, breaks-up main plot monotony
- health items (green) stack to build higher suit integrity even if health bar full - never clearly explained in tutorials
- buy at discount, prepare to spend time getting acclimated to developer mandated run-n-gun play-style
- game could have greatly benefited from tighter "Devil May Cry" controls and improved melee combat; there's an unsettling pause between strikes, features seem instinctively cut or missing, melee functions not fully realized or fluid
- game crashed a few times during play - nothing to bad but very annoying if at higher levels (have to start at beginning cycle to build suit features for final citadel boss)

[h1]Oh. My. God.[/h1]

Some of the most insane and satisfying gameplay I've seen. I read reviews but they don't do it justice.

It's a little hard, but not in the way that beats you down. It throws upgrades at you constantly -- none of that "here's a weapon every 5 seconds but they're all bad". No, you get some sort of upgrade practically every couple minutes. Plus the meta-upgrades that carry over. You're meant to die and start over, and I love how it ties that into the gameplay. Also, while I like some weapon style a [i]little[/i] more than others, they're all really good -- just pick up the highest level weapon you find and you get a ton of variation.

Very well paced - some intense bullet hell fire fights intermixed with some exploration of really great environments and compelling storyline. Battle, loot, die, try again and hope you get a little farther. Roguelike loot.

[b]The level design though - amazingly crafted.
Visually incredibly stunning and fabulous boss/creature design. Really cool weapons too.[/b]

Hands down the coolest game I've played in a long while.

It's called Returnal because you'll return the game as soon as you see the bugs and performance issues.

Finished the whole game, got the secret ending. I think its a really good game that's not really a rogue-lite but has some mechanics in. I loved the story and the mystery, I loved the gameplay, I loved the art style. It's a shame this game is so demanding with its graphics because I feel more people should play it. 

The game is hard at the start but once you get the ball rolling it gets easier. One tip is to focus on upgrading your weapon mods rather than trying to progress at early game, because they're busted. One thing I wish the game could have done is make the early game a little easier for those who aren't used to shooters like this. Luckily, I managed to pick up the mechanics easily and had little trouble there, but I can understand why a lot of people give up at the first boss. 

Loved the bosses in this game though. All of them were very memorable, and I especially loved [spoiler] Hyperion. [/spoiler]. The lead up and boss fight were amazing.  

One thing to note i'm getting a lot of stutters on a ryzen 5800x and 3070ti on 1080p ultrawide, though the settings in this game are superb and there is so much thought put into them, I wish they could put in a bit more effort into the optimization.

Overall 9/10

The concept behind this game design is truly remarkable. However, it seems that the developer's personal preferences may have influenced its design, which makes it particularly enjoyable for hardcore gamers. Once you become familiar with its mechanics and gain proficient shooting skills and patience, this game can become addictive, though some players might find it a bit repetitive after a while. Personally, I like to come back to it from time to time, but I find it challenging to play for long hours consecutively.

Additionally, for casual gamers, this game might present a bit of a challenge, especially during the beginning and boss fights, which could potentially lead to some moments of frustration.

Just rolled credits after the Act II final boss. What a game. It was hardcore and badass from start to finish, with gripping story elements along the way. I paid full price and don't regret a cent. The action is incredible. It's a game that demands you improve until the very end. Act I pushes you to play well and learn the mechanics, and once Act II starts, they ramp up the difficulty to make you wonder why you ever lost to Phrike. Every new world changes the way you approach combat, each new piece of gear changes the way you traverse, every new gun changes the way you think about enemies. It's just an amazing ride, start to finish. 

My PC is a powerhouse and I maintained 90+ frames despite my ultrawide and some actually insane bullet hell sequences. I saw some other reviews discussing bugs, but I experienced very few (my screen went dark after a teleport at one point and it almost cost me my final run but the game recovered. The only other issue was a crash near the beginning of my playthrough). 

Huge thanks to housemarque and climax for an incredible experience. I'm not done with Returnal, and don't think I will be for a while.

Returnal is a great exemple of how an action roguelite made by a AAA studio should be. 

The gameplay is exquisit, and it is simply a plesure to move around. Guns really differs from one another and feel and sounds fantastic.
Procedural generation is interesting and varied enough to not be too repetitive, but to still allow you to learn the different parts of a level.

Parasites, resines, relics and consumables allow some truely interesting builds, and can make or destroy a run depending on your (poor) choices.
Negatives effects add some great risk/reward layer on top of it.

Ambience and sound design are top notch, as expected from a AAA studio nowadays. The music is more of an ambient layer, but not very memorable.

Storywise, it's cryptic AF, and you slowly try to entangle fragments of texts, visuals, audio, until you reach the true ending, and then well... Still don't get a clear vision of it all. It's still interesting and making theory about it is fun enough.

Concerning the difficulty, yes, Returnal is tough, and knowledge of level parts, enemy attacks, and learning to position yourself will be necessary to succeed. Note that I am an average player, so your experience might be different.
My only disappointment is about bosses. While being memorable encounters and fun fight, I found them lacking in difficulty comparing to the rest of the game in general.
Great Game!
great story and great gameplay

Great game, bosses are though easy, but with huge 3x health pools, compared to some of the normal humanoid enemies, and the toughest enemies are minibosses with orange health bars.

You have 6 biomes to explore plus a tower, not sure about the tower difference between two timelines.
Boss amount though doesn't correspond to the amount of biomes.
First 3 have 3 bosses, the rest 3 have 2. First two are optional later on, and the same goes for the 4th one.

And then there is the tower boss, first and only time I encountered it, I got there with a rocket launcher, and to my surprise it did 0 damage to it, first though maybe I was missing some mechanic, but the alt fire that threw a grenade did damage to it, so I was basically doomed to die, as I wouldn't beat him just with an alt fire grenade that does barely any dmg, if it hits.

Also keep in mind this is a rougelite 3rd person shooter metroidvania/platformer.
Only thing you keep is an ingame currency for various things, and information, lore and weapon traits (keep in mind to pick up the weapon that has "new" written next to the trait, otherwise the game won't remember that you've found said trait on that weapon, if you don't like to use that weapon at that moment), everything else is restarted, though the 6 biomes are halved in terms of dying and where you start again, and if you ever get to the 4th biome, to get back to the first 3 without using co-op, you have to complete the 6th biome once. Sadly you can't carry over your temporary progression over to the other timeline after finishing the 3rd biome, or finishing the 6th biome. Each timelines 3rd/(6th) biome end acts as a death.

Loads of varied ranged weapons, each weapon has many traits, but the same amount.
You can only equip one weapon at a time, but you can switch any time you want, as long as you have access to the area where it was dropped.
First 3 biomes are limited to first 15 weapon levels, starting from 4th you start at 15 and can go up to 30. In the tower you can go from 1 to 45, depending maybe from which act/biome you start the tower.
Levels also unlock how many traits a weapon can have.
You also have a melee weapon that is a permanent unlock, and it's possible to make a melee build, but not suited to battle bosses.

You can also temporarily upgrade your stats, gain artefacts, and parasites (double edged sword).
Not sure about stat limits, the only limit that I know of is the health stat limit which is 300%, but you can gain that by collecting 3/2 resins, or silphiums when at full health, besides upgrading, or through some artefacts or parasites.
Artefact limit is 15, but you can destroy the ones you don't like to equip new ones.
Parasite limit exists too, but each new one you pick up, will replace a random parasite, same with removal through some game mechanics. each are pretty much as 1 place where you can sell equipped parasites randomly.

There is also a debuff mechanic that gives you up to 2 negative effects (malfunctions), each of them also has a special requirement that allows you to remove them, though there are some parasites/consumables that can remove them. 3rd debuff can't be gotten, but instead you'll get a critical malfunction that will destroy 1 random artefact.

There is also a buff effect called adrenaline for killing enemies, stacks up to 5, each one gives various effects to you, but they're always the same, also when you're at max stacks after killing a certain amount of enemies you get a shield buff, protects you from 1 hit. When you do get damaged, you'll lose all stacks. You can also equip multiple different shield buffs. Though be careful when falling down with a shield effect, some shield effects will cause a black screen after respawning the last spot where you were standing, you can't hear anything too, but you can move, so don't move, otherwise you can fall again, and just alt+f4 out of the game after waiting few seconds if you're safe, just to be sure the game saved. Though do mind because of that, sometimes weapons on the ground will have all their alt fire skills and traits erased.
It's a really good game.
I could write a lot, but just get the game and experience it for yourself. One of the best games I have ever played.

9.5/10 
Whichever psychopathic masochist came up with the idea a Rogue-like, bullet-hell, third-person shooter is a mad genius. This an absolute masterpiece of a game and one of the all-time best I've ever played. Every single aspect of this game is amazing: graphics, shooting, game-play, movement, combat, sound design. The music is really atmospheric and gives it a really cool sci-fi feel. The game runs incredibly well too (might just be my PC), it runs at a stable 120+ fps at ultra and looks amazing. Some of the coolest set-pieces I've seen in a game (my favourite is the citadel). The lore of this game is really intriguing with tons of stuff to uncover. Can be quite punishing at times but that honestly makes it more exciting. It also has online co-op to play with friend. One of my only criticisms of this game would be it's a little short for a Rogue-like as it only takes a few successful runs to complete the story content. I am also completely confused by what the story is meant to be. My only other criticism is that most runs feel pretty similar to each other, game-play-wise due to the only real difference being which gun you choose to go with, so I would compare it more to 'Hades' than 'Binding of Isaac' as far it's Rogue-like features go. I'm a little peeved that amazing games like this are kept from me for years because of consoles existing but that's an entirely separate topic. Absolutely would this recommend to everyone.

I don't often rate games, but this is definitely in my top 10 games in so many categories: storytelling, music, atmosphere, even categories like horror and science fiction. It's just such a good game.

Firstly, I really wanted gave the game thumbs down.

It seems that the co-op mode was added to the game when the developers realised that the game was very boring in single. If you like podcasts or have a second monitor for video, then it is likely you can try solo.
The plot seems very intriguing at the very beginning. But then it falls into unrelated mess with metaphors, which such a casual person as I am not able to fully understand. if you want to understand the plot you have to do it in solo mode. Some activities are unreachable in coop. In my opinion, sharing items with a partner and sorting out enemies is much more fun than falling asleep.

in general, coop mode is okay. The game that keeps you engaged solely by gameplay. I would like to recommend the game only in coop mode. It's fun, challenging and highly dynamic. Good variety of weapons / buffs + debuffs / enemies ([i]and bugs[/i])
The picture is beautiful, although the abundance of special effects sometimes burns out the eyes.

I understand the teleportation to the host as a quick and not too painful compromise. But sometimes it's too crooked. When you use location teleport it throws you back, when the host uses teleport game teleports you to the host, but when the host destination is not too far you have to use the teleport, but the teleport cannot be used because it is still occupied by the host... you cannot use the teleport when it is busy. But there are also teleports that must be used only together. Not many, it seems to be a trifle, and adds a sense of crookedness.

Bugs. Mostly missing indicators on the map or items that are located in different places for players. But, I faced "invisible" enemies once and the run was ruined. Also, the host player faced "out of video memory" on RTX 3090. And the icing on the cake, when the host was knocked out and I fell down, because of which the game cutscene did not start and we just got stuck. As a result, 2.5 hours were wasted. More to add, some type of enemies are broken. Sometimes they show animation that they are going to attack with the teleport but sometimes they do it just in a moment, so you don't have any chance to evade it.

Returnal means that you have to return. But most runs are really long. You can pause the run, but in this case, after restarting, your partner’s progress will be cancelled and it’s not a fact that you can call him into the game, due to the conventions of the cooperative mode.

Despite all the indignation above, we had a great time: we swore, laughed, analysed and tried different tactics, rejoiced at overcoming difficulties. All good qualities for a rogue-like game.
The harsh environment and the world force you to use what you get. And for the most part, the ecosystem of the game works to torture and please you, forcing you to complete one more run. 

I do not think that I will ever return to this game. But it will definitely be something to compare with.

As such, it's a good two-player co-op game, especially on discounts.

Fun game. Gets challenging at times, but overall a fun and rewarding experience. There are a few metroidvania elements to it as well, which at first may leave you scratching your head(it's not too bad and you quickly realize it).

There are basically 2 game modes to play. There's the main story to go through where you go through different biomes slaughtering everything and grabbing weapons and items while trying to stay alive, fighting bosses, dying and doing it again. Then there's The Tower, where it's much more fast paced with little time to rest, just going from one encounter to the next.

There is online co-op which is really cool. Basically you and another person can play the main story mode and go through the levels and bosses together. A couple notes on multiplayer:
1- Weapon drop rates seem severely reduced, adding to the challenge.
2- If one player dies, they have to wait to be revived by the other. Can be nice, but can also be tedious as depending on the situation, you could just be waiting around for minutes on end.
3- If a player disconnects during a session, they can't be brought back into the session. It gets locked out. You have to reset a run from the start. I found this to be an issue as in multiplayer I had an issue where if I fell off a ledge into a pit, I would respawn but the screen would go black. Gameplay and sound was still present, but my screen was black. The only way to fix it was to close the game and reopen it. Once you get back you can't re-invite a friend into the game, you have to start it over. 

If you pick this up on sale it's well worth it if you like roguelites. It'll get your adrenaline going and keep you coming back for more death after death.

Unplayable, do not buy.

Just listing here bugs that have been reported since release, everyone knows about them and developers are not fixing:

- In coop, if you try to join your partner in a private session, you will see infinitely looping loading screen on top of gameplay, preventing you from playing (you can still control your character, but can't see anything)
- In coop if you die and you are not a host, you will see black screen and there is no way to remove it. You have to reboot the game, and then you will see the first issue
- Game crashes about 30-60 minutes at random
- Stuttering happens at random when enemies spawn (RTX 3090 here)
- If you have multiple screens and you alt-tab once, the game will not be able to lock the cursor to it's screen again, wasting the run.

Those issue above do not have working workarounds. The VP9 codec fix people refer to is for a different issue (which you may also have). If you have any of those issues, you they will happen EVERY time, its not intermittent.

Game is unplayable. Especially if you plan to play in coop. Avoid until patched.

Lots of talk about people needing the Starship Enterprise to run this game; and as a true-hearted Gamer Girl™️ with a rig the size and cost of a small country, I can confirm: This game crashed everything and attempted to take me and lives of everybody in my home with it.

It's not happy being played and in the extremely brief period I played it hitched intensely around the start and end of all cutscenes, before my graphics card imploded, and my computer bluescreened - the most catastrophic crash I've ever suffered in 2 decades of sweet sweet PC gaming.

Naturally I am scared to try to run it again (I did give it a few goes and it suffered the same performance problems so I got scared my rig would explode and kill the neighbours, and I went for the refund).

I hope it gets fixed one day because honestly the brief window of time I did get to play it, it was genuinely buttery smooth, and the benchmark ran beautifully crisp at max settings so... I'd love to play it one day! Soon? Soon. Let's have this review go positive. Love you Climax & Housemarque x
