This game has loads of potential. The graphics and atmosphere are great, the combination of bullet hell, first person shooter and rogue-like is great. The story and sound design is great. Single-player mode is mostly fine, but the business logic developers have unfortunately terribly failed to build a system free of race conditions. Almost every multiplayer scout session, there is a new bug encountered:
* Spawning below the floor
* Falling to death after entering a crypt for no reason
* Camera staying permanently tilted after exiting a teleportation animation
* Biome 2 Boss getting stuck at the border of arena, refusing to transition phase
* Teleporters stopping to function
* Items in a room spawning invisible for scout
* Individual Bosses suddenly doing 10x damage to scout for no apparent reason
* Spawning in coop without any perma upgrades (despite host having them)
* Spawing in coop with permanent black screen 
* Spawning in coop, unable to move
* Map permanently staying hidden after leaving a crypt
* Biome shop breaking, when host triggers backup machine in parallel
* Doors permanently refusing to open
This is just a _subset_ of most annoying bugs, triggered by timing/level loading conditions (especially in multi player). The devs seem to be entirely oblivious how to properly handle latency, thread concurrency and packet loss situations. It's a shame, because the concept is really fun, but in a game with hours long run sessions and literally dozens of game breaking timing bugs like this, fun dies rather quickly.

On top of this, devs didn't manage to have PC and PS players join the same sessions, nor implemented the full steam API.  So you can't find or chat with your coop host in case your game just "broke" by one of the mentioned bugs above. Neither are there any emotes. This being said, I hope there is a successor which builds upon this game concept and has better coding.

A Decent (Hard) Third-Person Rogue-like Shooter

I've only scratched the surface, and there are many more mechanics to unlock, but what I've experienced so far is engaging, albeit slightly frustrating. It's a love-hate relationship, for me. I want to explore more of the game world, see the weapons, level up my character, and become powerful to the point where the loot-loop becomes a fine-tuning process, and I have time to really build the perfect combo of abilities. However, what I often find myself doing is acquiring my first decent weapon, being unable to find (or afford) more health, and then failing at a boss.

There's no somewhat forgiving "camp-fire" / "flask" system from the 'Souls' games. When you restart, you start from scratch. Those player and gear levels all reset. It's brutal.

I can already tell that once you get the hang of the "parasite" mechanic, and figure out the balance between the "adrenaline" enhancements, there's probably a lot of powering up to be had. The dash mechanic is really nice, and I hope that you are able to increase the distance and cool-down, to feel even more powerful. What's infinitely frustrating is the unforgiving nature of the game.

For example, one hit (in a bullet-hell world) will typically reset your "adrenaline" meter or nullify many power-ups. Health is also extremely scarce, and it would be nice to have some sort of always-present reward for player aggression (similar to 'Bloodborne', where you can regain health by aggressively attacking, within a short window).

Housemarque has always been a favorite studio of mine. 'Super Stardust HD' and the PSP port were two or my all-time favorite games (bring those to PC, please), and 'Alienation' was one of the best 'Diablo'-esque co-op games I've ever played through (please also bring that to PC).

There are definitely some similarities between this and 'Alienation', but the biggest issue (and perhaps the shortfall of this game's design) is the third-person camera. I can't help but think that this would've been a much better top-down or "twin-stick" shooter; though, I'm sure they're probably tired of being known for that (why break what isn't broken?).

While a few of the weapons are interesting (and others definitely are not), the reloads feel totally broken. There's not any vibration or audio cue to increase your chance of a proper reload. The mechanic is a bit like the classic 'Gears of War' system (on-screen prompt and everything), but you don't get that audio pitch change when the weapon runs dry, nor do you really have the time to babysit the half-baked mechanic while you're "claw-gripping" a controller to navigate away from the projectiles in-battle. And so far as I can tell, you can't decide when to reload; weapons either auto-recharge after a period, or you cook off the magazine to bring up the reload mini-game prompt.

There's also a melee sword attack - again, reminding me of 'Alienation' - but it doesn't appear to be a very deep mechanic, nor very effective against most enemies. Then again, maybe that improves, the longer you play.

Housemarque has always been known for their amazing music and sound design. However, even with Dolby Atmos and nice headphones, the ambient soundtrack is indistinguishable from the sounds the aliens and robots make. While you're walking around, you won't be able to tell the difference between enemy sounds and the background world noises. It's very hard to locate enemy positions without looking at the map, and the game gets a bit too challenging early on to afford you those glances.

As with anything, it's possible this is by design. It just doesn't make for a fun experience when health is so limited and you have to play "keep-away" with every encounter, instead of feeling powerful. There's also a "malignant" de-buff system which is meant to create an element of mini-game challenges to "cleanse" your temporary skill handicap. You come across this when harvesting resources (opening chests, harvesting currency). You have the ability to either roll the dice with malignant infections or to "cleanse" the curse from the item by spending "ether" (which is exceedingly rare and needed for high-ticket upgrades and items).

Again, way too difficult to limit resources this much, especially earlier on, as players are still trying to learn all of the systems.

I will also say, that while the music composition is appropriately dark, I do miss the catchy music of past Housemarque titles, which often helped with player focus in stressful "bullet-hell" moments. Perhaps it would be easier to focus on the stress of combat with the sort of music you'd find in something such as 'Nex Machina' (10/10, buy that game, immediately).

Maybe I'm missing something, playing with the XBOX controller on PC, but I just constantly find myself spinning in circles and trying not to run into environmental hazards. Again, the third-person nature makes things a bit unfair, since the enemies still have split-second attacks and reactions as if this were a top-down shooter.

When the original 'Resident Evil 4' launched, they solved this by having enemies behind the player approach more slowly, and they gave players the ability to quickly reverse their camera. In 'Returnal', if you're in a full arena, you are 100% going to be unfairly hit by waves of bullets and beams as you focus on what's in front of you.

The auto-aim is mandatory, in my opinion. I don't see how anyone could go very far, using a controller, without that feature. I haven't tried playing with the mouse and keyboard controls, because I thought that the rumble features likely added a lot to the experience, and had read that the game was purpose-built to to sell the DS5 controllers (maybe that is a hugely different experience, I don't know).

Another issue is that boss doors / arenas are only sometimes marked. There are copy-and-paste "trap door" areas which are 90% cool item stores or loot, or 10% the hardest boss you've encountered, so far. It's not very clear what is and is not a "safe" area, or a checkpoint. The in-game respawn mechanics are not very thoroughly explained, and you basically just have to find out, accidentally. Again, perhaps by design (and fitting for the theme), but a bit frustrating, given the investment of resources and the lack thereof.

And when you inevitably lose to that surprise boss (immediately after you just defeated the previous one, and barely have any health), you start all the way from the beginning, again.

Graphically, the game is beautiful at times, but nothing completely mind-blowing. I had read that it's a "game which is only possible on next-gen hardware), but I could see it being downgraded a bit in texture resolution and appearing on the previous gen consoles.

I played it maxed-out on a 3080Ti rig with an i7-11700KF and 128GB of DDR4, at 4K HDR 120FPS. Performance is overall smooth, until you get to the second world and the robots start spawning lots of projectiles in smaller spaces with environmental traps. DLSS implementation with UE4 seems to be a bit smeary and not-quite-there, but I may try the "quality" setting to see if that improves anything when hundreds of projectiles are on-screen. I opted to turn it off, for maximum sharpness.

It pains me to say this, but I'm a little let down. It's not bad by any means, it's just not as amazing as I had been told and doesn't scratch the same itch as other fast-paced Housemarque shooters. I nearly bought a PS5 for this game, and I'm thankful that I only had to spend $40 on a sale rather than going that route.

I'd recommend 'Returnal' if you're a Housemarque fan, but come into it expecting a bit of a frustrating experience. Maybe watch higher-level YouTube recordings to see if it eventually becomes the sort of game you'd like. I chose to go into it blind, as they're one of my favorite game studios.

If I had to assign a number, I'd say it's a 6/10 so far. I want to love it, but it just hasn't grabbed me, yet.

This game just feels like a very barebones roguelike. Most of the upgrades that you get mid run are all boring ass percentage based upgrades: "your gun deals 10% more damage", "deal 30% more damage to targets with low health". I don't know dawg, maybe Risk of Rain 2 has spoiled me with meaningful items, but the items in this game do not feel good at all to get. Half the time it doesn't even feel like I've gotten any upgrades, I believe the game to do the maths but the gameplay is barely affected by it. 

The weapons are really cool tho, too bad you are limited to one at a time instead of changing your playstyle on the fly. The game is already a high octane bullet hell dodge fest, why not give the option to change weapons to suit the situation that the bullet dodging has forced you into? 

My first impression of the game is that it was one of the truly "next gen" games that we've been promised. The technical aspect is really impressive but man, this game really doesn't know if it wants to be Doom Eternal, Risk of Rain or Metroid Prime. It takes a little bit of everything but doesn't really manage to glue it all together. The pacing of Doom Eternal without the flexibility of the weapon system. The roguelike elements of many games but without items that truly impact how you play. The exploration and atmosphere of Metroid Prime but without the metroidvania elements to properly back it up. As wide as a lake and as deep as a puddle. 

Its fun, but its disappointing in many fronts. I would recommend it to people who haven't played a roguelike before. I was very excited at the prospect of a triple A budget roguelike but this game really misses the mark there, specially compared to other options in the market.

Edit: After playing more I can confirm that it doesn't get better, the lack of build variety just makes it more repetitive. You just pick up the one gun that you like, get as much HP increases as you can and that's the build. Not a good roguelike, this game really should've been a regular third person shooter.

This is a bullet hell-esque rogue-lite 3d shooter, and those are all things that I like individually, so it'd make sense that I love this game. But it just feels tedious, I feel like I'm not learning anything new w.r.t. enemy patterns or mechanics on each death. It just feels like I'm dying because I accidentally hit a dead end in a randomly generated room and all the mobs cornered me. This wouldn't be a problem if you could carry more than one gun, but usually what happens is that I'm locked into one style of play based on the only gun I'm carrying. Also the decision to have your main currency disappear within seconds of an enemy dying, forcing you to put yourself in bad situations to collect money, is...an interesting one for sure.

A little bit too easy.  I kinda understand the story, but I've only cleared all acts once.  Either the story telling is kinda sub par and up its own ass, or there's a long way to go.

Edit:  Nope.  Story writers are up their own ass.  Ridiculously vague to the point where they aren't even telling a story.  Just making you write it yourself, based on their vague hints.  Maybe if they throw in a few more inscrutable references to Greek/Roman mythology it will make you think they're totally deep.

Gameplay is pretty good, though.

I just rolled credits after beating the Act II final boss. My in-game time says 13 hours played (I have a habit of leaving games open sometimes). I have a total of 19 deaths, about 5 of them are my first time getting to the fourth biome and having real bad luck. I only add this as context to what I've played and experienced in this game. I'm not done playing, but I've played most of what the game has to offer.

TLDR; Overall, I would say this game is an enjoyable experience with lots of fast paced and active content. If the combination of metroidvania, bullet-hell, and rouge-like mechanics with a narrative element sounds appealing then I would definitely recommend. $60 is a steep price. The $48 sale that I purchased at felt much more justifiable but closer to $30 would be the sweet spot (if it goes that cheap any time soon). Some performance bugs were annoying but did not detract from my overall experience.

Lots of people say this game is challenging. I can see why. However, I found it too easy to steamroll a run through of the game. Once you have enough health to make some mistakes, and gather ether for the death checkpoints, it's a breeze. 
The weapons were interesting and enjoyable with nice design and effects. The music, sound design, and environment design is well done. None of the rougelike or bullet-hell mechanics ever felt unfair, it was always my fault if I got hit or died. 

Co-op play seems interesting but is not the focus of the game. The hosting player cannot get scout rank (which is not that important) and the joining player cannot earn permanent upgrades (way more important). Co-op seems designed for late game play when there are less unlocks to worry about missing out on. And the Tower of Sisyphus SHOULD be coop (the endless mode). Luckily, there seems to be a mod to allow it to work in Co-op mode.

Graphics are amazing but I personally had performance issues. I have a Ryzen 3700X and an RTX 3070, playing at 1440p 165hz. My rig doesn't struggle too much but I had lots of performance issues with this game. After reading up, it seems that Ray-Traced lighting is a no-go for now and the performance issues come from loading areas of the game between rooms. It was most frustrating during boss fights and fighting groups of enemies. It was not the end of the world, but it was annoying.

A guilt fueled fever dream on loop, with tight controls and impactful guns. The atmosphere is delightfully oppressive as you see new levels, gaze at impressive architecture that you will see over and over again.

This might be some unlucky coincidence with my setup, but despite covering the recommended requirements and then some for the most part, and completely covering the minimum ones, the games runs like ass with everything on low for me. Fatal Error CTD's every 30-60 minutes, choppy performance all the time, invisible projectiles and other effects, the game failing to load new rooms - sometimes for a full minute, you name it. Seems the devs were somewhat aware of the last one because most gates have "door jammed, unlocking" state as a workaround to let the next room load, but the boss gate does not have this feature so I fell through the floor of the last room in the overgrown ruins a couple of times.

That being said, I wouldn't say the game itself is anything to die for either. Basically they fused rougelike and action adventure gameplay with a mysterious story. The story could be good from what I've seen so far, but the rest of the game is somewhat lacking in execution - the rougelike elements do not provide sufficient variety across runs, and the action adventure ones do not do anything to distinguish themselves from other entries in the genre. Ultimately what it achieved for me with its gameplay was make me want to play the better games its aspects remind me off again.

If either the game did a better job of hooking me in or I did not have such severe technical issues I'd probably give it a thumbs up, but under these circumstances I cannot do so in good conscience.

Beat it on PS5, and  I'm back here again on PC to play online coop with friends.

Performance is good on my PC, but I have a fairly beefy one.  There were times where the game glitched out, but I don't remember any hard crashes.  Story is amazing as is gameplay, but I almost feel like it's light on content for being a rogue lite.  It also really doesn't help that the achievement list really doesn't help make matters better. Finding glyphs randomly where there is only a small chance for each one to spawn?  Die over and over to reload the map to run through the map to try to find a single glyph?

That's a no from me, Dawg.

Anyways, overall this is highly recommended!  A couple blemishs here and there, but amazing overall!

An almost great game ruined by stupid design decisions.

When I first opened this game it seemed great with an interesting story and very satisfying gunplay and combat.

Unfortunately, one stupid design makes the entire game not worth playing: Actually shooting the enemies normally gimps your progress by not rewarding currency. Instead the optimal way to play is to cheese, wait behind cover and melee wherever possible.

The devs tried to artifically increase the variety of upgrades by making oblites (the upgrade currency) shoot in every direction and despawn near instantly after shooting an enemy. This means to collect enough currency to meaningfully progress you end up having to cheese enemies wherever possible, waiting for them to be in a position where it's easy to collect and making sure not to kill more than 1 at a time. This ends up entirely ruining the flow of the combat, the pace of the game and the overall experience.

Returnal starts out fun to play and appears to be a really great game! I love Atropos the alien planet and the world we get to explore. Graphics are also really great, though, audio vocals are inconsistent, often soft and difficult to hear. 3D audio and other options were NOT useful in fixing the INCONSISTENT VOCALS. I would score this game a 9 out of 10 until it becomes IMPOSSIBLY DIFFICULT and therefore NO LONGER FUN. The gruelling difficulty is compounded by the fact that you CANNOT SAVE your game at any one point and return to your save point. When you die you lose almost everything and have to START ALL OVER AGAIN from your crashed ship. We BADLY need a DIFFICULTLY OPTION available by default to make this game SENSIBLE and REASONABLE for most normal players. I don't want to spend hundreds of hours REPEATING in DIRE FRUSTRATION! WeMod offer some CHEATS that ALLOWED ME TO PROGRESS, but I shouldn't have had to cheat! Come on! I honestly can't recommend this game in it's current form. You might love it and really do your best, but you will end up giving up in frustration or cheating as I did.

Pros : Absolutely stunning game; like Ripley from Alien crashlanded on a Mass Effect xeno planet that's crawling with Matrixy parasites... and with a peculiar groundhog day twist.  Stripping it down to its components; yeah, its roguelike in its level design (the closest I've seen to it is if you were playing with Dungeon Tiles in tabletop). Yes, its a bullet hell.  But most of all it reminds me of Control in its action and deep lore, of Dark Souls in its slow peeling of the onion with repeated runs.  An intriguing mystery that's worth the effort. 10/10 for sound design as well; puts you in the heart of the action.  AAA for presentation, well done Housemarque.
Cons : its not the most stable of ports, on a old i7 with a 3080 I was getting big framerate drops/spikes; on a 7800x3d 4090 I still get CTD and screenlock on loading sometimes.  Persevere though, and the massive range of PC options are really lovely to customise and enhance the experience.

I'm not the best at the game's fast-paced combat, but even dying feels less disheartening within this game's unique thematic presentation. The story is quite out there and reminds me of my favorite things about films such as Annihilation from 2019. Also a huge fan of the music and sound design, really nails that eerie, unnerving vibe! I'm altogether enjoying my time on Atropos, and I definitely recommend this game, especially on sale.

Was really excited to play this and grabbed it as soon as it went on sale. Firstly, the game runs horribly. I frequently drop frames despite having the recommended specs. Despite only playing the game for a short time, I've also had numerous texture bugs, as in many textures simply did not load in. Low frame rate, poor textures, and an over-use of bloom often makes it hard to tell what's going on and react accordingly.

I think I could overlook the technical issues if the game was better designed. But so far it also suffers the classic Sony issue of being split between trying to be  a fun game and a narrative experience. Everything feels over animated. Get ready to spend a lot of time holding the scan button. This is not engaging gameplay, it simply slows the pace of the game and makes it feel like a slog to start. The story line is interesting, but it gets in the way of the gameplay. It's also hard to tell what enemies are doing. For example, there's a flying enemy which aims an orange beam at you. I've seen this move countless times already, and still have no idea what it's doing. It doesn't seem to deal damage, but it also gives every indication that it does (bright red color, following the player, ect.). Other times elite enemies leap across rooms in a flash, which often feels unfair. Enemies in general have too much health, again making the combat feel like a slog. The game gives every suggestion that it's meant to be fast paced, but the actual gameplay feels unbearably slow. 

The game also markets itself as a rogue-lite/like, however it is missing many of the staple features of the genre. There are only a handful of rooms, I've already memorized most of them after only a few hours. There are only a handful of weapons available initially, and while they seem to have some meta-progression, it does not feel meaningful. The active items feel similarly pointless. 

Nothing about this game works for me. I have no inclination to keep playing, although I likely will try for a few more hours since I've already spent the money on it. I'm extremely disappointed. If you are at all skeptical of this game, don't bother. Just play Issac or Dead Cells.

Lots of contextual dialogue, intriguing plot tidbits, and build posibilities.
Build an undestranding of the world and story as you try to make your defintiive escape from the in-universe loop. If you like Hades, third person action, Nier, and Metroid Prime, you will probably love this.

Returnal is super polished and super fun. It can get a bit frustrating as it sends you back to the start each time you die but each time you move forwards in the story it's super satisfying.

At first, the world is scary, desperate, if not hopeless. Wins are savored out through attrition and sweat. Some weapons feel absolutely useless as you hope the next chest has a better roll. You look for every chance you get to cheese a boss, hoping that the door closes just before they charge.

But you persist. Your heart pounds as you somehow take down the first boss. The win feels good, but now the desert awaits. Getting to the beacon feels impossible. Closer, dying, closer, dying. The cycle feels endless, desperate. But when you hit the beacon...it is but one of many. 

Yet the weapons grow in power. More is unlocked. Patterns in the bad guys start to emerge. Dashing feels natural. You realize you have a few precious i-frames on the use of your sword. Your grappling hook becomes your wings. 

Soon, that weapon you just got feels OP, broken. You wonder if the creators overlooked something. But as you look back at the hours you've invested, you realize: you earned that rocket launcher that both replicates hits as well as burns the bad guys. And soon after, you accidentally take down a horde of enemies in a single shot. 

The last boss falls. Again. To your hand. You realize your health bar is nearly full after that last one. Your items languish in your inventory, unused, as you cross the finish line. Finally, the Truth of the Cycle dawns on you: you're not stuck on a fighting on a planet with aliens, they are trapped in an inescapable loop with the righteous avenger of wrongs: you.
One of the best roguelikes ever made and most certainly the best triple-a roguelike. I will conquer the Tower of Sisyphus, even though I will have to push that boulder up once more.

Excellent roguelike with tight controls. Really great feeling and satisfying to learn & progress.

Limited progression is available for the joiner, and some critical story elements (eg House stuff) is not availabe in co-op.

Co-op scaling is a bit harder than solo play, with 2x health on enemies, and no additional resource drops to support the now-two-player experience.

This is one of the most addictive games I've ever played. I'm 52 and started at the Arcade to give you context.

The graphics are beautiful. There are small lag spikes when entering new areas but it typically doesn't effect the gameplay. The DLSS 3 update jumped my frames from 165 to 205 on my RTX 4080, 4K, epic everything.

The mechanics and gunplay are top notch. There are a compliment of weapons, while not a lot, that make you think about the next drop to pick up. Sometimes the best rolled weapon is not the best to fit your playstyle. Learning to effectively evade the bullet storm, ensuring you are reloading at the proper time to increase damage, and picking up obolites (currency) from fallen enemies, can be easily accomplished but hard to efficiently master. I still have a hell of a time and I think I have the mechanics down pat.

While you get stronger as you play, so do the enemies. Dependent on how many completions you've made, the same enemies you've gotten used to slaying will now have different special abilities or attacks. Using the environment to your advantage is a must. You should always seek some form of cover; never stay out in the open.

My major complaint with the game is the story. As much time as I've played and I still don't have a firm understanding of what the hell has happened. The story gives you snipits and never spells anything out. I don't expect this, but a little more would have been nice.

I recommend this game at full price. If you have the machine to run it maxed, you will be amazed.

A phenomenal game with an excellent sci-fi atmosphere, vibe, and plenty of challenge. Got the Platinum trophy on PS5 back when it launched and I'm impressed how well and fluid the PC adaptation feels with M/KB. The game was definitely designed with a game pad in mind, so if you have access to a Dualsense controller the aim-function for that enhances the natural rapid pace of the game. 

As some people have mentioned you are pretty squishy in base-form, but that's sort of the nature of a bullet hell game - which this is *very* much a bullet hell game. Others have also complained about luck-based aspect of the game but it's a roguelike so what did you expect? The upgrades and items start simple but the more you fail the more you're rewarded, and the more learn to properly stack items. So while a lot of it is up to luck, there's plenty of ways to be adaptable with what the game gives you and completely over-level yourself. The first time I ever beat it my health bar ran across the entire screen; partly due to luck and partly due to patience. If you have a loose idea for what you want for a build you can usually spec towards that if you play smart. 

Upgrades do come a little slow, and new items can only mostly be unlocked for a chance to find in a run at the beginning of each run - which depending on how good you are that could be an hour or two. Luckily there's a suspend feature to save your progress during said run. Outside of that it's extremely rewarding to do everything near-perfectly (especially in challenge rooms) because that allows you to stack on the upgrades faster and hit those overpowered moments. There's also a neat twist to the plot regarding the stages you play through and encourages you to play it over and over to explore areas and zones with newer abilities and situations. 

Also, the Hollowseeker weapon is the GOAT, look for those in particular.

I'd start the review by saying: If you're looking for a bombastic roguelike experience, Returnal definitely isn't it, there's games that do this miles better (Binding of Isaac, Hades...), HOWEVER, if you're liking the game's vibe and are intrigued by what it's got to offer, I have good news for you - Returnal is a truly unique game with an interesting, mysterious storyline that's definitely worth playing through.

I can understand if you're a bit afraid of the game being tough, it definitely is at times, and what doesn't help is the poor PC performance. On PC there are stutters even on high-end rigs so it's a bit of a coin toss whether the game will run good for you or not, but if you've got a high-end PC, the game should be running mostly fine for you. Returnal is pretty fast-paced and you will need to dodge a lot, so smooth fps will be key.

I'd say the strongest part of Returnal is definitely its story. The story is slowly unraveled as you progress through the various zones in the game. There's been a lot of careful work done to make sure the game's presentation and story is top-notch. Everything from the graphics, music and audio, cinematics and writing has been done in a way that makes you dive deep into what's going on, and oh boy the game's definitely cooked up some great plot twists for you, but you're gonna have to dig deep to find them!

The gameplay itself (while not being varied enough for me to call it a proper roguelike) is great overall. The controls are smooth and the gunplay feels satisfying. The roguelike elements definitely don't hurt the game, there's enough decision-making involved to make your runs interesting. Though I feel like if the game wasn't roguelike and difficult, it would gain a lot more traffic.

As is, Returnal is quite hard to get into. The game runs rather poorly, has a lot of mechanics and systems (though they're quite easy to understand in a bubble, they do get piled on you pretty fast) and is overall rather tough, though you're far from powerless, there's a lot of revival options and player boosts to help you get through your next run.

I feel like the best way to experience Returnal is to put on some headphones, immerse yourself while focusing on the gameplay so you can get through the story in full at least once. As a roguelike, it's nothing much, as a story/atmospheric game, it's amazing. So make up your own mind on what you're looking for when buying Returnal.

Interesting concept, terrible optimization, lousy game depth.

Earlier game is decent while you learn the mechanics and the story, later game is flat terrible. You spend thirty minutes carefully avoiding damage and hoarding health, then get dropped in 30 seconds because each hit lops off a quarter of what meager health you've managed to get, half the enemies are shielded, the other half have teleporting or homing attacks, and then when everything starts spitting out projectiles the performance drops to garbage and now the gameplay stutters.

Probably the worst part is that you CAN increase base weapon power and thus start with a stronger gun... except the power level is stupidly and arbitrarily capped (so you can get to level 25 in a run, but will never start higher than 15 on each cycle) and you start every cycle with the SAME FREAKING PISTOL. Every. Single. Time. Yeah, the traits will vary, but it's still the same garbage pistol and you can easily spend 10-15 minutes barely scraping by because the randomized level system just will NOT drop a new weapon for you.

Oh, and the weapon traits. Only a few alternate fire modes are actually worth anything at all, and some weapon traits can make a gun all but useless. And since you can't control any combination of these things, maybe a third of the weapons you find are actually of any use and MAYBE ten percent are actually GOOD weapons.

And the only thing as arguably as stupid as always starting with the pistol? Shielded enemies. Not a big deal when maybe one enemy in ten is shielded, but when you start entering rooms where literally EVERY ENEMY is shielded? And can do huge close-range spam attacks, making it terribly hazardous to break their shields with melee? Yeah, the game goes downhill HARD at that point because you've got a shooter that now wants you to use melee on everything but also has a terrible melee system.

For the power curve past the midpoint of the game, enemies rapidly get more powerful and more capable then you do. This means that, short of very lucky drops, you hardly ever get ahead of the curve and most fights turn into overlong grinds, especially as the shield ratio grows.

Ultimately, just another roguelike that screws up the balance and is arbitrarily limiting because it can't find creative or interesting ways to add challenge. Even on sale, it's just not worth the headache of trying to beat random chance for decent enough drops for a fun playthrough, much less a playthrough where you actually achieve any actual progress.

Easily one of my top 5 games of all time.  A fast paced, get good bullet hell where the only thing between you and restarting your run is your skill and some well-timed dodges.  There is 2-player online co-op if you're having trouble solo, score attacks if you enjoy that, and the game is very well optimized and stable.

The story will stick with you long after you've completed the game, both because of the amazing writing and the fantastic voice acting.  It's a very personal story about grief and trauma, and it pulls no punches, so be ready for that.  It takes a lot of inspiration from Greek Mythology and Greek Tragedies, but stands on it's own none the less.

I can't recommend this game enough.  Play with a controller if you can.

I first learned about Returnal from Coach Toolshed's YouTube review.  I knew immediately that I wanted to play it, and I was very quickly disappointed to discover it was a PS5 exclusive.  Well, no longer.  I have to assume some of the difficulty has been lost in the changeover to MKB schemes, but that doesn't make this an easy game.  You have a reasonable amount of health, but healing can be difficult and a few mistakes can ruin an otherwise excellent run.  You're most likely to be defeated by being overwhelmed, and that's all a part of the unique draw of a bullet-hell TPS.

Even so, the player is quite powerful, which adds to the sense of fairness.  There are plenty difficult trade-offs in every run, and the game allows you to be as smart or as stupid as you choose.  I particularly like how nimble you are, letting you keep up a strong defense with negligible interruptions to your offense.  Both the adrenaline system and the parasites are rewarding and unforgiving at the same time, which is a good mix for a roguelite.  I also enjoy the vaguely Metroid approach to key items, locking areas away behind ability acquisition instead of just relying on boss kills and keycards.  It's all part of the strong focus on gameplay and replayability.

There are a number of downsides, though.  I really like this game, but I have to admit that I enjoy it despite most of the visuals and all of the story.

The art style is extremely oppressive and dark, as you can see from any gameplay footage.  It's story-appropriate, and I do appreciate that in theory, but that doesn't make the endless piles of corpses, desolate and rotting environments, and highly suspicious omnipresence of tentacles any less grinding.  The quality of the work is very respectable, but it's no secret that roguelikes are very repetitive, so I wish we had a few more level pallets and a lot less ugly ruination.

As for the story, the plot is halfway-decent sci-fi pulp, which would be good--if it weren't for the all-but obligatory drudgery of a main character opining her bleary way through depression, hopelessness, guilt, dread, childhood trauma, pharmaceutical drug addiction, irrational fear, cruel fate, hallucinations, loneliness, and existential angst.  Oh, and don't forget that oh-so-worn-out "awe" we get to experience as we learn about this week's ancient, Lovecraftian, hyper-advanced, bloodthirsty, mythology-deconstructing, extinct alien race, all of whom were apparently well educated in neo-pagan nihilism and brutalistic architecture.  How the Hell have we made that bundle of ideas so tired?  I guess you can ask our clone army of twitter activist "games journalists," or the copypasta studios begging for an ad spot in their endless exhibitionist psychiatric masturbation cam shows.  I'm sure there are lots of redditors who will find this sort of stuff deep, but I'm certainly not one of them; I enjoy grimdark as much as the next guy, and I can forgive a cliche or three, but there's just too much of both here.  It never lets up, and that makes it very hard to take seriously.

And for the endless pouting anti-poetry of the audio logs, I will respond in kind:  "Someone... made this... for me... it must mean... something... stupid."

But, thankfully, the story is pretty minor.  This game really does care about being a game first, and I can pretty easily shrug off the nightmarish pipe-dream annoyances.  It's a little bit overbearing the way that the game tries so hard to find in-world justifications for being a roguelite, but I can ignore that too, and I suppose some hermits would call it all "immersive."  The first person "horror" segments are quite tedious, but they're not very long or close together.  They might even be optional, but I'm a mildly-jaded completionist so I'll never know.  Jane Perry does a bang-up job voice acting for Selene--though the entire Edge of Tomorrow reincarnation shtick had me wishing I was listening to--or at least looking at--Emily Blunt most of the time.

But you can't have everything, right?  It's nice to play a fun game, even if the writing is only trying to impress high school sophomores and the art direction is way too fascinated with Giger.  The score-attack tower climb is very fun, the daily challenges are enjoyably quirky, and the campaign levels are more than serviceable.  The 3D map is great, especially since it carries over one-to-one from the map menu to the minimap. The currencies are well-balanced, encouraging the player to explore thoroughly and risk death in challenge rooms and the occasional nasty secret area.  The platforming adds a lot to the game, both in combat and in traversal challenges.  The effects look great, and the enemy patterns are fun to learn.

Death has that signature appeal of good roguelikes and obscene hot sauces--it stings like Hell, but you're ready to do it again once the burns heal.  There are lots of build options, giving the player all sorts of limitations and opportunities to spark creative strategy.  It's always fun to plan your run around some strong items and abilities early on, then encounter something that can exaggerate your build into a glass cannon, or flip everything upside down with a brutal handicap or expensive sacrifice in exchange for an impressive new strength where you once had a dump stat.  The weapons are cool and diverse, with a wide variety of randomized mods; I would like it if the player could carry two or three, but that would bring in all sorts of balancing issues in a game that already boasts a complicated sandbox, so I won't complain about it.  

I paid full price, and even with all of the annoyances, I don't regret a penny of it.  And that's all you can really ask for--a game with strengths to outweigh its weaknesses.  By that standard, Returnal is a success.

This is a hard one to review. I've played 46 hours and beaten the game properly. Graphics are amazing, the gameplay is generally great, and the weapons are fun. The action is good.

Where the game falls apart is in a few places, first there is really limited permanent upgrades you unlock which leads your runs to being quite random, and often luck might determine things. After getting to act 2 I would just restart the run if the first room was too much. You always restart with a super weak weapon and even getting a different one can take a while.

The permanent upgrades on the guns are completely random and whether a gun comes with a slot that can be upgraded is also random. While the upgrade "availability" persists from run to run, it's really no fun grinding out weapon upgrades seeing as how rare they tend to be. Also some of the weapons (including the one you always start with), are actually pretty useless. I appreciate everyone might have favourites but if you watch videos on beating the bosses it tends to be done with the same types of weapons because the others are trash.

The entirety of Act 3 is simply replaying the game again. Doing so completes the story for "real", but given the abstract and open ended nature of the story it doesn't really feel complete. It feels like this was added on to increase play time.

Lastly, the game doesn't really build up on each run. Bosses for an area usually just need to be beat once (which at first is super wonderful given how hard they are!). But when you go for your next run, instead of trying to develop an amazing build you'll find yourself trying to get through the minimum number of rooms, taking the minimum amount of damage - hopefully getting some health max, maybe an artifact, and just trying to survive until you can advance to the level you're working on. Artifacts/items are super expensive, and the game doesn't scale well.

Also, if it matters there is no variable difficulty. I appreciate you need to die a lot in this game, that's part of the story. For some making it a bit easier to see the end might be nice.

Shut up and take my money! You like more money? Give us more of this and we make it rain😋.

Just finished all the story content for the game (including the Tower of Sisyphus) with 59 hours of played time. What an incredible game. Rarely have I played a game that combined the narrative with mechanics (roguelike) so perfectly like this one (Hades was also good in this regard). To me the highlight of the experience was uncovering the lore and absorbing the atmosphere of this world + underneath all the layers of narrative there is a super fun core gameplay that is a super fast paced third-person shooter. I wanted to keep playing because the gameplay is super fun and I wanted to uncover more and more of the story because it was intriguing. As a fan of cosmic horror, sci-fi and action games, this is a 10/10.

I recommend it, but I think it's pretty flawed.

Finishing the game one time through, and discovering the world for what it has is really interesting. A lot of fun to unlock the abilities in this game.

But many of the mechanics in the game are simply frustrating:
Adrenaline is a cool concept on paper, where you get more buffs for getting kills without getting hit. Except that if you get hit you lose all of them, potentially making some items in your build useless. If you're in a boss fight, you cannot increase it again because it's based off of kills. The smallest thing can count as a hit too, like a singular tracking dart.

The resurrection items are neat, but also fall into annoying. You can get parasites, buy restructures, or buy an item which will resurrect you without wiping the run. Yet for some reason, you aren't given a spawning shield or anything. So while you are paused and it tells you "Saved by X" you'll potentially have been grabbed or taken dmg from anything in the area.

Some of the guns are really good, and some of them are straight dog. Assault Rifle, hell yes! Electric Web Shooter, who the fuck thought of this? Making some weapons a must pick, and others an avoid at all costs. Most levels encourage you to have a fast shooting, low time to kill weapon. But for some reason the late game weapons are just projectile based slow ass weapons that you want to avoid because you've already progressed the earlier weapons more and they don't do enough damage for their rate of fire. Making it increasingly hard to get a good weapon you enjoy, and goes where you shoot, deals reasonable damage, and has fun upgrades. Which need to be unlocked.
This game is one of my favorite games. The struggle of this game makes me wanna get at it more. Having the weapons of all sorts is impowering
This game is perfect and very beautiful it delivers that raw unhinged challenge for those who seek it while also still maintaining reasonable fun and strategy behind it.

I've been waiting for this game to come to PC. Last time I played this, my buddies and I were all passing the controller around like the days before Xbox Live became a thing, laughing at each others misfortune and cheering successes. Have gone full m&kb for a while so trying to play with the controller was difficult but didn't take away the fun. Finally it's on Steam!

Now for the actual game review:

Gameplay felt more drawn out on console, resulting in a feeling of prolonged content, perhaps because I was struggling with a controller. On m&kb Returnal feels much easier by comparison. Almost blew through the three stages in my first run! Have given the tower several tries which is loads of fun and tried a weapon quest.

I still plan on playing more but overall it doesn't feel like a $60 game.  My opinion as of right now is to wait until Returnal is on sale for at least $40. 

Highly polished gameplay, a "meh" story, I really enjoy this game. Can't wait to try some coop. Hope this review helps!
